name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on reform of the EU asylum and migration policy in light of the continued humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean and Africa (2019/2516(RSP)).

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the migratory situation in the Mediterranean Sea has improved significantly over the last years in terms of the number of arrivals. In total in 2018, approximately 150 000 irregular arrivals were registered at our external borders in the Mediterranean. This represents a fall by a quarter compared with 2017 and is the lowest level in five years. This total for 2018 was also 92% below the peak of the migratory crisis in 2015. This shows that our resolute and comprehensive action and our engagement with key partner countries have paid off and should continue to be pursued. The number of deaths at sea remains too high, of course, and efforts must continue to bring it down. But in 2018 this number also decreased by a quarter since 2017, and on the central Mediterranean route alone, the decrease is more than 50%. The UNHCR estimates that in 2018 the Libyan Coast Guard rescued or intercepted nearly 50 000 migrants at sea. The EU holds an important stake in that number, and I would do like to start by referring to recent developments regarding Libya and the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa. Since 2014, the European Union has mobilised EUR 338 million on migration-related projects in Libya, EUR 318 million under the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, and EUR 20 million as bilateral assistance. One third – EUR 91 million – was granted to support the Libyan Coast Guard in the form of training, including on human rights and equipment to set up basic operational rooms for the Coast Guard in Tripoli and to support the development of Libya’s own Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre. EUNAVFOR Operation Sophia has so far provided training for a total of 237 coast guard personnel, and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) has provided training on access to the asylum procedure. Regarding our support inland in Libya, an important component of the EU Emergency Trust Fund programme consists of EUR 134.7 million in assistance and protection services to stranded migrants. It also covers voluntary humanitarian return assistance by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), including reintegration support, which has benefited over 16 000 migrants in 2018 and over 19 000 migrants in 2017. The EU entirely supports the evacuation of asylum seekers and refugees from Libya in the framework of the Evacuation Transit Mechanism (ETM) by UNHCR. Since its start in 2017, this has so far benefited over 2 800 persons. Finally, on 4 December 2018, following a month of negotiations with the authorities, the UNHCR – again with EU support – was able to open a gathering and departure facility in Tripoli. The facility is the first open centre in Libya, hosting migrants released from detention centres in view of resettlement. Nevertheless, a number of challenges remain on all Mediterranean routes, and they are very different from one another. The European Council conclusions of June last year set out clear guidance for priority action on each route. Hence we will continue taking forward the implementation of existing policies on the eastern and central Mediterranean routes. On the eastern Mediterranean route, numbers remain low, but the significant increase of irregular arrivals at the Greek-Turkish land border shows that we must keep a vigilant attitude to any shifts along the route. In this respect, cooperation with Turkey under the EU—Turkey Statement, as well as with our Western Balkan partners, is essential. Our work with neighbouring Mediterranean countries on the more pressing issues has been complimented with further engagement with countries further afield in Africa. The regional dialogue in recent years, the Rabat and Khartoum Processes and the Valletta Action Plan represent useful frameworks for a comprehensive and deep cooperation with African partners. They are supplemented by a robust set of funding instruments, including the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, through which the EU has been able to mobilise more than EUR 4 billion for actions across the main African migratory routes. New cooperation initiatives are also in the pipeline, like the upcoming EU—AU ministerial meeting of 21—22 January 2019, which will contribute to strengthening region—to—region ties and addressing common challenges. It will also establish a regular forum for discussions with our African partners. Regarding the reform of the EU asylum rules, the Council has worked intensively on these complex files during successive Presidencies. Fruitful negotiations have taken place between the Council and the European Parliament, which resulted in substantial progress on five of the seven proposals. The Romanian Presidency stands ready to continue these efforts in order to make progress where possible. For other important legislative files, like the Schengen Borders Code, the Visa Code and the Immigration Liaison Officers Regulation, the Presidency hopes to conclude the ongoing trilogues with Parliament before the elections. Regarding the reform of the European Border and Coast Guard, both co—legislators are putting a lot of effort into reaching a position which will allow them to start interinstitutional negotiations. However, there are still significant disagreements between Member States on some major issues of the asylum reform, in particular the Dublin Regulation. While all Member States agree on the importance of striking the right balance between responsibility and solidarity, it has so far proved impossible to find a compromise on the concrete elements of that balance. It has been argued that enhancing the responsibilities of Member States should be compensated by a predictable system which is capable of providing relief to frontline Member States faced with a crisis. Striking the right balance is not only about finding the right formula for the distribution mechanism. Solidarity can be expressed in different ways. The complexity of the situation is demonstrated by the fact that, notwithstanding the important decrease in the number of arrivals, there is still a high number of asylum applications, a big proportion of which are lodged in countries other than the frontline Member States. This shows that there are significant secondary movements which will need to be tackled if we want to come to a structural solution for the issue at stake.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please, colleagues, a little bit of respect for the speaker and do not interrupt. You may have the floor at a later time (protests from the left) ... yes and I have the microphone. Commissioner Avramopoulos, you have the floor. This is a difficult issue so we will try and have an important and strong debate on this critical issue.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I feel like we have been here before, discussing again and again the same issue in similar circumstances. However, while the context has changed and irregular migrant arrivals have dropped drastically, certain political attitudes have unfortunately not changed and so we find ourselves here again.  First of all, let me state that I am relieved that a solution has been found that allowed all the migrants on board the two NGO vessels to disembark in Malta. But also let’s not fool ourselves; having 49 people – 49 – on boats at sea for almost three weeks is not what the European Union stands for.  (Applause) It is even more shameful to think that this happened during the Christmas period. The European Union is about human values and solidarity and we are all determined to uphold these values. But if human values and solidarity are not upheld, it is not Europe.  At the Commission we spared no effort to call for and coordinate relocation pledges among Member States and make this disembarkation possible. I was myself, day and night, in direct contact with a number of ministers. I have also called publicly on all Member States to show more solidarity. This is a message I will keep repeating because we cannot continue to negotiate with human lives at sea.  First, I wish to commend Malta, as one of our smallest Member States, for demonstrating such solidarity and I plan to visit Malta very soon.  (Applause) I would also like to thank all the Member States that agreed to receive the migrants who disembarked in Malta: Germany, France, Portugal, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Romania, Slovenia, Ireland and Italy.  (Applause) All these countries have shown European solidarity in the most concrete way possible. But the European Union simply cannot continue to rely on unorganised ad hoc solutions when it comes to disembarkation. I was in Italy, as you know, yesterday where I had constructive discussions with the leadership of the country, with Prime Minster Conte and Interior Minister Salvini. We are all committed to establishing a truly European solidarity mechanism because it is not only through a European approach that we can really manage this challenge. The situation today is already proof of that.  The number of irregular arrivals today is nowhere near to that of three years ago and is 80% less than last year, and yet the political resistance today seems almost bigger. I ask everyone to open their eyes. We are not in a migration or refugee crisis anymore, although some try to present it as such. And while we are determined to continue reducing irregular migratory flows towards Europe, we also have to acknowledge that some migrants and refugees will continue to come, even if those numbers are much smaller today. This is not something that we cannot handle, but it does become unmanageable if countries have to act alone. It is for exactly this reason that we need predictable and sustainable mechanisms in place.  It is indeed critical for Europe to uphold its moral and human duty while at the same time to have in place a solid, sustainable, future-proof and fair asylum system. This is the essence of our common European asylum reform. Until we get there the Commission is ready to work with Member States to set up temporary arrangements. They will allow us to ensure solidarity with the most exposed EU countries while avoiding creating a pull factor. They will serve as a bridge until the new Dublin regulation becomes applicable.  I said this in December, and I will not stop making this point until we succeed: now is the time to finalise the reform of the European Union’s asylum rules, now is the time for the governments to take up their responsibilities in the Council and stop blaming the Commission.  (Applause) I count on this House’s continued support and before I close my remarks, I would like to express my gratitude to Parliament for its support during all these four years. Thanks to your support and your commitment we are in a position to say that we deliver, but we can do more in the future. But unfortunately the clock is ticking. We are running out of time and we have only three months ahead. Let’s do our duty. Let’s do our job.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, before I open the floor for our group speakers I will not be taking blue cards in the first round. We are quite constrained on time and a number of colleagues want to take the floor at the end of this debate.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, although the Mediterranean crisis has led to an attention to immediate needs, it has also highlighted the structural constraints of the tools on the Union's migration policy.  In 2016, the Commission pushed for seven proposals to reform the Common European Asylum System. To this day, there are possibilities for political agreement in five of them, but the Community institutions are in the hands of the necessary solidarity and determination.  The instruments contained in these proposals, even on their own, represent a step forward in migration management. Reform of the 'Eurodac' system, the Regulation for the European Asylum Support Office or the creation of a common resettlement framework may succeed if there is political will and political agreement, but further work is needed on reforming the Dublin system as, two years after the Commission launched its proposal, the divergent positions of the Member States continue and have prevented the Council from adopting a mandate to initiate negotiations with the Parliament.  The Union has everything at its disposal to alleviate this crisis: the 2015 European Agenda on Migration, the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa or the Union's External Investment Plan. In addition to the seven legislative proposals, a budget increase has been envisaged in the next financial framework that can reach EUR 10 billion, not to mention the signing of the Global Compact for Migration with the United Nations.  But solidarity and better management are needed to prevent men, women and children fleeing terror, wars or climate change from being left helpless, dying at sea or falling into the hands of criminal networks. The adoption of the seven reports and a firm commitment to European solidarity in the face of selfish and short-sighted political resistance would be a good solution.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. The latest in a series of such cases is the unfortunate story you mentioned, the 49 people who remained trapped on the Mediterranean Sea for 19 days, and no country on the Sea-Watch ship on which the refugees were trapped, even allowed entry into their territorial waters in order to retreat from storms in the waters. Despite the late response, I welcome the decision of the Member States of the Union which have decided to help and accept refugees, not least my country, Slovenia. And any such tragedy is new evidence that a common approach and response from Member States to the humanitarian crisis is needed, but when colleagues, when, I ask the Member States. We adopted the reform of the asylum system, which would go beyond the partial interests of individual countries and which would stand the tooth of time, was already adopted in Parliament two years ago, and I agree with you, Honourable Commissioner, that responsibility and guilt is now entirely on the part of the Member States. I wonder how many more tragedies we will witness before we act. Courage in action, loyalty to European principles and solidarity, and a common response to the challenges of our time remain the only real path to a solution.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we continue to repeat ing. In this context, I refer to the speech last summer by Mr Verhofstadt, the leader of the European Liberals, here in the Chamber on the need to reform European asylum and migration rules. He then blamed the Council for its response to the migration crisis. Verhofstadt argued in the same breath for European centres in African transit countries, where every migrant could apply for asylum, read: a ticket one way to the EU. This is really asking for trouble, because there are about 60 million people on the run worldwide. Europe cannot accommodate them all. That is why we need a limit on the number of migrants we take in. But as long as the European Parliament, like Mr Verhofstadt, continues to approach migration issues from the point of view of open borders, many European proposals for reform on migration will be stranded on the Council's reluctance. Parliament dictates idiotic and unworkable proposals, in the genre of airbridges between Africa and Europe, and then marvels at the refusal of the Member States.  This legislature is coming to an end and many asylum files are still stuck. It's time for realism. The unbridled influx must be limited. That is why we need to focus on the monitoring of external borders and support the Member States more.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, a year and a half ago this Parliament approved with a two-thirds majority a pragmatic reform of the Dublin Regulation – after very difficult work, I must say. We managed to join five groups in a text that actually points out the need for a truly European compromise.  We voted for a proposal that would ensure solidarity between Member States; where every Member State would play a positive part in correcting the failures of the current system. We improved the Commission proposal by ensuring immediate registration and security screenings of applicants, reasonable balance, easing the burden on front-line Member States and a fair sharing of responsibilities for all. Our text would incentivise applicants to work with the authorities instead of driving them to abscond and make use of smugglers. What I want to see is an orderly asylum system in Europe where those in need of protection who reach our shores would receive exactly that, and those that do not comply with the criteria would be sent back.  We did our homework in this House. What did the Member States do? They dug themselves deeper and deeper into the trenches. All of them seem to worry mostly about themselves and no one is ready to find a compromise.  Now I quote Commissioner Avramopoulos: ‘Open your eyes’. We are all time low on migration at this moment. And still there are a few that manage to reach our shores and we need to take full responsibility for them and we should do it jointly together. The result that we see from Member States now is that people rescued at sea have to wait for weeks in full despair and desperation as Member States haggle over their future. With every failure of the Member States the bar seems to be set lower and lower.  Believe me, judgment day will come and generations to come will ask all of us, why did you allow this to happen? Why? No one can give a full answer to that but we know that we managed to put systems together on everything except for human beings. The day has come for us to deliver. (Scattered applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, "At night, everything is black. I was very scared but I had to get in the canoe. I've seen a lot of people, rebels, shoot anyone. You could hear people screaming, screaming, crying. I thought I was dead." This, ladies and gentlemen, is one of many testimonies of a migrant who has survived the Mediterranean. Every day, on the edge of our Europe, humans die for simply wanting to leave hell - almost 18,000 since 2014 If Europe cannot accept all the suffering of the world, it must take its fair share in welcoming those who call for help, especially as it bears its share of responsibility for the causes of migration. Instead, the European Union, which likes to claim itself as the world champion of human rights, does not hesitate to make itself the best ally of oppressive regimes, such as Sudan or Eritrea, or failed states, such as Libya. Today, it is with European money that we finance armed gangs in these countries, occasionally renamed coastguard or security assistants - a deception that will not deceive many people. Because the objective is clear: to prevent at all costs the slightest asylum application from being filed in Europe. This is the clearly announced objective by the Austrian Minister of the Interior last July. And make no mistake: if the latter belongs to the extreme right, his positions have been de facto endorsed by the heads of state and government, both right and left. From summit to summit, they measure, as you did, Madam Minister, the success of the asylum and migration policy alone in the light of the decline in arrivals.  Fortress Europe is an insult to the values of the European Union. This repressive policy makes us complicit in regimes and, dare we say it, murderous regimes that trample on human dignity, at the risk of beginning to resemble them. But is it not already too late when, from Belgium to Italy, from Hungary to France, some governments criminalise migrants and those who help them? More than a year ago, rejecting everyone for itself and simplistic formulas, this Parliament adopted by an overwhelming majority, under the leadership of Mrs Wikstrom, who has just spoken, a position radically opposed to both simplism and populist flight forward. We had the courage to overcome national selfishness by abandoning the senseless rule of Dublin. Europe can do more, it must do more. She can do more and better, and if she doesn't want to give up her values, that plus and best is what is necessary for her.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you, Commissioner, for your contribution. But what does the Council really want to talk to us about today? That is what I am asking you. Do you want to talk to us about the 40 000 people who have died at the EU's external borders since 2000, or the 18 000 since 2014? Do you want to talk to us about the missing children, the tens of thousands who were simply gone on the unsafe routes to Europe? Do you want to talk to us about the women who have been raped in Libyan prisons? Do you want that? Do you feel like it? That is what I ask you, the Council. That would be exciting. For a year and a half, they have been blocking progressive proposals, progressive proposals, in which Parliament voted by a two-thirds majority, and not just with regard to Dublin, on the reception directive. You are blocking it! They are blocking a positive, progressive asylum policy. They are complicit in the many deaths at the EU's external borders. I am ashamed of you – for you, the Council, and I believe that you have actually forfeited talking about human rights.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after years of work, the reform of the common European asylum system has been watered down, drowned out by national self-interest, which does not allow us to find a common position on the fair distribution of responsibilities and solidarity in asylum and immigration policies between the Member States, as laid down, moreover, in Article 80 of the Treaty. According to a recent EPRS study, the shortcomings of ceas have an impact not only on fundamental rights, but also in terms of economic costs, which are estimated at around EUR 49 billion annually. This figure includes, among other things, the costs of inefficiencies relating to Dublin transfers, asylum procedures and even returns. The lack of legal access routes still leads to the use of human traffickers for those forced to flee war and persecution. Well, faced with this bleak framework, it is time for the Member States to move from words to deeds, showing consistency not only with the Treaties, and therefore with solidarity and cooperation, but also with an end to the neo-colonialist policies that continue to impoverish and destabilise entire areas of the African continent, exploiting human and material resources. At this point we can only agree with what italian Prime Minister Conte said yesterday, when he defined the issue of migrants qualifying for the European project. If we continue to prevaricate and ensure that individual countries tackle this phenomenon in a non-structural, but emergency, way, we run the risk of the entire European building falling.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, the Council and the Commission are praising themselves for the decline in migration. But let us be clear: it is the result of succumbing to blackmail from Turkey and of corrupt tribal leaders in Libya, where billions of taxpayers' money is being funnelled from EU citizens. It is the result of Matteo Salvini, italy's interior minister, reluctantly accepting the crackdown on people-smuggling NGOs. The Council advocates the same weak EU policy of returning illegal migrants, while Mrs Merkel acknowledged last week that the Turkey deal has completely failed on this issue. The Council has therefore agreed to send more billions to corrupt African countries, but to send back hardly one migrant.  So the solution has to come from the patriots again. As Mr Wilders has argued in the Netherlands for years, the borders must be closed and not only the borders of the EU, but also the borders of the Member States. This makes it virtually impossible to travel to Germany, the EU's migrant walhalla. Towing boats carrying migrants back to the African coast, and I tell you: the EU Coastguard is not going to do this. There, too, we will have to talk about the Member States where patriotic parties govern.  The only solution to this failing EU is the cooperation of sovereign states that themselves ensure the protection of their citizens. So I say to the Commission and the Council: stop your waste of money and failed policies and support Italy, Poland and Hungary. Take that as an example for the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the European Union, although it knew that the entry states of Spain, Italy and Greece do not have the necessary possibilities, nevertheless tolerated hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants seeking asylum for a long time in them, and especially in Greece. These people, as you know, live under miserable conditions, especially in Greece, and this is a stigma for our humanism and culture. On the other hand, now that things have come to an end, the European Union is trying to convince us that it will solve the problem by proposing some reforms to the institution of asylum and, above all, to the anachronistic Dublin Treaty. But these reforms will not succeed and will not succeed very simply because, as the situation has evolved, no state will implement them and they will be left empty. Because which state in practice will be responsible for examining the asylum application? But the state of entry. How will secondary movement within the European Union be restricted for these people? But of course by remaining in the state of entry. Thus, above all, Greece will remain and become a permanent place for illegal immigrants. So let the European Union leave the knee-jerk moves and hypocrisy and let the states protect their borders and work together to solve this problem.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the migration problem is, in the five years we have spent, a crack in the European construction. We need to speak with truths. The Commission has made very important efforts and we, as Parliament, have taken decisive decisions. However, the fact that, in particular, the Dublin proposal, which was perfectly balanced, remains an open subject in the Council, shows the responsibilities of the governments of specific Member States. We must demonstrate in the forthcoming elections – there is sufficient time – that solidarity and equal sharing of responsibilities is an obligation of all Member States because undoubtedly the fact that we are experiencing inefficiency in managing the defining issue – without responsibility, I repeat, of the Commission or Parliament – is pouring water on the mill of populism. The next bet we have to face is to prove that in the European Union democracy can defeat populism. I come from Greece that you all know was the first gateway due to its geographical location and the dramatic flows of 2015 were very important but always the problem exists. My country's government may have had problems with management and poor infrastructure, but it is the first Member State to show solidarity in practice. This solidarity is also the bet of the next elections, it is the bet of the future of Europe.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I just want to announce that because of time constraints we are not able to take a blue card, apologies to Mr Carver. We do want to take some catch-the-eye contributions.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, first of all, I am addressing the Romanian Presidency to tell you that you have the last chance to try to shed some light on this serious problem that we face in the European Union. It will be difficult for you to do worse than the Austrian Presidency, so you have a chance. Because it is very frustrating to talk about this issue again in this Parliament. This is a Parliament and that is what it is for, but European citizens must know that this Parliament has done its homework; that we have a roadmap to solve the serious humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean and Africa; that we have a recipe for making a reform of the Dublin system that is efficient and humane; and that it is the Governments, many governments of the Member States, that are slowing down this solution. It is very important that citizens know this, because citizens are talking about the whole of the European Union. And it is not the whole of the European Union. This Parliament has done its job, the Commission does its job to a large extent, and it is the Council that is blocking a solution. We talk about this Mediterranean problem as if it were a humanitarian drama. That's what it says in our title, but we treat it like it's just a technical problem. And we have forty-nine people circling the winter storms, because we are not able to welcome them in one of our ports. And that is because there are governments of the European Union that are blocking a common asylum and migration policy. This is what citizens need to know. To address their governments as well. Because, I stress, this Parliament, which, by the way, is also made up of twenty-seven different nationalities and very different political groups, has managed to vote on an important agreement which would solve the drama currently suffered by refugees and migrants. We've done our job. It's your turn, ladies and gentlemen of the Council.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Madam President, after many years of debate and work we are still not close to a solution to the migration crisis. The reason is that the approach of the Commission and this Parliament has been unrealistic. The left and the centre say that Europeans demand solutions. That is true, but Europeans do not want bad solutions. The common European asylum system is centred on ideas like solidarity, management and burden-sharing. What most Europeans actually want is not just managed immigration but less immigration, because massive third world immigration is damaging to our societies. Reducing immigration must be the cornerstone of any European solution. This is already understood in many Member States. I hope the next European Parliament has the will to deliver what Europeans need and want.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, what would we say if 2 000 people had died trying to cross Mr Trump’s border wall? We would consider that a gross violation of human rights, yet we hear the Presidency here say ‘oh the situation has improved significantly, numbers have gone down’. But Madam President, last year over 2 000 people died trying to cross the Mediterranean. We are very critical, and rightfully so, of this silly wall of President Trump, but Fortress Europe is just a European equivalent of that wall, and you in the Council are building Fortress Europe. You are building the wall. We just happen to have the Mediterranean in between.  Now, like Trump and his stupid wall, the Council is using Fortress Europe for populist purposes and political debate. Like Trump and his silly wall, you are spending billions on Fortress Europe and on unsavoury regimes, rather than adopting the package that’s on the table that has been adopted by a majority of this House. Something else: it’s not just the European Parliament and the Commission; it’s local authorities. The mayor of Gdańsk, who was stabbed to death, welcomed thousands of migrants into his city. You should take an example from that. You should learn from that, from all the NGOs and churches who are actually clamouring for a sensible, humane and effective asylum policy. It is ready to be adopted, so stop playing games. I would like to commend the Commissioner for his strong personal commitment and all the efforts, the tireless efforts, he is making for a common asylum policy.  I just have one small request to you, and that is true refrain from putting new proposals on the table, like the recast of the Return Directive, which is absolutely, completely unnecessary and just part of the silly political games of the Council. Do what the European citizens expect of you and adopt the asylum package, because yes we can do it. Germany has demonstrated it can be done, so just do it.  (Applause)

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Madam President, I wanted to start by making a comment on numbers. The figure of 65 million was raised earlier. This is the number of people displaced, the overwhelming majority of whom are in their countries of origin. And while we are seeing an increase in the number of refugees we also have to recognise that that is a result of conflict, persecution and that increasingly we are going to see people pushed to move because of climate change, and I am sure that even patriots would want a robust position from the European Union on tackling climate change if they are so worried about the growing number of people moving.  But I am concerned about what’s happening to a number of EU policies. A shift in our development policy where we’re actually looking more and more at migration control as a central point rather than poverty reduction. And I would like to ask Council whether they think we have got the balance right, where we are turning a blind eye to human rights abuses in Turkey and Libya? Whether the EU is doing enough on resettlement, that you mentioned, and that in terms of Dublin and secondary movements, are we doing enough to remove the push factors where our Member States are not delivering on the asylum policy correctly so people will move on for family reunion to have their claims heard? We need to be looking at what we are doing and we could do better.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we always say that we are a union based on law. Fake. We are not a Union on immigration and we are in violateing European and international law. The only regulations on which the Council insists are those on securitari, border guards, returns, which outsource asylum obligations. The files based on solidarity are all buried. A year and a half has passed and the Council is still not backing us on Dublin 4. The other files, qualifications and resettlements have been stopped for a year. The result, here it is: quarrels between Member States, criminalisation of search and rescue, ad hoc agreements between EU states to circumvent even the Dublin 3 rules, the handing over of migrants to Libyan lagers, Mr President, are death camps. The Council is guilty of omission of due acts and the Court should deal with them. Commissioner Avramopoulos is right, now is the time.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Madam President, Mr Lamberts said, I quote ‘people getting onto boats and dinghies in order to leave a living hell’. If Mr Lamberts is still here – he’s not here – okay. But, Mr Lamberts, does this include those migrants getting into dinghies in France in order to cross the English Channel? What are they fleeing from? What is the living hell in France that they are fleeing from? They are not asylum seekers, are they? These are migrants, and the problem we have is that we are conflating the issue; we are reforming the EU asylum and migration policy, but until we deal with migration policy, we cannot truly deal with asylum. We need to have a very strict ability to decide on exactly how many people come into Europe so that our local authorities can ensure that there are enough houses for these people, enough jobs for these people, enough schools and doctors and teachers. Right now it’s a free for all, and all that’s happening is that the countries that have opened up their borders – like Germany – have realised that they can’t cope with this huge amount of people and are now trying to force these people onto other nations, like Hungary and Poland – nations that don’t want them because they don’t have the infrastructure for them.  So until we actually manage – and government is about governing, about being in charge – our borders, until we manage how many people come here in an orderly fashion, how can we make sure that people who truly need asylum are not being ignored, or that we’re not creating migration fatigue among the people who live in our nations, leading them to turn their backs on those people who truly need asylum? Can we get our house in order? Reform means to improve. We are not improving anything. We are just moving the deck-chairs around on a ship that’s sinking.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, more than 'Fortress Europe', I would like to talk about 'strong Italy', on top of which there is a courageous captain, Mr Salvini, who has managed to apply the populist recipe, that of stopping the landings, of stopping the activity of human traffickers, which is the shame that this Europe has allowed. Commissioner Avramopoulos forgot to remind us of the list of 670 migrants to be relocated, which this Europe had undertaken to relocate. He returned from Rome without giving guarantees to the Italian Government, which asked for them, and from these benches there are many representatives of European governments, all in solidarity with Commissioner Avramopoulos. Let us move on to concrete solidarity, go to Commissioner Avramopoulos, on behalf of your country, and indicate how many of these migrants to be relocated, who are in Italy and which this European Union had undertaken to relocate, which have not been relocated, otherwise you are just hypocrites. Italy has the boxes full of having to suffer the negative results of the wrong policies. Landings must be stopped in order to stop traffic, stop landings and then review the rules of... (inaudible words) ... it is an institution before which the Italian Government acknowledges that it is subject, because it is an institution of high political civilisation. (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, the EU does not have a policy to control migrants; it has a policy to entice migrants. The EU policy has turned commercial shipping and coastguards in the Mediterranean into a taxi service for criminal gangs dealing in human beings. The EU is colluding in human misery and criminal money. If the EU were to insist that all asylum applications must be processed in countries outside of the EU, this would cut the deadly traffic immediately. EU policy is therefore resulting in death and human trafficking. It is encouraging the slave markets in North Africa. It has resulted in migrants being shipped into the EU for forced labour. The hope for Europe now lies in national leaders to protect our ancient nations from themselves. Sebastian Kurz in Austria, Viktor Orbán in Hungary, Matteo Salvini in Italy – these democratic leaders have taken back control from the migrant smugglers for the people.  Borders belong to nations. Without borders there are no nations, just a smugglers’ gold rush.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Colleagues, if we really want to help, we must be able to prevent thousands of migrants from risking their lives on their way to our continent. We must therefore make it clear that it is not possible to enter Europe illegally. Smuggling networks and routes in the Mediterranean must be eliminated, because it is not permissible for people smugglers to decide who can come to Europe in the current situation. Smuggling has become one of the most prosperous business models, and European NGOs are assisting in this by transporting migrants to Europe for hundreds of kilometres. Africa's population is projected to double by 2050. This will obviously lead to a new wave of migration towards Europe. So the problem will be with us for decades, stay with us. Mandatory distribution of migrants in the EU cannot therefore solve this, as can humanitarian or migrant visas. All ambitable signals are only a 'pull' factor, so it is an incentive for young Africans to go to Europe in the hope of a better life, because they will be distributed there anyway. Europe must be able to protect its external borders both on land and at sea, rather than managing situations that are being forced out by people smugglers. This is what our constituents expect of us, especially across Europe. We need to bring help to those in trouble, not bring the problem to Europe. There we need to strengthen the population retention power of the third countries concerned.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would have expected the Council to start its speech by apologising to the 49 people and crews of Sea Watch and Sea Eye, who have been holding hostage to a tug-of-war between states for twenty days. And instead he didn't name them and he made the usual bulletin of how much the flows have decreased, but if that's your goal alone, what's the next step? Shoot directly on the barges? It is shameful that neither the Maltese Nor the Italian Government nor anyone else has granted a safe haven for twenty days, in violation of international law. And who assures us it won't happen again tomorrow? Instead of moving forward, it seems to go back: in 2015 the governments had committed themselves to making 160 000 relocations, in two years they made just over 30 000 of them and today it took twenty days to decide on 49 people. We need a structural solution, and there would already be a structural solution: it is the Dublin reform voted for by a two-thirds majority of this Parliament, which shares responsibilities fairly, obliging each Member State to play its part in reception and enhancing the applicants' significant links with the various countries. Governments, do your job and approve this reform, otherwise you will explain to the citizens of Europe why your inertia and selfishness risk ending it in a drawer. And I would ask hypocrites, such as Mr Borghezio, to complain today about the lack of relocations, given that you voted against it in this House and abstained on the Dublin reform. (Protests off-microphone by Mario Borghezio)

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for There is much talk of reforms in this House, such as a reformed Dublin regulation. It would be based on the compulsive distribution of migrants coming to the EU. You could have realised from the outset that it would fail. You also talk a lot about solidarity, but you do not realise that real solidarity cannot come through coercion. It must be voluntary, and the EU can never order a Member State to show solidarity with a designated quota of asylum seekers. That is why today we have a deep divide within europe that just seems to be deepening. You have never understood the seriousness and tried to find solutions to migration in the surrounding area. Instead of finding practical, sustainable solutions, it has been more important for you to play good and be politically correct. Real solidarity cannot be reformed!

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – It is very simple, Madam President. This is the slightest parliamentary courtesy.  First, Mr Borghezio has spent half an hour in his word time and then gets up and shouts, insults other Members.  That is not tolerable in this House, and you should intervene.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Indeed, Madam, as you will have seen, I did step in on a number of occasions so I am trying to give balance to what is a very emotional debate. Thank you for your support.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, in the area of refugees and migration Europe is failing to comply with international law in many respects, but there are two where it is unbearable. The first is to refuse to have a refugee reception policy. And, please, I would like to join in the voices calling on the Presidency, in this case, to unlock, at once, the reform of the Dublin system. We cannot go on another minute without having a host policy worthy of this name. And the second is the criminalization of humanitarian aid. What has happened to Sea—Watch's ship leaving women, men and children for days in the middle of the sea without harboring it safely, which is an obligation under international law, is a real shame. And now, moreover, the question of the Open Arms vessel, which is incomprehensibly held in the port of Barcelona, is added. He is not allowed to go to life rescue with a mind-blowing argument: that if States fail to fulfil their obligations under international law, a ship such as Open Arms should not do so. So from here I would like to ask you to unblock the reform of the Dublin system and to stop criminalizing humanitarian aid and let NGOs work if you do not.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, what you are doing cannot be called migration and asylum policy, but rather close and outsource borders, cause the conditions for migrants to die, to murder in deferred. Drowning in the Mediterranean or abandoned in the desert... what's the most! They are migrants, but above all, they are poor.  Last month, a delegation from my group travelled to Niger to learn what you call 'the emblematic example' in the European Union's foreign and border policy: with European funds, Niger border guards are trained and equipped to fight terrorism and, by the way, to halt migrants.  The consequence is clear: those that were previously safe migration routes even for women with children are now routes of risk, kidnapping and rape, impossible to transit without paying mafias. Their policies favor the mafia business so much that they seem designed by the mafias themselves.  "We will continue to migrate" we were told by refugees from the war in Sudan, people who would now have the right to asylum in Europe but who have been arrested and tortured in Libya.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, like the United Nations with the Marrakesh Pact, the Brussels Commission believes that migration submersion is a fatality that must be accepted, or even a chance that must be seized. It wants to facilitate it with three foolish measures: first, the adoption of a Dublin IV regulation that would distribute new migrants among European states, according to a system of compulsory quotas; second, the creation of legal immigration channels; thirdly, the abandonment of internal border controls, which several European states have re-established for more than two years in response to the absurd Schengen agreement. None of these three measures will succeed. They will suffer the same failure as the Juncker Plan of 2015, which aimed to relocate 160,000 migrants and which several European states have rightly resisted in order to preserve their national identity. The peoples of Europe are mortal, they know it and they do not want to die. The Brussels Commission is deadly too, but it seems to be ignoring it. If we do not want to listen to the peoples of Europe, she will disappear.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, Madam Secretary of State, during the first two weeks of this new year one person a day died trying to reach our borders. Last year, 2018, we had probably the deadliest ratio ever, with more than one dead per 100 arrivals. There are fewer and fewer new asylum applications, and yet five countries continue to take in almost 75% of people. Given the recent populist narrative, we might think that at least the return of those who have no right to remain in Europe was going well. But it's not true. Here too governments fail. In 2017, the rate of return effectiveness was 37 %, below what it had been in the previous year.  We have been able to strengthen Frontex and we are about to do it again. One would expect that at least we could create the European Asylum Agency, one of the eight proposed structural measures. Here too, governments have not allowed it to act, as Mr Diaz de Mera has said. Madam Secretary of State, what do you intend to do in these four months of your presidency? Will the Council finally respect and listen to this Parliament? Have no doubt, Madam Secretary of State: inaction not only affects those seeking protection from our territory, it undermines our image in the world, weakens respect for our values and encourages outdated nationalisms and empty populism.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The events of the last few weeks, the boats full of refugees in the Mediterranean, show exactly the situation we are in today. In a situation where some Member States are unwilling to sign a new Dublin Convention out of political selfishness and stupid politics of fear and hatred. This fact is yet another testimony to the Council's simply inability to carry out its task. Since there is still no chance of a new Dublin agreement, I think we need a transitional agreement. A transitional agreement guaranteeing, at least until the new Parliament is in place, that refugees rescued in the Mediterranean will be distributed among the Member States which volunteer to do so. Member States that refuse to do so should provide technical and financial assistance to others. I call on the Romanian Presidency and you, Commissioner, to examine the possibility of establishing such a transitional agreement, because it would be shameful if we were unable to change this situation today.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Madam President! Every year, hundreds of thousands of illegal migrants flood Europe's borders. When you hear the debate in this Chamber, you could get the impression that we are actually supporting the illegalities that are taking place, both on the part of the traffickers and from those migrants who have no legal access to Europe. In fact, the vast majority of people in this House seem to think that up to one million people should be legalised every year without any conditions whatsoever to live, live and integrate here. This is perhaps the best answer to why it is so important for Denmark to have a reservation about all this integration madness that takes place every day here in the European Parliament. The only institution that has taken a fairly sensible line on this issue is the Council. It is therefore only to be hoped that the Council will stand firm and say 'no' to the crazy proposal on migration sharing and legal migration, which lies with the Commission and Parliament, and, on the other hand, takes the concerns of Europeans seriously and stops illegal migration before it rips Europe apart.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, first they decided to close lime and I sing the borders so that no migrant can set foot in Europe. Then they decided that the best deterrent strategy is to let them die in the Mediterranean. They force them to throw the sea in the hands of the mafias, because there is no other way to get there. There are no rescue ships chartered by the European Union and they don't even let NGOs save lives. The Spanish government prevents the Open Arms ship from going out to rescue people and thus becomes an accessory to murder. And now the strategy is to not even let them leave Africa. Border outsourcing is new colonialism and materializes in agreements with African countries where centres where torture and enslavement are financed with European funds. Cooperation funds are devoted to border control in Africa, and the European Union reaches agreements with bloodthirsty dictators, as in Sudan. Because it's all worth it in this election race where the space of the far right is contesting it until social democracy.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: – The President of Sinjura, meth nirreferu għal dak li ġara l-ġimgħa li għaddiet fejn dawk li kienu ilhom isofru għal kważi tliet ġimgħat, jiġifieri 49 persuna, inkluż ħamest itfal, tħallew abbord dawn iż-żewġ dgħajjes, fl-aħħar il-każ tagħhom ġie riżolt. Madankollu ġie riżolt qisu ttrattat fuq bażi ta' kriżi, b'telefonati għaddejjin bejn Prim Ministru u ieħor. Il-Kummissarju Avramopoulos naħseb li esprima s-sentiment Ewropew mill-aqwa meta qalilna: "Dan mhuwiex dak li l-Unjoni Ewropea għandha tirrappreżenta". Għaliex fil-verità dak li rridu huwa li jkun hemm mekkaniżmu sostenibbli li huwa bbażat fuq il-valur tagħna tas-solidarjetà, mhux li nittrattaw każ b'każ. U jiena nżid kummenti oħra hawnhekk ukoll għaliex rajna sitwazzjoni fejn ikollok anke tatti大i ta' pressjoni kbira minn pajjiżi kbar fuq pajjiżi iżgħar, tattiħi ta' bbulijar, u dan ma nistgħux nittollerawh.  Ma nistax ma ngħidx ukoll kemm huwa kru大jali li nindirizzaw il-kwistjoni li jrid ikun hemm policy ħara ta' ritorn ta' min m'għandux dritt ikun f'pajjiżna. Però ma nistax i nagħlaqx, Sinjura President, billi nirringrazzja flower-Gumssarju Avramopoulos għall-kummenti tiegħu rigward Malta.  Qal li se jerġa' jiġi fostna, mhux l-ewwel darba tiegħu, u mill-ġdid jerġa' jkun milqugħ f'pajjiżna.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, as we approach very fast the end of the mandate we only have a three-month window and it is somewhat déjà vu – a tiny country like Malta, 400 000, which was the country when I first became a Member of Parliament that was taking refugees and again such a tiny country taking refugees, again the Commissioner going Member State to Member State, and we have to then ask the question: are we deluded if we say there is no common policy or that we don’t reform Dublin or we don’t have a package?  That is the question everyone needs to answer today. And the answer to that question is, of course we need some common approach otherwise the shame of Sea—Watch and Sea—Eye will be repeated, over 2 000 people will die and their numbers will be added to and that will continue. So we have a window of three months, in that window an opportunity must be taken. We didn’t have QMV in the Austrian Presidency and I say to and I ask the Romanian Presidency: take this opportunity, we should have QMV under the Treaties, we should have some movement, the homework was done in this Parliament, many of the rapporteurs were here. Let’s take this opportunity. We have three months. Let’s do it. (Applause)

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Madam President, today we are talking about a current crisis in the Mediterranean, but at the moment we are not witnessing a new crisis, nor are we talking about large numbers of people. And at the same time, the European Union is paralyzed – where to redistributed another 40 people, after so many years in a row we have not been able to redistribde the thousands of refugees from Italy and Greece. After at least three or four years we have been trying to reform the European asylum and migration system, but we are failing. The way we can deal with any upcoming refugee or migration crises is by completing the asylum reform, so that it is clear who is responsible for asylum seekers, who is examining their applications, and how exactly the difference between asylum seekers and economic migrants is made.  It is important that this reform removes the burden of first entry border countries, such as Malta, Greece, Italy and even Bulgaria, and ensures that all Member States of the Union, wherever geographically located, assume their responsibility.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A few days ago, the cynical game of 49 people rescued from drowning by NGOs was finally ended. The refugees on the boats of Sea-Watch 3 and Sea-Eye were traumatized and completely exhausted in Malta after 18 days. The same question will soon arise again: will the rescue ships be given the safe haven they are entitled to under the law of the sea, and will the refugees be distributed in the EU, or will the Member States fail again? That is why I am calling for a solution immediately. There must be a coalition of willing Member States that agrees on a permanent distribution key. The Council still refuses to negotiate seriously on the European Parliament's decision on the Dublin IV Regulation. This decision contains precisely the distribution of solidarity that is always talked about. That is how I imagine a Europe of solidarity. The European Union must finally launch its own maritime rescue programme to put an end to the deaths in the Mediterranean.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Almost nowhere else in the world are the values of human dignity and freedom lived in the same way as in Europe, and not least that leads to prosperity in Europe, not least that makes Europe so attractive. These values also mean a european responsibility in the world, to take responsibility for a strong Europe with these values and also for people in need. This also means, however, that Europe needs a system that can really accommodate the most vulnerable, who are really in need, in Europe and do not support criminal smugglers. If there is no longer a migration crisis – as the Commissioner has also said – it is because the criminal smuggling routes through the Balkans, through the Mediterranean, have been pushed back. The fact that there are now fewer deaths in the Mediterranean is a consequence of this policy. We must protect the external borders, and we must, above all, now take care of integration in Europe for those who can come, who are the weakest and who we in Europe also need for the labour markets.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for more than a year now this House has been deliberating on its reform of the Dublin Regulation, an innovative, courageous reform, centred on the principle of solidarity. Without this reform, it is illusory to be able to think about managing the phenomenon of migration. Without a clear definition of responsibilities and without any guarantee to protect the rights of refugees and migrants, the shameful events of Aquarius, the Ship Diciotti and Sea Watch will become the practice. I would like to thank all the NGOs involved in the search and rescue work. We must recover our humanity and first of all save human lives. We need to save them and take them to the first safe harbor. We must also have and demand a right to dock and disembark immediately. I also call for a dignified reception, a right to reception and the sharing of responsibilities. I call on the various governments to abandon all demagoguery and to act and to act in accordance with the Treaties, but also according to the two global compacts recently adopted by the United Nations.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, sadly attending this umpteenth debate on asylum reform — always frustrated by the Council — there are millions of Europeans who ask themselves and ask the current members of the Council what they believe their predecessors were thinking when they signed the Lisbon Treaty, which promised exactly what the European Parliament has set as a position , expressing its outrage at its non-compliance in all official languages of the Union: solidarity, integrated management of the Union's external borders and a system of shared responsibility in the management of asylum claims.  This therefore directly demands the responsibility of the Council, because we want an asylum policy that is humanitarian, effective and, above all, European. And the Council's responsibilities are not liable with telephone calls or emergency patches or emergency patches, nor with the massive non-compliance with European law, by stealing deaths in the Mediterranean or criminalising non-governmental organisations, but by the Council's compliance with its obligations and mandate under European law.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, some Member States have been happy to participate in the separation of individual African states by justifying these reckless interventions by fighting dictatorship and supporting democratic processes. Today, these countries are no longer functional, the central government in them is weak or nonexistent and at the moment it is impossible to cooperate with them effectively to stop migrant waves. This means that the European Union must make a double effort to successfully guard external borders, break up smuggling chains and bring order to migration policy. Further toleration of illegal migration will only strengthen organised crime. For migration and asylum policy to suit new circumstances, we need a clear division into authentic asylum seekers, refugees and economic migrants. The procedure and criteria for these three groups cannot be the same because their needs are different. The system so far has enabled massive fraud and this is a problem we need to address.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, 2019 will be a very important year. We need to show european citizens that we can tackle problems, and so we are asking here from the European Parliament for a very effective asylum policy. Mrs Stevens, no, the Liberal Group and Guy Verhofstadt, we are not advocating an open borders policy. We are faced with a single European asylum application and done shopping between member states. We stand for solidarity and responsibility between the Member States. We stand for faster handling, for the protection of children in migration. We stand for tackling the people smugglers, for reforming Dublin. We all know that Member States cannot cope on their own. Only the European Union can tackle asylum and migration, and those who claim otherwise with false figures and scare people, they should be ashamed. I ask the European Council and the Committee on Political Action. The package lighter, just do it now.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, the anti-European far right is gaining ground across the European Union. In the face of this worrying progress there are different strategies: one, that of Andalusia, which consists in directly bleaching the far right with the support, by the way, of members of the Group of the European People's Party and the ALDE Group. Another strategy is to isolate the far right, as has happened in Sweden. And another, even more common, is to take on the populist discourse and the false and simplistic recipes of the far right, especially in terms of migration and asylum. This is at least partly explained by the fact that we have been talking about the reform of the Dublin system for years and that we are talking for years about the reform of the asylum and migration system, and the Member States are unable to agree, demonstrating an alarming lack of solidarity, willingness to share responsibilities and cede sovereignty , that this is what the European Union is about. Gentlemen of the Council, abandon populism and selfishness, and take on this reform.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, four years after the outbreak of the migration crisis, we are still fighting over how many refugees and migrants each state will accept on its territory, not to make them its citizens, but to examine whether they are entitled to asylum. It is a disgrace for the Presidency and the Council to tell us that the problem is secondary flows and that solidarity is not the sharing of desperate people. What is solidarity, Madam President-in-Office? Give money to build camps? Secondary flows will exist as long as the door is closed and we don't stop the wars. It is very bad to hear the phrase 'illegal refugees and migrants'. People can't be "illegal." War is illegal and the arms trade is illegal, and we don't even talk about it. How many more children and women have to leave life to stop wars?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have taken five catch-the-eye questions. I apologise to everyone else who wanted to contribute to the debate, but time has run out. I now give the floor to Commissioner Avramopoulos to respond to our debate. Just before you speak – Ms Gomes, indeed you were among the first, but I do apologise – I am under strict instruction. Frankly, if this were my decision – this is a really important debate – I would give it more time, but I am under pressure from what is already agreed by those who are above my pay grade.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks for this very timely debate. I wish we didn’t need it, but unfortunately we do. As I said, and as many of you underlined during this debate, this is Europe’s last chance. We shall not spare any efforts. The Commission, and I personally, remain fully committed to continue working with you and the Council to achieve this very important goal: the reform of the European asylum system. I would like to thank you for this clear and loud support. We will continue to work together intensively to achieve the completion of our comprehensive work. To respond to Ms in ‘t Veld, all our proposals are indispensable pieces of a comprehensive policy. I have taken note of your remarks. I know how sensitive you are, and I respect that, but from our side that’s how we see the whole package and the policy we have to adopt. One should never forget that, in the area of migration, all our actions are interconnected and all the pieces have to fit together. Completing the European Union’s asylum reform is indispensable in order to curb irregular migration, to prevent secondary movements, to reduce abuse and to ensure that asylum applications are processed quickly and fairly across Europe. We all agree that cooperation with third countries is key, not only to prevent irregular departures to Europe, but also to eliminate once and for all the cruel businesses run by traffickers and smugglers. Partnership and enhanced cooperation with African partner countries is at the heart of our work. The EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa has contributed to delivering concrete results. It is also essential to ensure that all coastal states in the Mediterranean are able and ready to comply with their obligations under international law regarding search and rescue. A crucial element, therefore, is also our work on return, both with countries of origin and within the European Union. Last but not least, we need to continue our actions to strengthen and better manage our common external borders. Our proposal for a standing corps of 10 000 European border guards is on the table. This is what our Member States have asked for, and we have delivered. That is why we also need to advance those proposals on which we are ready or almost ready. We have to be ready for the future – an unpredictable future. This is in everyone’s interest. We simply can no longer afford these types of unorganised ad hoc solutions. Now is the time to put words into action.  In this electoral new year, I want to reiterate the message that Europe will be judged on what it delivers for our citizens, as Cecilia Wikström has also said. Our citizens expect a lot from us, and they count on us. I hope we will have a different debate soon, including key legislative files, so let’s move ahead and leave – this should be our goal – a strong legacy for Europe’s future.

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the situation referred to is indeed unfortunate. The Presidency is working with the Commission and Member States to find an arrangement that ensures predictability, in accordance with the international law of the sea concerning disembarkation, and enables efficient asylum and return procedures. In December 2018, the European Council invited the Council to continue work on the basis of its previous conclusions, that is and I quote here, ‘to seek consensus on the Dublin regulation, to reform it based on a balance of responsibility and solidarity, taking into account the persons disembarked following search and rescue operation’. The Romanian Presidency will therefore take the work forward on this basis. Over the course of several presidencies, intensive efforts have been put into an attempt to find a solution acceptable for all. Different concepts were tested; however, it has not been possible to agree on a compromise. As already explained, it has been clear that the agreement has to be built around the different aspects of the comprehensive approach, and this is the avenue that the Romanian Presidency intends to follow.  As I said previously, we are working to find an arrangement that brings predictability, in accordance with the international law of the sea concerning disembarkation, and enables efficient asylum and return procedures. I welcome the solution found last week on the two NGO ships, with the support of the Commission in liaison with the Member States.  It is of the utmost importance that we succeed quickly, even if only with a temporary solution. The EU as a whole – not to mention the migrants themselves – does not deserve to see this situation remain unresolved. At the same time, we will continue working on reforming the common European asylum system that will bring about a permanent solution to address the situation in the future. I remain confident that, thanks to all of our efforts, we can make an important step forward toward these goals.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, thank you for your cooperation during this important debate. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – We are sadly attending this umpteenth debate on asylum reform , always frustrated by the Council. Millions of Europeans are wondering and asking the current members of the Council, expressing their outrage, about the unacceptable blocking of negotiation in the Council. In the face of this we need solidarity, integrated management of the Union's external borders and a system of shared responsibility in the management of asylum claims. This issue therefore demands the responsibility of the Council directly, because we want an asylum policy that is humanitarian, effective and, above all, European. We cannot tolerate flagrant breaches of European law, robbing citizens of deaths in the Mediterranean or criminalising non-governmental organisations. We demand compliance by the Council with its obligations and mandate under European law.

We demand compliance by the Council with its obligations and mandate under European law.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – The case of the 49 shipwrecks rescued in the Mediterranean before Christmas by two NGOs and remained at the beach until 9 January, was "resolved" after 20 days, only as a result of an agreement between European countries. This is therefore an exceptional solution. We can no longer continue to address the issue of the redistribution of asylum seekers with buffer solutions. The Mediterranean remains the privileged place for migration routes from Africa, but the cold numbers published by Eurostat on arrivals and applications for international protection submitted to the European Union show that the situation today is fully manageable. Comparing the 2017 data with those of 2018 shows a sharp reduction in asylum seekers in the first instance and a collapse in arrivals. It is true, Mr Avramopoulos: Now is the time! We must arrive as soon as possible at a genuine reform of the Dublin Regulation, which is the only way out of the current crisis. Now is the time, but when will the time be for the Council to be responsible?

name: Miriam DALLI
text: bil-miktub. – Il-Kunsill qisu qed jagħti l-impressjoni li l-kriżi migratorand bħal donnha qed tbatti. Assolutament mhux il-każ. Qed isemmu l-fondi imma l-fondi waħedhom m'hu se jsolvu l-ebda problema jekk ma jkunux akkumpanjati minn politiki b'saħħithom li verament jagħmlu differenza.  Sakemm se nibqgħu f'sitwazzjoni fejn Membru wieħed jitfa' l-piż fuq l-ieħor m'aħna se nsolvu xejn. Din mhux suppost li hija problema tal-"front line Member States" kif qed issejħilhom il-Kunsill imma problema tal-Unjoni Ewropea kollha kemm hi. X'ipokrezija! Kontinent ta aktar minn 500 miljun ruħ jippretendi li pajjiż wieħed, b'anqas minn 500 000 ruħ, ikollu jirrikori darba wara l-oħra għal miżuri ta' solidarjetà ad hoc għaliex hemm numru ta' Stati Membri li g għalihom is-solidjetà ma tfisser xejn.  Lil dawk li qed jippruvaw jippuntaw subgħajhom lejn Malta ngħidilhom ji大大大ekkjaw l-affarijiet. Lil dawk li għandhom ir-responsabilità li jintlaħaq ftehim ngħidilhom li 4-ikeittadini Ewropej ma jistennew xejn anqas minn hekk.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – I listened to the debate on migration in the EP Chamber and heard a lot of nonsense. We need to build air bridges between Europe and Africa. Soon the judgment will come, and we who do not want to accept these migrants into our own homes will be judged on it. Everyone has to take responsibility for the migrants, even though we didn't invite them. That's the truth! My country and many others have not invited any migrants and we do not want to accept them, who invited them, to be so good and to accept and take care of them. We must protect our external borders, as is my country, because if it is not protected, it is not a border, but a mental line. We must distinguish political migrants and/or those fleeing war from economic aliens. This distinction must take place outside Europe. We need to export aid to these people outside Europe, not bring them into Europe and then cause problems here. I see the concern of our liberal colleagues, a worry that in the next parliament there will be many more people like me here and we will solve the migrant problem the way Europe deserves, not the way they want it!

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – We are sadly attending this umpteenth debate on asylum reform, which is always thwarted by the Council. Millions of Europeans are wondering and asking the current members of the Council, expressing their outrage, about the unacceptable blocking of negotiation in the Council. In the face of this we need solidarity, integrated management of the Union's external borders and a system of shared responsibility in the management of asylum claims. This issue therefore demands the responsibility of the Council directly, because we want an asylum policy that is humanitarian, effective and, above all, European. We cannot tolerate flagrant breaches of European law, robbing citizens of deaths in the Mediterranean or criminalising non-governmental organisations. We demand compliance by the Council with its obligations and mandate under European law.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The Seawatch3 saga shows the hypocrisy of European governments that claim to be Christians, but not even the Pope listen. The Commission may now thank them, but the governments of Italy and Malta have prevented 49 shipwrecked people from landing for more than two weeks, even when 10 governments were already willing to take them in. We've been told the NGOs that persist in saving lives. Citizens need to know that it is the Council, where governments sit, that is blocked in reforming the Dublin regulation, preventing a common asylum policy. Parliament has done its job. The fictitious Libyan "Coast Guard," the Khartoum and Valetta processes, the EU-Turkey "agreement" and readmission agreements invoked today by the Romanian Presidency, such as the horrendous "vallas" around Ceuta and Melilla, are products of an illusory "Fortress Europe". And, in fact, they feed the business of the mafias of human traffickers, who exploit the lack of legal and safe routes for access to migrants and refugees. Blocked in this matter, the Council sinks values and the future of Europe, helping to spread populism and xenophobic hatred, such as the one that murdered a courageous politician who fought them in Gdansk.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – It pains me to see that 49 migrants were stranded at sea for days waiting for the Member States to take responsibility and show solidarity in this heart—breaking situation. It pains me to see the ineptness and rigidness of the current EU rules, when all we have been fighting for in the last few years was a European solution to the migration crisis. It pains me to see that people’s lives were endangered because the Italian Government refused to comply with their international and European obligations. But it hurts much worse to see people deceivingly attacking my country, when Malta has done more than most EU countries have done in the last 10 years. When, Malta has taken in, per capita, more than any other EU country. And when Malta has successfully helped to conclude the ad hoc agreement for the quick and safe relocation of the 49 migrants. We cannot expect that every time Salvini decides to blackmail the European Union and the Member States, then Malta will take the burden and the responsibility for the whole of the EU. But please, do not let people suffer any longer and provide us with a sustainable European solution to share the responsibility among all Member States.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – The reform of the asylum system and migration policy is essential to respond to the humanitarian crisis we are witnessing in the Mediterranean and Africa, and which calls for our deepest responsibility as uncompromising defenders of human rights and the dignity of the human person, but also of solidarity, which we advocate for ourselves. The European Union cannot simply ignore the problem that it gives our backs on a daily basis, relying on disorganised and unilateral and almost always reactive solutions. There is an urgent need to reform asylum policy in order to reduce illegal migration, prevent secondary movements, reduce abuses by traffickers, and ensure that asylum applications are processed swiftly and fairly.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – Since 2016, the European Commission has been is is releasing progress reports on migration. They need to show the results of the policy. Arrivals have fallen by 90%. Migration budgets are increasing year after year. Only the resettlement figures are disappointing, but no government has ever complained about this – or before. All fine. But in our lives it is not essentially about numbers, or not substantial. It doesn't give us a warm home to return to. We don't feel safer on the streets. At the end of the ride, our job is no better protected.  Today's migration crisis is not a crisis of numbers, but a crisis of confidence. When refugees came to Italy, Greece, Germany and Sweden, people didn't experience that it's better to be in the EU than outside – quite the opposite. No progress report, return agreement or disembarkation centre that solves that. If it were up to the European Parliament, the Commissioner would come and say today that it will never happen again. That a plan is in place that ensures that a village with 1000 inhabitants will never have to take care of 400 unaccompanied children alone, because 26 other Member States will be ready. Today, European values were as tangible as the actions of Salvini and Orbán.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the analysis by the Austrian Presidency of the Council (2019/2942(SDR)).
