I would remind all honourable Members that, for this debate, there is no catch-the-eye procedure and no 'blue card' questions will be accepted. Before giving the floor to Chancellor Sebastian Kurz, I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency for its active cooperation with the European Parliament. I would also like to thank the Austrian Presidency for its invitation to me, on behalf of Parliament, to take part in the event dedicated to relations between the European Union and Africa, which was attended by the summits of the European institutions with Commission President Juncker and Council President Tusk. I believe that this presidency has ended in a very positive way. I would also like to thank the representatives of the Austrian Government who took part in the sittings of this Parliament and, of course, also the representation in Vienna in Brussels. I would like to end by thanking Chancellor Kurz immediately.

name: Sebastian Kurz
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr President of the Commission, chairmen and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased to be able to visit you once again in the European Parliament and to present the results of the Austrian Presidency today. We have had an intensive six months, a very dense work programme, but above all very good cooperation with the European Parliament. I would therefore like to begin by thanking you for the good cooperation that we have been able to ensure between the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament over the last six months. Thank you for the good support of our Presidency. During our Presidency, we have always attached great importance to full cooperation with the European Parliament. I would therefore like to express my sincere thanks today to Juliane Bogner-Strauß and to Karoline Edtstadler, who represented us here as the Presidency during the plenary sessions. However, I would also like to thank you all for the 161 trialogue negotiations that took place together, in which 53 agreements were reached. Thanks to the efforts of many in Parliament, the Council and the Commission, but above all because there was a willingness on the part of all those involved to compromise. In the, I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency team, especially our Ambassador Niki Marschik in Brussels, but also Alexander Schallenberg and the two teams in Brussels and Vienna. Since each Presidency is only one link in a chain, I would also like to express my sincere thanks to our trio partners Estonia and Bulgaria. I would also like to take this opportunity to wish the Romanian Presidency all the best for these intensive six months. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for your excellent work. I was here with you in July and said at the time that we should all take the European Union for granted, but must work every day to improve it. Although there are always difficult debates on substantive issues, I said at the time that I believe that there will always be more that unite us than that could ever separate us. I would put both the same today.  As the European Union, we always have the challenge that the European Union's structure is very complex, that decision-making sometimes takes time, often seems almost impossible, but that there is still so much that holds us together, that there is so much that we have to tackle, develop and resolve together, that there is no alternative to this cooperation and, above all, to the will. to find compromises.  I am glad that we have been able to reach some compromises with you over the last six months, and so Hopefully we have been able to move the European Union in the right direction on many substantive issues.  Given the current occasion, but also because of the dimension, perhaps allow me to start with Brexit and the challenges that come with it.  When we were allowed to take over the Presidency in July, we had the ambition to do everything we could to maintain the unity of the EU-27. Today I would like to thank the President of the Commission, but also Michel Barnier, for the careful negotiations. After all, it has been possible – and we have always tried to support this – to ensure that the unity of the EU-27 is still in place today. The European Union, it must also be said, has nothing to reproach itself for in these negotiations with the United Kingdom. We have negotiated an excellent withdrawal agreement that is balanced and even ensured a political statement on future relations. Even if the vote is negative – this afternoon in the United Kingdom – and the next few weeks and months may be difficult, I very much hope that we will continue to be able to ensure the unity of the EU-27, but also to bring about a joint action between the Council, the Commission and Parliament. Austria will certainly do everything possible to support this line even after the Presidency. In addition to Brexit, we have deliberately focused on three key issues under the motto "A Europe that protects". Firstly, security and the fight against illegal migration, secondly, prosperity and competitiveness, and thirdly, neighbourhood. Because if we want to guarantee security in Europe, we must also fight for stability in our neighbourhood. On the first area, on security and migration policy, despite the blockade on the distribution issue, we have succeeded in making progress on cooperation. with third countries. In particular, with Egypt, but also with other states, we have succeeded in ensuring that the rescue is no longer carried out only by European vessels, because this is always connected with the ticket to Europe, but that more and more rescues are also carried out by Egyptians, Libyan coastguards and others and that people are transferred back to North Africa after the rescue. As a result, a total of 95% fewer people are arriving in Europe today than in 2015. Most importantly, not only the number of arrivals, but the number of deaths in the Mediterranean has fallen massively. It is now the case that the central Mediterranean route, the Mediterranean route via Italy, is de facto closed. We have had virtually no arrivals here in the last few weeks.  It has been possible to secure an agreement among the interior ministers to strengthen the Frontex mandate: that Frontex will be able to cooperate more closely with third countries in the future, but also play a more important role in foreign transfers. As far as staffing increases are concerned, we remain in favour of all the Commission's proposals and will continue to support them. I would also like to invite you: please talk to your Heads of Government, talk to your governments, there are some who still need to be convinced here. As far as the distribution dispute is concerned, we have tried not to celebrate it any further, but to present a new proposal, namely compulsory solidarity. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the Commission for the positive speeches on our proposal. In the area of competitiveness and prosperity, the sustainable safeguarding of our prosperity and our habitat, we have focused on the sustainable strengthening of the internal market. I am pleased that the majority of the open proposals in the area of the Digital Single Market have been positively concluded, such as the areas of cybersecurity or the Broadcasting Regulation. We have also dealt with fair taxation of internet giants. It has been possible to bring about a change of opinion in the Council. The real decision-making is still missing, and here too I would like to invite you: please help us to convince the States, which are still somewhat sceptical here. Sustainability is of great concern to us as the Republic of Austria, and I am all the more pleased that it has been possible to ensure a ban on certain single-use plastics. However, the reduction of CO2 emissions for passenger cars and heavy goods vehicles is also a great success for the Council, the Commission and Parliament, because there have been successful trialogue negotiations here.  Protecting the workplace from certain carcinogens or agreeing to set up a European Employment Agency are further steps that I would like to mention here. A truly powerful Europe, a competitive European Union, of course, also needs a modern budget. I admit that, as far as the MFF negotiations, the negotiations on the European Union's multiannual financial framework are concerned, I was very, very sceptical at the beginning as to whether it might be possible to achieve success here. At the request of the President of the Commission, I was then persuaded to get us to work at full speed here, and he was right: it was possible to achieve far more success here than I originally expected. At the end of our Presidency in December, we were able to hand over a full negotiating box. I hope that the negotiations on the MFF can now proceed quickly. In the third area that we have identified as a priority – the Neighbourhood Policy – I, as an Austrian, am grateful that the Western Balkans have now once again become more of a focus for the European Union.  It is nice to see a positive development in some countries of the Western Balkans, such as the resolution of the name dispute in Macedonia, and the opening of two chapters with Serbia and one with Montenegro is a really important sign of the European perspective for this region. I very much hope that Romania, and also the future Presidencies, will continue to maintain the focus on the Western Balkans initiated by Bulgaria. I would particularly like to thank President Tajani for the cooperation within the framework of the Africa Forum. At a forum in Vienna, together with the African Union, we tried to focus more on the economic development of Africa in order to sustainably strengthen living conditions on the ground and also to stop leaving the continent to the Chinese in terms of investment. We have been asked by the African governments, who participated received a very positive feedback and again a big thank you to all who made this forum possible. Finally, it is important for me to raise an issue which, as a Republic of Austria, seems particularly important to us because of our history: the fight against anti-Semitism and anti-Zionism. In November, we held the first European conference on this subject in Vienna with all the Jewish communities from Europe. Council conclusions on this subject were adopted in December. I would like to thank all the Heads of State and Government in the European Council for their support, because I believe that it is important that, when Jews no longer feel safe in some Member States, we as the European Union do not simply take note of this, but fight resolutely against it. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank once again the Commission – especially President Juncker – the European Parliament – above all President Tajani – but also all the other Heads of State or Government and all the Member States for the good and constructive cooperation during our Presidency.  We have always tried to make a contribution to strengthening the European Union, finding compromises and achieving concrete results. I am glad that we have succeeded in this in so many areas, and I can promise you that we, as the Republic of Austria, will continue to play an active role in strengthening the European Union.  Knowing that there is already a bit of an election campaign in the air here, I wish all those who are standing for the European Parliament again in May all the best for the election campaign. I hope that, during the election campaign, there will be an intensive, objective debate on the future of the European Union, because that is what we need. I also hope, however, that this debate will always take place in a respectful tone, because that is entirely in the spirit of a united Europe and, above all, of the citizens of the Member States of the European Union. Thank you for the good cooperation during these six months and all the best of the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Chancellor, thank you for your speech, but also your strong engagement against anti-Semitism. It is very important for this Parliament to defend freedom of religion and dialogue between religions. Thank you very much for your work in this direction. We will in this Parliament commemorate the Holocaust in the coming days.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: président de la Commission. Mr President, Mr Ambassador, Mr Ambassador, who has played a major role in the success of the Austrian Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, Mr President- It makes little sense for me to repeat what the Chancellor has said here. The austrian Presidency's record is impressive when one considers the number of agreements reached between the Council, Parliament and the Commission. 134 dossiers were successfully dealt with, processed and negotiated, 73 political agreements were reached with Parliament and 61 with the Council. I have experience in the balance sheet, and I can compare what the Austrian Presidency has achieved with what others who have actually set out with higher standards have achieved, and I find the austrian Presidency's record impressive in every respect, with one relevant exception: I would have liked the Austrian Federal Government to have overcome this autobiographically weakening moment by opposing the , which many of us thought would have given our consent to the UN migration pact. The Chancellor knows – Sebastian knows, because I have wrestled with him on several occasions – that it would have been desirable if the Presidency had gone in the right direction instead of sending out negative signals. (Applause) But the truth is that Austria was not and is not the only country that is opposed to this migration pact. I didn't understand it, I still can't understand why this could have happened. However, with the exception of this, as I always say, autobiographically weak moment, i, as President of the Commission, have no objections to the Austrian Presidency, because I felt that, contrary to many previous impressions, this was a Presidency that served the European cause. In this respect, from a European perspective, I would like to see more presidencies that would be conducted with such stringency, consistency and continuity, as was the case with the Austrian Presidency. I really enjoyed the fact that we, as the Commission, have always been able to rely on the willingness of our Austrian friends to ensure the unity of the 27 when Brexit came about. It wasn't an easy job. Contrary to what one thinks, this debate is taking place not only at European Council level, but also in the expert councils, where Austria has shown a clear edge and followed clear lines. This deserves recognition and praise. I am very pleased that the Austrian Presidency – as Sebastian has just mentioned – has approved the Commission's proposals on the security of external borders. I must confess here that, on the basis of the admissions of the Austrian Chancellor, the Commission has modelled, reviewed and amended its proposal for the security of the external borders. We had originally proposed that we would keep two thousand x 10 000 men on standby by the year. This did not seem to the Austrian Chancellor to be appropriate to the request. But what I am now saying is that the Austrian Chancellor and the President of the Commission are the only ones who still stand by what everyone wanted. And the Austrian Presidency has tried to keep this idea alive in the various Councils. I would like to start by saying that I have the flu, so that is good news for you, because I can no longer speak when my voice is speaking – once again branding the duplicity of the Council. Everyone is asking us to do more when it comes to border protection. We are doing something, we are proposing something together with the Chancellor, and now there are withdrawals. I can only brand it. Either you stick to what you say and ask for, and then you do, or you should keep your mouth shut when it comes to important issues. (Applause) In any case, I am grateful to the Austrian Chancellor and the Federal Government for their maximum support for the Commission's proposals. I am also grateful that, contrary to initial concerns about the employment agency, we have made progress. I remember very well, Sebastian, that I had a sporting conversation with you in the Federal Chancellery and kindly admonished you to carry this topic on. This is what the Austrian Presidency has done, contrary to many concerns, sometimes even its own concerns, and I am grateful that, having a banking supervisory authority, we are now also getting an employment agency. Anyone who thinks of Europe, as I used to say, when I was only It was fundamentally wrong to be a trade unionist. Workers are also entitled to protection. Those who protect the banks must also protect workers, and the Austrian Presidency has helped us in this direction. (Applause) MFF, financial perspectives – the Austrian Presidency deserves praise and recognition. Despite initial concerns – as the Chancellor has just pointed out – the Austrian Presidency has succeeded, which in previous years has never been so early in the case, in filling the negotiating boxes, the negotiating boxes, so that the Council and Parliament – Parliament is somewhat more researched than the Council – now have a negotiating basis that allows us to make progress on financial perspectives. , which we need in order for us to reach potte in October – and this deadline is also a success for the Austrian Presidency. In this respect, I have only words of praise for the Austrian Presidency, knowing how difficult this 'crate boxing' is. I also wonder how to translate 'crate crate' into other official languages of the European Union. What I wanted to say is that the Austrian Presidency has been careful to gather the pieces that it needs in the overall context so that we can make further progress on the financial perspectives. I am also grateful to the Austrian Presidency for its clear words on anti-Semitism. I never thought that it would happen to me in my lifetime that Jewish fellow citizens would have to be afraid to profess their faith. Austria had special reasons to speak clearly about anti-Semitism. I was in Vienna months ago and also visited the Jewish community in Vienna to testify that there is no place in Europe for anti-Semitism, racism and xenophobia. The Austrian Presidency has not only expressed words of caution, but has also demonstrated that we are prepared to defend this negative fundamental resentment, which there is no need to continue. I am also grateful for the Chancellor's Africa initiatives. We had a high-level group meeting between Africans and Europeans in Vienna, as they say in German. This was an important message for Africa, because we need to know – and the Austrian Presidency has repeatedly stressed this – that there can be no European future without securing African futures. And this signal to Africa, coming from the Austrian Presidency, was already very important. So, overall, with the exception of what I said, this was a successful Presidency, and I have to thank the Chancellor, the Federal Government, the ambassador for much of what has been initiated and for successes that I did not think we could achieve at the beginning of the Presidency. Thank you and servus. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President Tajani, President Juncker, Chancellor, representatives of the Federal Government, Ambassador, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work he has all said. A warm welcome to the Chancellor on the balance sheet of the Presidency. We, the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, would also like to say thank you, because the balance sheet is impressive, it is strong. In the last six months, far more deals have been achieved for the future of Europe than we all expected together. And, frankly, politically it is sometimes a pity that we always have public debates on Europe only on crisis issues, that we only talk about what people see as problems on the continent, and that we hardly manage to get the positive issues, the issues that we conclude, that make Europe stronger, to be perceived. It is a pity that this is the case. We, as politicians, will have to live with it all the time. But this Presidency of the Council proves it quite impressively. The political record in the content has been enumerated. On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to emphasise once again the issue of security. With the defense fund in the field of cyber and drone technology, there are huge opportunities. We have strengthened interoperability, data exchange between security authorities, ECRIS as one of the issues. We have made progress in the area of prosperity, investment screening in Europe is an important point for us, the EU-Japan agreement was concluded during your Presidency, and we have achieved a great deal in everyday roaming, including roaming for bank transfers, so that people can feel it in everyday life. Last but not least, we have taken great steps in the environmental field with the ban on single-use plastics and the CO2 result. That is remarkable. And if people were more aware of what is being achieved in terms of content, we would be better able to communicate Europe. Perhaps more important is to initiate political debates beyond the content, because a Presidency of the Council must, of course, be in management, but it must also provide guidance. And we are concerned about issues such as the discussion on the protection of external borders at the first informal council in Salzburg. Prioritising the management of external borders in the migration debate is central to us as the PPE-DE; it is the precondition for any further debate on migration that we know who is on European soil. The fairness debate with the digital tax and, Chancellor, austria's progress now with a national digital tax to force the internet giants to pay a fair share for national structures is remarkable, is strong. Therefore: congratulations! This priority has been good for Europe. And the discussion of values – Jean-Claude Juncker has touched it: if we are in Europe on a continent where we are seriously talking again about violence against Jews, then it must be prioritized in an accentuated way. I myself was allowed to attend the meeting on anti-Semitism in Vienna, and what the Jewish associations told us there must wake us all up, must alert us all that we are dealing with the issue. The basic message behind this is: Never again! A great deal has been achieved. Congratulations! Finally, I would like to say that Austria has presented itself as a strong country with a strong government. The citizens have also supported it; As I have seen, in the six months they have been proud to be at the top of Europe, to be able to stand and to move Europe forward. That was a good presidency. What remains is that constructive work, leadership and the will to reach consensus lead to a good Europe. Thanks to Sebastian Kurz and thanks to the Austrian Presidency of the Council! (Applause)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Chancellor, the Austrian Presidency started with an important motto, which was ‘A Europe that protects’, and indeed we need a Europe that protects. But we can see that the Austrian Presidency was delivering more of another kind of Europe: a Europe of fears, retrenchment and a certain kind of selfishness. We regret this, because we need a strong Europe with strong ambition – so strong and so ambitious that we can provide the necessary solidarity.  This started with the refugee drama. We could have delivered quick, swift operations of rescuing and providing asylum. But we were confronted with several dramatic scenes in the Mediterranean, and we deplored this. Europe needs to define a fully-fledged migration policy to ensure the orderly, organised management of migration – because we do need migration. Instead, we were blocking some of the key pieces of this migration policy.  Then we had the episode of the Global Compact for Migration, which we very much deplore. This was endorsed by most of the countries in the world, and we saw in Marrakesh some of the Member States of the European Union not endorsing it, led by the Austrian Government – something we again deplore and something we just cannot understand. But this lack of ambition and solidarity also has connected with our citizens. Let us take the European Social Pillar – the biggest initiative we have. The Austrian Presidency could have delivered more quickly on the full package of directives and regulations which are necessary to implement the social pillar. We could not understand how it was even possible for the Austrian Presidency to postpone a meeting of the Council of Ministers. We are in a hurry, Chancellor, to implement this pillar in order to turn this into reality. And then we have the important negotiations on the multiannual budget. Yes, this is necessary to meet the new challenges in Europe and also to keep a strong commitment to cohesion. We were really disappointed that, in the last European Council, it was decided that the final agreement should take place only in autumn. This is too late. A lot of regions will suffer from this. We have the conditions to get the basic agreement before this, and we don’t understand why the Austrian Presidency was not able to put forward a more ambitious schedule to finalise this negotiation.  Then we had another opportunity on eurozone reform – something on which we have been waiting for years and years. The solutions are on the table. We might be close to an agreement enabling us to complete the banking union and to create the budget for the eurozone, something all monetary zones in the world have – they have a budget. But again, the Austrian Presidency was hesitating over this. This is a crucial piece to reset cohesion inside the eurozone and to overcome the divergences we have in this important area of European construction. Then tax fairness. Yes, we do need a new digital tax and we need to deliver this in a much quicker way. I must tell you, Chancellor, that from our viewpoint, the Austrian Presidency missed some key opportunities to deliver a stronger Europe, which we need in this particular occasion, because we are confronted with a new movement of ideas, calling for retrenchment, selfishness, a far right movement. In the face of this, we basically have a choice: either we make an alliance with them and make concessions to them, or we present a real fully-fledged alternative – a strong Europe, ambitious and able to provide solidarity.  So this is the way to go for us Social Democrats, and we really think that we need to move to a new phase where this new kind of leadership emerges in Europe. So these are our remarks, Chancellor.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, generally speaking, the Austrian Presidency was well-crafted, well-organised and efficient – that’s because Austria is of course a well—functioning country – so you covered a lot of issues. Let me do just a little cherry picking to pick up just a few of them. I will start of course with migration and security. I have to tell you that it was really refreshing to see a slightly different point of view from the Presidency and the Chancellery than we have heard many times before. You indicated very clearly what many other politicians were hesitant to say, namely that Europe is neither ready nor willing to accept continuous waves of migrants, as it would have an impact on both our security and the internal coherence of our societies. You also came forward with proposals and solutions. For instance, we’ve seen improvements of the Schengen Borders Code or the Entry—Exit System, which will both help to manage migration and help us to tackle illegal migration. I can assure you your message was heard and appreciated, particularly in Central and Eastern Europe and in the V4 countries. Again it was proven how important it is to find a consensus between the Member States instead of arbitrary solutions, like the very unfortunate relocation scheme pursued by the Commission, which unfortunately caused one of the most serious clashes yet between East and West and between new and old EU Member States. I hope that is definitely off the table. You also made it one of your priorities to ensure the prosperity and competitiveness of the European economy, especially through digitalisation and innovation, and you were right. While we have a well—established and functioning start-up culture, the biggest players often come from outside the European Union. We need to do more for start-ups and for small and medium-sized enterprises. In this respect, we need to remove trade barriers. I would also like to congratulate you on the swift ratification of the Free Trade Agreement with Japan, which happened during your Presidency. This creates the world’s largest free trade area, covering nearly 30% of global GDP. I hope that other similar treaties still in the pipeline – most notably with Singapore and Vietnam – will follow soon.  Last but not least, the Multiannual Financial Framework negotiations continued under your Presidency. They are not over yet, and that is good news, because this Parliament and this Commission are finishing their mandate, and therefore they should not decide on behalf of the Member States or Commissioners of the next term. External relations were also a big burden for you. I will not go further into that, but I will end by stating that the Austrian Presidency was pragmatic, non-ideological and not a Presidency of big slogans, but rather of achievable results. This is good news. It was good to see common sense once again prevailing in most of your endeavours, because common sense is exactly what my own group is trying to pursue in this Parliament.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Chancellor, I’m not sure whether you could bear even more congratulations, because we heard a lot today. So I will spare you by only saying that I think that that was an efficient Presidency and Austria did deliver as a Presidency on its intentions. But I rather look at always every six-months period of time, not as a Presidency issue but how did the European Union really do, and how have we advanced, regardless of the Presidency? And I think that this needs to be said. This is still a European Union of 28 – maybe tomorrow 27 – Member States where the Presidency has a key role to play, but obviously it cannot perform miracles, but it can help a great deal. I think that the balance sheet, as I’ve said, is pretty good. But if you speak of the number of trilogues, I agree with you: I think this is again a sign of an efficient Austrian Presidency. But let’s look into the legislation that we have enacted: is it really always the right legislation which will really deliver on the three priorities that you had or on the priorities that we will have in the future? I’ll give you just one example. Together with the rapporteur Angelika Niebler, we dealt with cyber security. I think the result is not bad at all. In fact, it’s a good result, and also I must say, even despite some clashes that we had with your ambassador (but that is a normal part of the trilogue), I need to say that it still reflects the lack of change of mind-set in the Member States. We still look at cyber security as an issue where we tack between those who would like to prevail in terms of competences and the rest, and we are as strong or as weak as the weakest part of the chain of the European Union. So that is just one example where I would like to say the numbers matter and you have been efficient, but it also matters what kind of legislation we are able to enact, how the Member States are ready and, of course, how we manage to strike compromises with real ambition. On competitiveness, on digital: yes, again I think that this is significant progress, but still at the same time, if I had the brain (and I don’t) and I invented an application, would I commercialise it in the European Union or would I go to Silicon Valley? And the answer is clear: I still would go to Silicon Valley. So there is a lot to do in terms of the European Union’s ecosystem. Let me just focus on two or three issues where I think we could have done better, for sure, and maybe that history will show also the Presidency. One is on internal security. I do agree with you and I think it was a balanced approach, but still let’s admit that we still have a block in the Council on a number of proposals which are still pending. And we are not facing today a crisis, we are facing a problem, and the moment the crisis would come, we could have significant difficulties on the budget. And I think that again, there is enormous progress – you have ticked all the boxes; the question is: how well were these boxes filled? And I must say I don’t agree with Mr Zahradil, who says that that should be left to the next Parliament. No, I think we have been elected or appointed for the whole term. But I think that he would have to explain, whether it’s on cohesion terms or to farmers, that, when you are really lagging behind, it has an impact on your businesses. But what I would like to say on the budget is that we should still proceed, and that’s maybe one critical remark also to Austria. I think that this is not realistic. I’m definitely against any waste of money, but I think that we need to address the fact that we have new challenges and we just can’t keep, without a serious revision of some of the policies, the budget, and eventually the sum will increase. But anyway, at the very end, I think with those remarks I think that you have done a very good job, but we as the European Union are not yet doing the job that our citizens really expect us to do, and we do fail on some issues. (Applause)

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I am sorry, Mr Kurz, I cannot quite agree with the praises of the previous speakers, because I am already wondering: what is actually left of the Austrian Presidency?  Many legislative proposals have not progressed and have become stuck in the Council. But what is really going to get stuck with us and what is really going to hang on to the people outside of the last six months is, on the one hand, the very embarrassing courting of Russian President Putin with a knee-jerk fall and all the drums and drums. On the other hand, it is precisely the political caprioles that the Austrian Government has beaten over the UN migration pact, and I have to say that was embarrassing: the Austrian government is actually negotiating this global pact with a lot of passion – I thought – for months. Finally, we have an effort from so many countries in the world to address the issue. So the Austrian Government is doing a lot, a lot of work, and then, after the work that has been done, pretending that this is all a devil's tool. Instead of working together to find sensible solutions, you have polemized and polarized, and you have put yourself in the right-wing nationalist corner, just as Trump and Orban did. And, Mr Kurz, I would say that you have harmed all of us, the whole of the European Union.  And that is not all: you have also shown us all that your government is whistling at our common European legislation when it matters. It is hard to explain otherwise that, in the middle of the Presidency of the Council, you decide to discriminate against EU citizens in social policy and to cut them's family allowance in fact – knowing full well that you are violating EU laws. Other governments are at least waiting for their presidency to be over, you have done the same – well. On the credit side of your Presidency, on the other hand, there is not so much to be seen for the last six months. You have not made any progress in the fight against tax evasion and tax dumping, and on the issue of CO2 ceilings for cars, you have unfortunately also distinguished yourself as a breakdown aide for the German car industry. Unfortunately, nothing has happened with the common European asylum system, and even at Frontex – even at Frontex, it must be said – the equipment has not progressed and has been put on the back burner, and these were also the priorities of the Austrian Presidency. After all, I have to say that we have made some progress in the fight against disposable plastics and I would also like to express my praise for the excellent work done by your officials.  Overall, it seems to me that the greatest achievement of the Presidency of the Council has been that you won the very first prize of the day as 'Fossil of the Day' at the climate conference in Katowice. Congratulations! But I have much more hope when I look at Austria itself, when I look at Austrian civil society. Many people are involved, interested in politics, taking to the streets against the shift to the right, against racism and against social dismantling. And I very much hope that these people in Austria will also be able to send out a signal in the European elections, because Europe needs a cosmopolitan and constructive Austria, and the whole of Europe needs a civil society as you have: a strong voice for social cohesion and against division.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mr Kurz, I am sorry, but I will disappoint you. I do not share the climate of self-congratulation and congratulations. I find it a disgrace to the European Union that Austria, as President of the European Union, has refused to sign the UN Pact on Migration in Marrakech. A Pact signed by 150 countries from all over the world, moderate, balanced, in the preparation of which you had contributed. I would like you to answer your second point: why did you embarrass the European Union, as President-in-Office, by refusing to put your signature on this text? I am not the only one who is telling you this on behalf of the European left. He told you more politely, more elegantly, and Mr Juncker, who belongs to your political group. You have also done nothing about the European social pillar, you have done nothing substantial to promote the Dublin reform package, to which we have long agreed, the European Parliament and the Commission. You delay it and block it. For the pan-European deposit guarantee, the famous EDIS, again procrastination and delay, thus not completing banking consolidation. To tax the giants of the Internet, nothing concrete. For the Multiannual Financial Framework, your job was to speed up the convergences in order to have an agreement before the European elections, because postponing decisions on this issue is damaging the European economy. I am very afraid that your co-government with a far-right party, founded by Nazi supporters in the Second World War, is a decisive influence on you, and that is why I think it is very worrying that such a right-right alliance will also be created at European level after the European elections. Because I've criticized you a lot, I'm going to close with a positive report. I think it is good that both you and unanimously the Council and unanimously the Commission and all wings of the European Parliament support the Agreement of the Prespas is an agreement positive for Greece, positive for Northern Macedonia, positive for the Balkans, positive for the whole of Europe. It is one of the good news that we have, unfortunately few at this time, and I would like to assure you that in the coming days the Greek government, the Tsipras government, is determined to ratify the agreement of the Prespas in the Athens Parliament despite the micro-political, demagogical reaction of the New Democracy and PASOK parties which, unlike the political groups of the EPP and the Socialists, oppose and refuse to ratify the agreement of the Prespas.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, President Juncker, Chancellor Kurz, I would like to thank the President of the Commission, Mr Kurz, for his excellent work on this Firstly, we should make three positive notes for the Minutes: firstly, the earth continues to spin, secondly, wars have ceased to be fought, and thirdly, the EU is bureaucratic as usual and unchanged.  And all this despite a first: so-called right-wing populists were involved in a government for the first time when it held the presidency of the Council of the European Union. This shows that there is a lot of change in the European Union at the moment, and quite drastically so.  The EU is different today than it was before the Austrian Presidency, because there is another novelty: for the first time, a Presidency of the Council has not felt obliged to put itself at the head of the European centralisers. It has been pragmatic and correct and cooperative, but it has not pushed ahead with centralisation. No example shows this better than the treatment of the UN migration pact. We in the AfD put this issue on the agenda early on. But I dare to say that it could never have dominated the debate in Europe for months if Austria had not been so resolutely opposed to the migration pact under its turquoise-blue government. Austria has courageously seerated from the herd of uncritical Jasagers and has thus made the public debate on the disastrous migration pact possible in the first place. Thank you very much for that, Chancellor Kurz. That is why I believe that the Austrian Presidency could one day be seen as a turning point in the history of the EU. I am not the only one who has taken on the defining power of a Presidency of the Council in the European debate. Such a small amount of querulance raises the profile of presidencies. I am sure that the Austrian example will therefore be followed by other presidencies which will set their own priorities. Ladies and gentlemen, a little resistance to the still prevailing direction of the EU does not yet make this government anti-European. On the contrary, not saying yes and amen is not just the right, but the duty of Member States. We must significantly strengthen the intergovernmental part within the EU's institutional framework. We finally need checks and balances that work again, and at last we need a 'no' vote against an EU that, under the leadership of this Commission and also of this European Parliament, is running like a superstate. This 'no' vote, I am sure, will be heard more often in the future, and it will do Europe good, I predict. Thank you for your attention!

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As an Austrian, I would like to begin by welcoming the Austrian Federal Chancellor, Sebastian Kurz, here, and I would also like to ask him to take thanks and respect with him to the other members of the Austrian Federal Government, at least on the part of our delegation, because/because this Austrian Presidency was highly professional, it was effective and it was exemplary. For all those who are looking for their hair in the soup here today and are also throwing dirt on this Austrian Presidency: may one thing be written into your family book, especially the ladies and gentlemen of the Social Democrats: the Romanian Social Democrats are also sitting in your group, and if you look at Romania, where proceedings against the top of the list for electoral fraud and corruption are taking place and the murmurs are all around, you are not exactly predestined for this, In the direction of the Greens, who are bringing the Freedom Party close to a regime here, I would also like to say one thing: it was the Freedom Party that co-decided in Austria for the largest restitution boost ever in Austria, and the Austrian model of restitution is now regarded as a best practice model in Israel, but also in the United States. I would ask you, for all the sensitivity of this matter, not to act in our direction with such unflattering reproaches.  I would also like to briefly replicate what the President of the European Commission said, who said that he could not understand why Austria did not accede to the UN migration pact. The explanation is quite simple: because there is a democratic majority in Austria – in the government, in Parliament – because we want to continue to determine our migration policy ourselves and not through a declaration that is supposed to be non-binding, but which says more than 40 times that we are committing to something. Austria would thus also cede a good part of its decision-making sovereignty on this important issue, including with regard to decisions of the Supreme Court, which could also be incorporated into our legal system and which, in our view, would be the wrong way to go. I would also like to point out that, during the Austrian Presidency, the issue of subsidiarity was also very important. There was the great congress in Bregenz. It is a perfectly correct guide, also for the future of the European Union, that this should be shifted back into national decision-making, which is better to decide in the national sphere than in the supranational sphere. The Austrian Presidency has been excellent and may this type of Presidency continue to serve as a model for all those who are still to come. Many thanks to the Austrian Federal Government!

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to thank Chancellor Kurz for his pro-European and pragmatic Presidency. This is an example of how a practical approach to European affairs is more useful than the 'always more inclusive' strategy. It is a good presidency programme, security protection, practical successes in the field of ecology, market protection from internet giants and other things that the Chancellor presented in his speech. This disagreement, which was pointed out with the Head of the European Commission during the debate on immigration policy, also speaks to the fact that there is more sense on the Austrian side, because a solidarity-based policy towards immigrants must be a responsible and realistic policy. A few years ago, the European Commission made a big mistake in imposing a quota programme for the distribution of immigrants, and he, truth be told, has contributed to a very serious decline in trust in the EU institutions and an increase in populism. We should therefore be careful about this. We should have a policy of solidarity and, above all, a realistic one. I think it is worth reflecting on the experience of the Austrian Presidency in this regard. I would also like to sign up to the fight against anti-Semitism, as Chancellor Kurz said, and I hope that this will be a good basis for extending this sensitivity to the protection of religious freedom in the full sense of the word, as well as the protection of the group that is most persecuted in the whole world– Christians.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the European Commission. Mr President, I do not have the impression that I would be well advised to add something to what has been said that would not look as if it was a complementary contribution to the content of this debate. I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency once again. To those who thought it would be appropriate to criticise the Austrian Federal Government for being timid on the migration pact, I would like to say that I am not just speaking on my own behalf, but on behalf of the entire Commission and many of them in this House. The assessment of those who think that this is not part of the democratic debate is a fundamental error.  On the whole, however, I agree with those who certify pragmatism to the Austrian Presidency. The Austrian Presidency has had it, and the results are that, on balance, this Presidency will go down in the recent history of European Presidencies as particularly successful. We all owe our thanks to the Federal Chancellor and the Federal Government for this.

name: Sebastian Kurz
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Mr Tajani, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Waiting for the work he has done. There is not much left for me to say. I would just like to thank you for your cooperation. I would also like to thank you for the positive speeches now. As you know, the European Union's motto is 'united in diversity' and not 'separated into equality'. This means that it is perfectly legitimate to have different opinions on substantive issues, and to take different positions between the political groups. That is what makes the European Union, and that is what makes our democratic Member States. I believe, however, that it is nevertheless important, despite the differences in areas where we need to make progress, to achieve this together. This is often very, very complex in a European Union of 28 Member States and three institutions. I am pleased that it has nevertheless succeeded in so many areas: the 53 trialogues, the MFF negotiations and many other issues, where we in the Council have been able to reach agreement, at least among the Member States. With this in mind, thank you for your cooperation, all the best for the Romanian Presidency and thank you once again for the hospitality here in the European Parliament! (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much for your engagement. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – Austria took over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union for the third time, after 1998 and 2006, on 1 July 2018. However, the Presidency in the second half of 2018 took place under a different framework than the previous ones. With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon in 2009, the position of the rotating Presidency was changed by the extension of the powers of the European Parliament. As the country holding the Presidency, Austria made a significant contribution to the legislative and political work of the Council. Austria put the Presidency under the motto 'A Europe that protects'. The access that Austria chose is a strengthening of the principle of subsidiarity: the EU should focus on the big issues that need a common solution and retreat on small issues where the Member States or regions themselves are better able to decide. In this sense, the Presidency has highlighted the EU's effective protection role, particularly in three priority areas: security and the fight against illegal migration, ensuring prosperity and competitiveness through digitisation and stability in the neighbourhood, bringing the Western Balkans/South-Eastern Europe to the EU.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. - Presidency means taking responsibility for the whole of Europe and building bridges. Unfortunately, this did not happen at the Austrian Presidency. Instead, the gaps between European partners are greater than before. I want to judge the Austrian Federal Government by its actions, but the result is mau. Apart from the fact that he has put up the issues of migration and external border protection, the Austrian Presidency has made no progress here. And although there is a lot on the table, nothing has been achieved in terms of protecting consumers, nor in the area of tax justice, and certainly not in measures that defuse social disparities. From the Kneissl-Knicks to the non-signing of the UN migration pact, which has triggered a domino effect: the political climate in Europe has been permanently poisoned. Although officials have done a very good job in 1,500 preparatory meetings, at the end of the Presidency there is no more than a big show with a nasty aftertaste. A Europe that protects needs more than fences and border protection. People must be able to rely on social protection for the EU. A pro-European Presidency looks different.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – 20 years on the creation of the euro is now marked. The single currency was presented at the time as the key instrument that would accelerate social and territorial convergence within the European Union. The reality of the last two decades shows that the euro, far from meeting expectations, has promoted social and economic divergence, becoming an instrument of dominance that has imposed on national states the neoliberal revenues prescribed by the European Union. In this sense, the liberation of the constraints that arise from Portugal's presence in economic and monetary union is now more than ever inseparable from our project of a left-wing patriotic policy.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The six-month Austrian EU Presidency has shown that a far-right government has advanced the EU's anti-labour strategy just as the liberal and social democratic governments are promoting it. With the law abomination for 12 hours a day, 60 hours a week, work until final fall under EU directives. The same in Hungary of Orban with the "slave law", in Salvini's Italy with the law-extortion to the unemployed so as not to lose unemployment benefit. The Austrian Government, on the basis of the agreement of all governments, went even further in strengthening the militarisation of the EU as well as the intensity of repression and deportations against uprooted refugees and migrants. A conclusion? Whatever urban governments call them, 'progressive', 'conservative' or 'far-right', they all worship the same god: the profitability of their urban classes, which is incompatible with labour-popular rights and their crushing requires powerful communist parties fighting for the abolition of capitalist exploitation and disengagement from imperialist organisations, as the only force that can make the real difference.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us now begin the formal sitting to celebrate the 20th year of the birth of the single currency, the euro. (projection of a video) Ladies and gentlemen, dear guests, today we are celebrating the anniversary of the twenty years of our currency. The euro is used by 340 million European citizens and is the second most important currency in the world. According to the latest Eurobarometer survey, three out of four Europeans give a positive opinion on the single currency. The euro has made our internal market more transparent and competitive, facilitating transactions, travel, trade and tourism. During the economic crisis, also thanks to the quantitative easing decided by the European Central Bank, and I thank President Draghi for this initiative, the common currency served as a shield, avoiding the collapse of the weakest economies. However, the crisis has also highlighted the failure to complete the euro building and some mistakes made in managing the problem of sovereign debts. It must be acknowledged that not everyone is convinced of the proper functioning of the single currency, and there are colleagues in this House too who criticise the construction of the euro and see monetary union and austerity excesses as a brake on growth and employment. Personally, I remain convinced of the goodness of the euro project, but the euro cannot be an end in itself, it must be an instrument for achieving a social market economy, with the aim of bringing prosperity and work to all European citizens. It is therefore imperative that we finish the building we have begun to build, the banking union and the capital market must be completed as soon as possible, just as fiscal and economic union must be pursued. We cannot remain in the middle of the ford, where we risk being overwhelmed by a new crisis. The most recent data indicate a marked slowdown in industrial growth and production, with the risk of a new recession in some European countries. Economic and social disparities are growing between the different territories of the eurozone, and in some regions one in two young people do not find work. This is totally unacceptable. It is therefore clear that there is still a lack of effective instruments to boost investment, support the real economy, create jobs and stimulate social and regional convergence. It is therefore urgent to follow up parliament's call for a budget adapted to these challenges. My appeal is that today's celebration should not be a mere celebration, where we are lulled on our laurels, but should be an acknowledgeee of the problems that are still open. I call for European leaders to take responsibility for urgently initiating the changes needed to strengthen the euro and relaunch growth and employment, with the aim of giving jobs to as many European citizens as possible, because without work there is no freedom, without work there is no dignity.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Trichet, former President of the European Central Bank, you have the floor. Please.

name: Jean-Claude Trichet
text: ancien président de la BCE. – Monsieur le Président, je vous remercie. Mr President of the European Parliament, former Presidents of the European Parliament, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the Eurogroup, chairpersons of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, cher Mario, honourable Members, honorables membres du Parlement européen, je suis très ému, I am moved. I have the memory of my predecessor, Wim Duisenberg, who was there at the very start of the euro. I also have the memory of all the presentations before the European Parliament from 2003 to 2011. There have always been, as there are today, challenging – not to say very challenging – times for Europe. From that standpoint, I would like to stress four successes of the euro. First, it is a success in terms of currency credibility and stability. The ECB was given the primary mandate of price stability by the open democracies. From its inception, it was made clear how its capacity to deliver stable prices should be judged: less than 2% inflation. Since it was founded, the euro’s average yearly inflation has been around 1.75%. It’s better than the former national currencies. The domestic stability of the euro is echoed by its international credibility. The euro is the second international currency after the dollar, far above the third, the yen. Second, the euro and the euro area have proved to be remarkably resilient in the face of the worst financial and economic crisis since World War II. At the inception of the euro, a significant global analysis suggested that the single currency would be short—lived as an audacious experience deserving respect for its boldness but incapable of sustaining the difficulty of hard times. L’euro a prouvé que ces prédictions étaient fausses et il a démontré une capacité remarquable à tenir dans les pires circonstances internationales.  En ce qui concerne la solidité de la zone euro, pour faire brève une longue histoire, je dirai que les quinze pays qui étaient membres de la zone euro au moment de la banqueroute de Lehman Brothers en sont encore membres aujourd’hui, évidemment, y compris la Grèce, et que quatre nouveaux pays y sont entrés depuis le début de la crise financière mondiale, la plus terrible depuis la Seconde Guerre mondiale. Je ne crois pas qu’on puisse mieux prouver la solidité et la résilience de la zone euro. En ce qui concerne enfin le soutien populaire à l’euro, je dirai, comme vous l’avez dit, Monsieur le Président, qu’il est remarquable que 75 % de nos concitoyens approuvent la phrase: «une Union économique et monétaire avec une seule monnaie: l’euro» et que seulement 20 % de nos concitoyens soient contre cette proposition. Ce pourcentage est le plus élevé depuis la création de l’euro, depuis que l’on pose la question. Ce soutien populaire, qui, très souvent, n’est pas pris en compte par les commentaires sur l’Europe, explique évidemment la solidité de l’euro et de la zone euro.  Regarding the fourth success of the euro, I would refer to the last IMF Data Mapper, which suggests that there is no significant difference between per capita growth in the euro area and in the US. The same is demonstrated by the World Bank data: approximately the same growth per capita in the US and in Europe since the setting-up of the euro in 1999. I also think that the euro, as I said, is a process, not an event. One should not underestimate the decisions made since its inception, the reinforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact, the ratification of the Fiscal Stability Treaty, the setting-up of the Macroeconomic Imbalance Procedure, the ratification of the European Stability Mechanism Treaty, and last, but not least, banking union. But as you said, Mr President, a lot remains to be done: as Mario says so often, on top of achieving banking union and duly implementing the reinforced economic fiscal and financial governance, I will mention on a personal basis, fleshing out the budget of the EU area, which has been decided in principle, make significant progress in the capital markets union, appoint a minister of economy of the euro area and, last but not least, reinforce the democratic legitimacy of EMU in giving, on the most important issues, the last word to Members of the European Parliament within a framework where you would have the MEPs that represent euro area members. During the whole of my term, I can testify that, in my hearings before the European Parliament, I benefited from the strongest and most important moral support when we had to preserve price stability and engage at the same time on very bold non-conventional measures, including the purchase of treasury bonds from a number of countries in 2010 and 2011 before the decision taken by the ECB under the chairmanship of Mario. The twin messages that I received from the European Parliament were: be faithful to your mandate and deliver price stability; be innovative and bold enough, when necessary, to be commensurate with your responsibilities in times of exceptional crisis. Expressing my gratitude to the European Parliament, I cannot help but mentioning that I looked at the Eurobarometer and I could see that the trust in the European Parliament bestowed on it by the fellow citizens is important, superior of course to the non-trust fellow citizen, and it is better result than what we see for the national parliaments. I mention that very cautiously en passant. Jean Monnet once wrote: «Personne ne peut dire aujourd’hui la forme qu’aura l’Europe que nous vivrons demain, car le changement qui naîtra du changement est imprévisible.»  Nobody can say today what Europe will be tomorrow because future changes, fostered by today’s changes, are unpredictable. I would say that this remark remains true as regards the long-term future of the European Union, but I will be bold enough to say that we already know that tomorrow’s Europe will benefit from its credible single currency, the euro, as well as from its trusted European Parliament. (Applause)

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the Eurogroup, dear Jean—Claude, honourable Members of the European Parliament, it is with great pleasure that I am here today to celebrate with you the first 20 years of the euro. The euro is the most tangible representation of European integration that our citizens encounter on a daily basis. It is fitting, then, to celebrate this anniversary here with the directly elected representatives of all our citizens.  Over the years here, elected representatives and leaders and elected representatives in other parliaments have rightly recognised that ensuring economic prosperity and stability over the long term is a shared challenge that is best faced collectively. We are stronger together. With the Single Market, we have a powerful engine of sustainable growth to underpin our living standards. The euro has safeguarded the integrity of the Single Market. Today, our economies are integrated to a point that was not imaginable when the euro was designed. Intra-EU exports have risen from about 13% of GDP to 20% today, but especially, value chains are everywhere today in the euro area.  The euro has also produced two decades of price stability, including in countries where this was a long-lost memory. Stable prices have fostered people’s confidence in the value of their savings, which is one of the conditions for prosperity. Based on such confidence, firms invest and create new jobs. Today, most challenges are global and can only be addressed together. It is this ‘togetherness’ that magnifies the ability of individual countries to retain their sovereignty over the relevant matters, sovereignty that would otherwise be lost in the global world. (Applause) It is precisely in this sense that the single currency has given to all members of the euro area their monetary policy sovereignty, compared with the pre—existing monetary arrangements. It is together that we have a voice – and we had a voice – in the regulation of international financial markets, a voice which has been fundamental in reshaping the world financial regulation after the great financial crisis. However, in some countries, not all of the euro’s benefits have been realised in full. Partly, this is because reforms at national level are necessary – and by the way, they would be so under any monetary system – to produce sustainable growth; partly, it is because the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) remains incomplete.  Great progress has been achieved since the crisis struck, but more work still needs to be done; and there is no alternative to a future where we will all continue to work together to make our Economic and Monetary Union an even stronger engine of prosperity for all its Member States.  The European Parliament has had and will have a fundamental role in guiding and designing our European future. In the past, together with the EU leaders, the European Parliament took the fundamental decisions to create the Single Market, and in its wake, the euro.  Today, we are all reaping the benefits of their commitment, of your commitment, and we want future generations of Europeans to benefit similarly from our commitment as well. Today, our duty is to complete what was started two decades ago.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, today's event is a surprise event. Remember: many people, when we started the process leading us to the single currency, thought we were crazy, saying that in no way could this monetary union between such disparate countries work. We don't hear them as much today. MPs here and elsewhere, journalists everywhere, law professors, especially in Germany, professors of economics, still in Germany... everyone was telling us that we were embarking on an adventure that would lead the European Union to the brink of the abyss. We are far from the abyss, because today we can see with satisfaction, almost with happiness, that the work we undertaken twenty years ago has been successful. The credit goes to those who were looking to the future. I want to mention two of my predecessors in the various functions that were and which are mine: the Luxembourg Prime Minister Pierre Werner without whom - and without whose imagination - nothing would have been possible, and Jacques Delors, who was a great craftsman of European monetary construction. I could add other names. Many, but not so many, were those who, on the basis of their deep, continental and European conviction, thought that the adventure deserved to be undertaken. Personally, I was closely associated with the successful adventure. In 1991, as President of the Intergovernmental Conference, I and others, including Jean-Claude Trichet, led the process that led us to the Maastricht Treaty. The monetary part of the Maastricht Treaty is a noble, successful part, while the political side was weaker, in fact mediocre. When I signed the Maastricht Treaty on 7 February 1992 - I am the only signatory to the Treaty to still be in political life - I thought that the logic and dynamism of the single currency would lead us to a deepening of political union. Great disappointment, because that was not the case. Just as the economic and social convergence between the different member countries of the euro area leaves something to be desired. I have always considered that the main merit of the success of the single currency belongs to the European Central Bank, since the European Central Bank, whose principle of independence was heavily challenged when we began our work in January 1991, has meant that the credibility of the single currency has never been challenged by the markets or by... (Ringing a mobile phone) He's a Frenchman, I don't know which one... now I know which one... The great debates cast their shadow.  (David Coburn off microphone: "Mrs. May?") That was yesterday. Without the independent Central Bank , and many of us had to fight for the principle of central bank independence , the single currency would not have been successful today.  There are weaknesses. I was one of those - along with Mr Delors, Mr Maystadt and Mr Bérégovoy - who, from the beginning, had advocated for the economic government of the euro area. It is a great weakness that the coordination of economic policies is not perfect. It never will be, but we should have done more in terms of coordinating economic policies, including fiscal and fiscal policies. It is a weakness that remains and, therefore, we cannot give up. But we must revive this debate essential for the construction that awaits us. There has been a lot of criticism of eurozone policy. This criticism reaches me very personally because I was President of the Eurogroup at the time of the most serious economic and financial crisis. Yes, there has been reckless austerity, not because we wanted to punish those who were at work and those who were unemployed, but because structural reforms, regardless of the monetary regime in which we find ourselves, remain essential.  I regret that we have given too much importance to the influence of the International Monetary Fund. At the time of the onset of the crisis, many of us thought that Europe had enough muscles to be able to withstand the looming crisis without the influence of the International Monetary Fund. If California is in trouble, it is not for the International Monetary Fund but for the United States of America. We should have done the same.  Similarly, I have always regretted the lack of solidarity that emerged at the time of the so-called Greek crisis. We have not been sufficiently supportive of Greece. We have insulted and covered this country with invective, and I am delighted to see Greece, Portugal and other countries have regained not a place in the sun, but a place among the former European democracies. Es gàbe vieles zu sagen. Ich sage nicht alles heute, weil ich eine gewisse Spannung fer meine Memoiren erhalten mechte, an die ich ja denken muss, und da werde ich auch Ross und Reiter benennen. Ich bleibe der Auffassung, dass die europeische Wàhrungsunion Friedenspolitik mit anderen Mitteln ist - Friedenspolitik mit anderen Mitteln. (Beifall) Und deshalb mechte ich mich hier auch - im Namen meiner Generation - bei denen bedanken, die all dies meglich gemacht haben. Der Euro, die europeische Wàhrungsunion ist der einzige Beitrag, den meine Generation zur Vollendung das europeischen Einigungswerks beitragen konnte. Vieles war gemacht - so gemacht, wie wir es nie geschafft h-tten, wir Nachkriegskinder, die nicht mehr wissen, worum es eigentlich geht. Ich mechte mich hier bedanken bei Helmut Kohl, ohne den dies alles nicht meglich gewesen wre. Denn Helmut Kohl und auch Theo Waigel haben ja die Wàhrungsunion in Deutschland durchsetzen messen. Viele Regierungen haben im 'brigen wegen der Vorbereitung of the Euro-Prozesses ihre 'mter verlassen messen. Ich mechte hier meinen Freund Wim Kok lobend erw-hnen, der vor kurzem verstorben ist und der einen sehr erheblichen Beitrag zur europeischen Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion geleistet hat. Bleiben wir bitte ihrem Erbe treu! (Beifall)

name: Mário Centeno
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Mr President, Mr President of the European Commission, Mr President of the European Central Bank, dear Jean-Claude Trichet, honourable Members of the European Parliament. It is a pleasure to join you today to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the launch of the euro. The euro is one of the greatest achievements in the history of European integration. Our single currency provides a solid anchor for the creation of jobs and growth across Europe.  The euro has become a symbol of the European identity. It became a popular idea among 340 million people in 19 euro-area countries as it enjoys greater support today than ever before. As the world’s second most-used currency, it reinforces Europe’s presence on the global scene. Many predicted a spectacular failure of the euro, but we proved them wrong.  Not all of the past 20 years have indeed been easy. The financial and sovereign debt crises have put the single currency to the test. Shortcomings in the architecture of the Economic and Monetary Union came to the surface. Still, the single currency emerged stronger from the crises, thanks to committed national policy action and major improvements in the euro area’s institutional framework.  The establishment of the European Stability Mechanism and the banking union has strengthened economic policy coordination, which illustrates precisely this point. Today the euro area is enjoying a broad-based economic expansion, which started in 2013. The outlook is positive. Despite some loss of momentum and some downside risks that have been accumulating. Steady job creation has allowed increasingly more people to benefit from this expansion. The health of public finances and of the banking sector has also been improving. Much has been achieved during these 20 years. Nevertheless, more is needed to ensure that the euro area is well equipped to handle future crises. The Eurogroup has been doing its part. Its work paved the way for an agreement at the December Euro Summit on strengthening our single currency. This was the single biggest reform of the euro performed outside the crisis context. The agreement will allow for a more effective and broader use of the European Stability Mechanism and make our system of bank resolution more credible. Importantly, leaders also agreed to establish a euro area budgetary instrument for convergence and competitiveness. I believe this project can, in time, go a long way towards making the euro stable and inclusive. The work on this file is our priority in the months ahead, but the Eurogroup will continue working on other important issues, such as the European Deposit Insurance Scheme and liquidity in resolution. Step by step, we are increasing the resilience and the smooth functioning of the currency union. Euro area countries and their citizens will thus be in a better position to reap the benefits of the single currency for the next 20 years and beyond.  We cannot repeat it often enough that the euro is not – and never was – an end in itself. It is a tool, intended to increase the prosperity of the peoples of Europe. It is our responsibility to ensure that it lives up to its promise, and even more so in these uncertain times. It is our task to generate a more prosperous society, a more inclusive society, a society with less inequality within each Member State and between our Member States. I just wish to leave you today with the desire to say ‘long live the euro, long live a stronger euro’. Thank you for your attention. (Applause)

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: President of the Committee of Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I would like to start by paying tribute to previous and current Members of this House who have contributed to the success of the euro and to enhancing its democratic oversight and legitimacy. In particular, I would like to pay homage to my predecessors, Karl von Wogau, Christa Randzio—Plath, Pervenche Berès and Sharon Bowles, and I’m pleased to see that most of them are here today.  Since its design, the euro has been a powerful economic tool and an ambitious political project. First, the single currency is an indispensable complement to the Single Market, which has made possible its deepening and has boosted the integration of value chains and the strength of our economies. Second, as President Draghi has just recalled, the euro is a prerequisite for preserving and recovering shared monetary sovereignty, after the crisis of the Bretton Woods order and the development of globalisation, and this is particularly true for the more vulnerable Member States. Third, the euro is a cornerstone of a peaceful and closer union and a global actor after the end of the Cold War and German unification. We will never forget the vision and the courage of Helmut Kohl, François Mitterrand and Jacques Delors. In other words, a strong euro is a fundamental condition for protecting and relaunching the European economic, social and political model, faced with the transformations of our time. Ten years ago, when we were celebrating the euro in this House, the financial crisis was about to shake its foundations. That crisis has provided us with two lessons. The first is that, despite being incomplete, the strength and resilience of the euro are rooted in the common political determination to preserve its integrity. Here, the resolve of the European Central Bank and of its presidents has been decisive, and the euro has protected the people during the crisis. We should, of course, be able to distinguish between the euro and the economic policies conducted during the crisis, including some economic policy mistakes which were made at that time. The second lesson is that, if we want to achieve our ambitious goals, resilience is not enough. We need to complement our common currency with a robust, democratic economic and social union. Let us not wait until another crisis happens to develop the necessary tools to ensure stability and common prosperity for all our citizens. The euro is a journey, and it is time to move forward. I am sure that this and the next Parliament will fully play their part.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Now it will be played by the Quartet Avena, the European er. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments pending voting time)

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall be brief. I would just like to remind the House of one of our former colleagues who died last Friday, the former MEP Enzo Erminio Boso, a good, generous man, a former carabiniere who dedicated his political fight to the defence of mountain people. A memory, and I also want to tell him, dear Erminio, you die but our ideas do not die.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, my point of reference to the regulation is based on Article 25 and several sections of the enforcement measures, including, I believe, Article 74.
