On 10 December, the Office again took the decision to delay the entry of the supplementary pension of Members to 65, to reduce its supplementary pension by 5%, to de-index it, and to ask the Secretary-General to consider going further - Secretary-General, who, by the way, earns four times more than a Member of Parliament and whose pension will be perfectly protected. This is all the more anomalous since this supplementary pension fund was created in 1990 by Parliament. Colleagues paid very heavy dues for 15 years, with perspectives clearly indicated to them on the official documents of Parliament. It had already been infringed in March 2009, but with the promise that nothing would change.  The financial difficulties of this pension fund are cited, but it is Parliament itself that is responsible for it, since, when the single status of Members was adopted in 2009, it had decided that there would be no more contributors to the pension fund. The logic would therefore be for Parliament to take over the service of this regime, created by him and with him. All the more so because today, ladies and gentlemen, Members of Parliament have been receiving a new pension without ever having to pay a penny of contributions, and this since the age of 63.  I conclude, Mr. President. How far will we go in the violation of the vested rights of parliamentarians? Do we believe that the prestige of the institution is protected by infringing on the rights of the oldest members of this assembly in a way that would not be accepted with respect to ordinary citizens?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Gollnisch, the issue is significantly more complicated, but I take note and you will receive a response.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I stand under Rules of Procedures 22 and 45 and I want to raise awareness of a 56-year-old MP, Leyla Güven, who has been on hunger strike for 69 days. She was arrested one year ago for condemning Turkish invasion of Afrin. Many of the MEPs here also condemned that, but she’s on hunger strike against the isolation of the Kurdish leader Abdullah Öcalan and I ask you as President to look at her pre-trial on the 25th of this month and send a delegation of MEPs to look at what is happening at her trial. (Applause) (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, allow me to abuse only a second of your generosity.  We have held a debate to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of the euro — a successful project — but I would like to draw attention because the six people who have intervened to talk about the success of this project, the benefits of it, have been men.  I hope it won't be another twenty years for women to properly integrate.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, Mr Pospíšil can’t be here today, but he’s asking for referral back to committee.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I call, on the basis of the Regulation, for the report to be returned to the Commission for the start of interinstitutional negotiations. Thank you for your cooperation and for your vote.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the explanations of vote.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report on autonomous driving. Last week, I had the pleasure of visiting Mill Brook in Bedfordshire, in my constituency. They have invested in 5G mobile test infrastructure to supercharge the development of connected and autonomous vehicles. The vision for the technological future is one where we all sit back and relax in cars that drive us safely and efficiently to our destinations. No collisions, no traffic jams. To become a reality, of course, there will need to be car-to-car and car-to-everything-around-them communications and crucially, all cars really need to be speaking the same language. There won’t be any translation booths or headphones. So, if industry-wide standards cannot be agreed by industry then the EU must step in. I therefore particularly welcome the call on the Commission to propose a regulatory framework to promote V2X connectivity for highly and fully automated vehicles.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! I must refrain from making the observation that for too long the European Union has been operating as a driverless vehicle, and simply to say that this is, after all, another area in which we can thank American development and industry for a hopefully breakthrough that will also make life easier for us Europeans. Of course, it requires regulation, and of course the European Parliament immediately throws itself into such regulation - even if we do not know what the cars will look like, even if we know neither software nor hardware or anything. It is good to be at the forefront, which is why, of course, I have also voted in favour of this report, because I cannot imagine anything more beautiful than being able to sit and read the newspaper while being driven to work by an automatic car. But let us remember safety. This is not insignificant, and we have already seen some terrible incidents of American experiments that must never, ever happen in Europe. So fine, but let's lift our foot a little off the brake.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will recall the debate here in the European Parliament on autonomous weapons. Today we are talking about more systems that are out of the law and are going out of their way quite effectively. I must say that, looking at this report and looking at the timetable that is emerging on this occasion, I am concerned that we again have a lack of time. Fortunately, there were no major divisions in this report. The report has been well received and it is hoped that this year 2020 will be a time when the next parliament will be able to come up with legislation that protects us from the negative elements associated, as if it were not, with the development of technology.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report and the broad approach that Commissioner Jourová set out last night. The three pillars of work needing to happen around the legal framework are the financial support for developing technologies and the socio-economic implications of driverless. The arguments around liability are now familiar and the ability to adapt technologies to local driving cultures are entirely feasible. The clear desire on the part of technology firms like Google, Uber and Amazon to dispense with those inconvenient and unpredictable human beings has social implications that are both wide and deep. However, there is a fourth pillar, and that is public acceptance of autonomous vehicles. The traveling public is perfectly willing to accept the notion of autonomous vehicles with a human safety override on passenger aircraft as a matter of routine, but the car is a symbol of personal freedom and status, and it is powerful and it is cherished. So politicians are sooner or later going to have to answer the question: in the future will I still be able to drive my own car wherever I want to drive it?

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In recent times, we have seen a very dynamic development of digital civilization. There is no turning back from this process, so, given this fact, Europe should become a leader in the implementation of new techniques and technologies. However, in order for this to happen, of course, certain investments are also needed, especially in road infrastructure, including in the electronic connections of European roads, and in the involvement in appropriate regulation – for example, on the liability of autonomous vehicles in situations such as road collisions. Of course, it is very important to take care of artificial intelligence. Appropriate legislation in this area is fundamentally important, if only to eliminate public concerns about this type of development of our civilization.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report. It’s very important that we address and look at the issues surrounding the development and the advantages that are there in terms of autonomous vehicles or driverless vehicles. They’re going to be entering into the market post-2020 in a rapid fashion and then expand to utility vehicles and trucks, if we are to believe the projections.  There are many issues that we need to address if we’re to bring consumers and to get consumer confidence in this area. Safety and privacy of data is one of them and, of course, safety of individuals. The technical standards of vehicles and infrastructure need to be addressed. We need responsibilities of the operators to come into play. Who is liable and what are the ethical questions around it? If we’re going to move forward in this area, there are lots of questions that need to be addressed, and that can only be done in this House and other national parliaments in ensuring that we do have societal acceptance of autonomous vehicles.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported my colleague's report, I believe that it really affects all the essential areas, after all, to name this subject narrowly would be very wrong, it has an overlap with industry, of course in the digital economy, in the environment, of course on innovation and on reducing emissions. I believe that we need rules in this sector. There is no doubt that we must also motivate European businesses, SMEs, to support this sector so that we are at the forefront of innovation. This is not yet the case, they are indeed rather colleagues across the Atlantic and it is important that these rules give direction to the correct and sustainable operation of these autonomous cars or these cars. We deal with the issue of legal insurance, liability for damages and, of course, correctly adjusted connectivity. I am particularly in particular in order not to increase the number of cars in our regions, and it is important that this method of driving is also implemented in public and rail public transport.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the next time you’re in a town or in a city, look around and count how many people are driving for a living: bus drivers, cab drivers, white van drivers, Uber drivers. Put them altogether and you’ve got probably the single biggest collective employer of men. Now, as autonomous vehicles become a reality, an awful lot of jobs are going to be lost in that sector, and of course that has led to some concerns in this House, which we have heard. But it doesn’t follow that all these people are going to be milling around unemployed. Where, after all, if we look around today are all the unemployed ex-video rental employees or secretaries or archivists or travel agents? Technology is constantly changing the way we work, and yet more people in most of our countries are in employment than at any time in our history. That’s the wonder of artificial intelligence and of modern technological change: that living standards keep rising, that we keep creating more new jobs as things get better and better. Look around; look around at how lucky we are to be alive right now.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo, mar is dóigh liom gur tábhachtach an t-ábhar é.  Go háirithe, ós rud é go bhfuil a lán dul chun cinn le déanamh againn agus a lán oibre le déanamh againn chun teacht suas le tíortha cosúil leis an tSín, an tSeapáin agus na Stáit Aontaithe, atá i bhfad chun tosaigh maidir le taighde agus rialúchán ar an ábhar seo. At the same time, I just want to say that these autonomous technologies in the area of transport and logistics present a huge potential for future development, particularly in my own country, Ireland, where we depend highly on our road transport network for our country’s economy and social life. The use of drones for the transport of goods and automated light rail systems for public transport are already a possibility, and entry into the European market of passenger cars with automated driving functions is imminent. Therefore, we need to get ready, and we also need to do a lot more research. I look forward to that being done, especially in the next Horizon programme. Therefore it is a technology that is going to move us forward and we better move quickly. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! At the last general election in 2014, road transport - the transport of goods across borders - was one of the major themes. I remember how in Denmark, the concept of cabotage, which is not otherwise a distinctly Danish word, suddenly became a word everyone knew and had on their lips because it highlighted one of the great problems of EU cooperation: that you can work in one country while employed in another and therefore have to comply with the pay and working conditions that applies in the country where you are employed, and not where you do the work. This creates a completely exorbitant and unfair environment for competition. That is why I had looked forward with some anticipation and hope that we would be debating cabotage in this House. But I, like the majority of other interested parties who sit and follow outside the thick walls, must be grappling with amazement and disappointment. Because nothing happened. Or rather, what has happened has gone in the wrong direction, just underlining that the whole EU project is on a mad course, away from the citizens, away from reality and away from the problems, one hopes.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On 28 October last year, the Chairman of the Committee on Transport announced that the Council would not be ready in due course to negotiate this report. However, this report was adopted because it was referred to Parliament. I would point out, however, that the adoption of amendments 28 and 34 unfortunately spoils this report. Fortunately, all the other amendments have been rejected – precisely the perishable ones – so we have a good starting point for such a debate, which should end with a Council decision. At the moment, however, pressure must be exerted as much pressure as possible to actually adopt solutions in the short term, because this is crucial for important activity, an important part of Europe's economy.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have been creating a single market for a united Europe for decades. Unfortunately, despite so many years, the movement of services, goods or people is still over-regulated in the European Union. These rules, on the other hand, restrict free competition, restrict economic development, restrict citizens' freedom, and restrict the integration of the European Union. I am therefore in favour of liberalising the right to use driverless vehicles. These are solutions that will serve not only the development of transport in Europe, but also economic development. It also gives jobs and prosperity to our citizens.  By the way, I would like to stress that I am also against the restrictions that result from the mobility package that we have been debating recently in Brussels and Strasbourg.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! We have seen the European Parliament repeatedly adopt one fine resolution on gender equality after another, but we have to note that it is somewhat lagging behind. I come from Denmark, where we have a President of the Folketing, Mrs. Pia Kjærsgaard, who is a woman. We have had a Prime Minister who was a woman, we have appointed a Commissioner who is a woman, we even have her Majesty the Queen, as the head of the country, who is of course a woman. But here in the European Parliament, the President of parliament, the President of the Council, the President of the Commission, even the President of the ECB, all men. One might therefore think that this report would be the main focus. But no. Then you think mistakes. On the contrary, we care about gender-neutral language and the problem of visual stereotypes and other nonsense - instead of addressing the root of the nettle. It's embarrassing.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament, paragraph 15, recalls the revised guidelines on gender-neutral language in the European Parliament published last July, which contain strange advice on the use of gender equality and gender equality. A peculiar strange thing is expressed here satisfaction with a similar publication published in 2008 under the same title. It should be recalled that it disappeared very quickly from circulation, as the proposals contained therein were considered absurd in many countries. I also disagree with the provisions of recital U that LGBTIQ people are "relatively poorly exposed and their voice is weak." I think the opposite is true, which is why I voted against this report.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against the report on gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament not because I am against equality, but because of the incorrect, illegal concept of equality. The report even emphasises in point AD that gender mainstreaming requires specific skills and knowledge. Therefore, it is worth remembering that a woman by reason of her construction and physiology and psyche is different from a man. It even has a differently built brain and has organs to conceive and bring a baby that needs care at birth. The huge role of the mother's presence for the emotional development of the child with the attachment needed for life has been proven. Equating a woman with a man, in my opinion, also undermines human rights, the functioning of democracy and respect for the rule of law. Women have the right to be responsible mothers, to give birth to children and to raise them, which is their vocation.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this report because it contains content with which I absolutely cannot agree. One thing worth highlighting is that we should take every action to combat sexual harassment, and I think we all agree. We are against sexual harassment, against violence. It is a pity that the whole left-wing ideology of gender transition, with the promotion of LGBTIQ, is thrown into this report, and it is also proposed to introduce gender neutral language. Well, we have come to the wall, I am convinced, since left-wing communities want to interfere even at the language level. This is a direction that is absolutely unacceptable. Women are smart, women need regulations that allow them to combine the role of mother and employee.  (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, the meaning of the concept of gender equality has shifted significantly since we started using it here in the European Parliament. We originally said that it was wrong for men and women to have different salaries, pensions if they work in the same positions. This is an injustice that needs to be addressed here, but at the same time I would like to stress that women's access to work must be greatly valued. Women often have a different approach in thinking, they can be systematic, they can be empathetic, bring peace of mind to the working environment. But in both business and politics, those who are often more aggressive are promoted by men who are more heard. Perhaps that is why we have more men than women who are not afraid to point out more what they want to promote. I am certainly in favour of women having the same space and presence here in Parliament, but the debate has moved today to monitor whether enough women are represented in the institutions of the European Parliament. However, we cannot impose this here. So women are supposed to work here, but we can't tell you how many there are. So we're showing them due respect. I'd like us to work out how to help women and mothers in how to raise children.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report and support individual messages throughout, as well as the wider message conveyed that discrimination of any kind is not acceptable in the European Parliament. If gender equality does not exist within our own institution, how can we possibly ensure gender equality in the broader society? I certainly welcome achievements made over the past two years as outlined in this report, and I believe now – before the European elections – is the perfect time to look at where we can improve into the next mandate. One of the most notable actions taken by Parliament recently was to introduce a training programme specifically for MEPs on these issues. I personally completed the training and I found it very worthwhile. I think this training is extremely important and I would urge all colleagues to attend. It certainly brought out for me the need to ensure that gender equality is always at the forefront in all we do in the European Parliament.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Budget of the European Union is undoubtedly important for the public sector. I do not want this impact of the EU budget to be particularly widening. However, I will say right away that it is very important that the budget responds swiftly to the changing needs and situation of the European Union itself. Unfortunately, this is not the case. Already in 2007, a report which described the possible effects of reforming EU countries and the EU economy indicated that the effect of the budget was unfortunately critical for this process. Today we have even worse. I would point out that the study itself has produced very important adjectives describing the reform of public administration as disorderly, without coherence, without coherence and without proper impact on what is most important.  I would like to draw attention to this, because at the same time the need to coordinate many projects, which is lacking, as well as to address cohesion policies more precisely within the European Union, is constantly emphasised.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, is é Brian Hayes, Fine Gael, údar na tuarascála seo agus iarrann sé ar an gCoimisiún Eorpach ról níos lárnaí a imirt i riaracháin phoiblí na mBallstát. Tá sé seo in ainneoin nach bhfuil aon inniúlachtaí dlíthiúla ag AE i dtéarmaí riaracháin phoiblí náisiúnta. Léiríonn an staidéar go soiléir conas a úsáideann an Coimisiún buiséad AE chun a thionchar a leathnú. Níl sé de chumhacht ag an gCoimisiún na Ballstáit a athchóiriú i dtaobh a gcuid riarachán poiblí náisiúnta. Mar sin, úsáideann an Coimisiún buiséad AE chun dreasachtaí airgeadais a thabhairt do thíortha a chuireann athchóirithe i bhfeidhm agus tá sé beartaithe acu €25 bhilliún a úsáid as seo sa chéad bhuiséad fadtéarmach eile.  In Éirinn, tá a fhios againn go bhfuil an baol ann go nglactar le leasuithe ón gCoimisiún. Deir an tuarascáil gur cheart dúinn beartais a sheachaint a laghdaíonn pá agus polasaithe go sóisialta, ach is iad seo polasaithe cruinn atá ag Fine Gael agus Fianna Fáil agus ag an gCoimisiún Eorpach. Má thugaimid níos mó cumhachta don Choimisiún, feicfimid níos mó de na polasaithe seo agus sin í an chúis go bhfuil Fine Gael ag tacú leis seo.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, although I am aware that our role is, above all, in creating certain synergies, an incentive for the Member States, because they are the ones that are primarily responsible for the quality of their public administration. But we have clearly defined interests here, which we must protect in the Field of the Union, and it is above all in the interest that a European should be able to handle a substantial part or preferably all of his contact with the public administration through digital technologies, through 'eGovernment', or also, of course, to have access to information, to all the information he needs and which he seeks through, therefore, these digital technologies and 'eGovernment' as such.  We use a tool called cohesion policy, which also deals with, for example, increasing the efficiency of public administration, and the involvement of the European budget is simply quite obvious there. So is increasing the absorption capacities of public administration. These are our interests that we pursue, and I think that the Member States must add to ensure the same level of access to public administration rights for all Europeans.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I agree with the report's statement that freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief is a universal human right. It is also good that, in paragraph 2, the European Parliament is deeply concerned that there has been a sharp increase in violations of freedom of religion or belief worldwide and persecution of believers in recent years. An example is Asia Bibi, where, in paragraph 13, our Parliament calls on the Pakistani authorities to ensure its security. It should be up to the EU Special Envoy to promote freedom of religion or belief outside the EU to ensure fair treatment of Christians in particular. The word Christians do not appear directly at any point in the report, and this is the most persecuted group in the world. I therefore abstained from voting on this report.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab This report is based on the premise, I quote, that 'the principle of separation of church and state is the fundamental constitutional principle throughout the world and in Europe'. It's symplicism. This is a populist thesis. That's just not true. In Poland, for example, the principle is the mutual autonomy of the State and the Church, the mutual independence of the clergy and state authorities and, finally, the principle of the cooperation of the State and the Church for the common good and for the benefit of the people. The authors of this report should take into account that this slogan of this separation was very often a pretext for human rights violations, for persecution not only in communist countries, but in post-revolution France or Mexico. These are things that must not be forgotten. In law, linguistic precision is of great importance, so let us react to the smuggling of an ideology that really seeks to exclude Christianity from European life.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As has been said, the report begins with a statement of untruth, that is, the principle of separation of church and state is the main constitutional principle throughout the world. Have you not heard that, for example, the Queen of Great Britain is the head of the Anglican Church, that there are Protestant churches more or less closely associated with the states, have you not heard of the Vatican, of Saudi Arabia? These are blatant nonsense simply. Besides, this report is really largely not about. As we begin to list persecuted groups, we immediately add women, girls, people because of their sexual orientation and so on. If we write a report on the persecution of women, do we add Christians there? Well, no, why are we doing the other way around in this way, just to show that for the European Union, the millennial Christian Church is nothing more than a feminist organization or a philatelic union or whatever. I do not know if the PSL is proud of Mr Grzyb and boasts in Poland of what his Members write here?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, I think it is striking that even 70 years since the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was approved, it is not enough to make these rights a matter of course for all. Many citizens are denied freedom of thought, expression of conscience and religion. This applies not only to Christians, but also to minorities living in the Middle East, for example. I support the adoption of the European Union's guidelines, which can practically help to promote religious freedom here. Today, in many parts of the world, people are killed just because they want to retain the right to freely choose what they believe, even if they simply want to believe in God – simply being an atheist. I welcome the European Parliament's call on the Pakistani authorities to ensure the safety of Christian Asia Bibi. To this day, she has failed to leave her country and must live in a safe place and hide there, in Pakistan. However, there are fewer known other cases of people awaiting sentencing in Pakistan and other prisons around the world under the laws of goddessing. I also appreciate that the report mentions the creation of posts of special envoys for religious freedom in individual Member States. This is further proof that the subject of freedom of religion is becoming an important element of foreign policy.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report and the commitment to zero VAT on sanitary products. The average woman uses 10 000 tampons in a lifetime, and spends GBP 18 000 on periods. That’s a lot of money for something that’s completely natural and unstoppable and happens every month. Yet, we are living in a society blighted by period poverty and period stigma. Plan International UK found that one in ten young women were unable to afford tampons and pads, leading to some girls missing out on school. Then there’s period stigma, partly, I would argue, because this monthly event is still shrouded in secrecy. It’s time to go a step further, and I call on European governments to fund free sanitary protection in all public buildings. Just as it is for loo roll in toilets, so let it be for pads and tampons, too.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Our ECR Group voted against this report because we believe that it falsely portrays the current tax policies of the Member States as discriminatory. The first point of the report refers to combating the male breadwinner model. Further, in point six, the rapporteurs call for the elimination of all tax expenditure based on common income. I also share the minority opinion expressed on behalf of the largest PPE Group, criticising the report. In this opinion, European families and their right to choose the tax system are defended. In view of all these reservations, we voted against this report.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against the report. on gender equality in the context of tax policy, although I support the principle of equal pay for equal work of equal value and am in favour of equal treatment between women and men, together with the fight against all forms of discrimination and poverty, the right to choose the tax system for European families cannot be denied. The tax policy that seeks individual taxation and the other proposals put forward in the report are against the family, violate the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, and violate human rights, especially women's rights to self-realization and justice. For most women, family, giving birth, raising children is a first-class self-fulfillment, which is not replaced by top management positions or high salaries. Discrimination against women by treating them as a labour force is, in addition, simply unthetical and contrary to the natural role of women.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is another report marked by a gender obsession, which is taking this detached Parliament away from reality. It is full of sentences such as 'it is noted that the reduction in capital gains and property taxes primarily benefits men, because it is rather men who control such resources'. So what? Yesterday there was a discussion in which it was said that there are far more women than men in the Equality Committee and it was said 'it is difficult because men apparently do not want to be there'. Well, apparently women don't want to buy property. So what? What do you want to force women to do? I don't understand what the result is. In theory, for example, a tax there applies equally to everyone, but affects each gender in different ways. Well, that's what equality is all about. Equality is the same rights, but not necessarily the same effects. If the effects differ, apparently different sexes have different predispositions or preferences. If the facts don't agree with your theory that both sexes are the same, then you're offended by the facts and you're trying to force change them. I voted against.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Despite my commitment to protecting women's rights, I could not support the report on gender equality in the context of the European Union's tax policy, because it is saturated with extreme left-wing ideology to the detriment, unfortunately, of objectivity. It is false to say that a remedy for existing inequalities and discrimination may be a mandatory harmonised transformation of member states' tax systems. I accuse the authors of this report of a lack of balance and objectivity. Instead of talking about equality between women and men, you have set out a vision of European women being discriminated against en masse and on a large scale, or even by male breadwines. Once again, such reports do harm to women, rather than supporting them in their development and giving them a chance to equalise inequalities.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the presentation of the Romanian Presidency's programme of activities (2018/2918(SDR)). I would like to take this opportunity to greet the Prime Minister of the Republic of Romania, our colleague for many years, Viorica Dăncilă, who has the floor.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President of the European Parliament, President of the European Commission, honourable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, I am honoured to be here today before you as Prime Minister of Romania. I have taken over the European mandate from Austria and I would like to reiterate on this occasion my thanks to the Austrian Presidency. At the same time, I would also like to thank our partners in the trio, Finland and Croatia, with whom we have had very good coordination in preparing a balanced joint work programme for the next eighteen months. In the following, I will present to you the priorities of the Romanian Presidency of the Council of the European Union and the vision for the future of the Union. Ladies and gentlemen, Europe has always known how to overcome obstacles, to be reborn after the less glorious episodes of history. The European project itself, in its present-day form, has been shaped by the many crises it has been through. Today we are once again at a complex moment in the European construction process but, as you know, any situation of this kind can be turned into an opportunity, into a new beginning. For this reason I tell you that, in my view, Romania's exercise of the rotating presidency over the next six months is not just a formal duty. There are over five hundred million European citizens waiting for an answer about the future of the house they live in, which is called Europe. I therefore believe that it is important to show the citizens of the Union that the European institutions work for them and, above all, that they produce results that improve their lives and prospects for the future. I am aware that the first stage of the rotating presidency will be intensive and reduced in time in terms of decision-making. That is why I am counting very heavily on your support, in order to complete as many legislative dossiers as possible on the European agenda and to respond to challenges at European level. The vision of the Romanian Presidency on the European project is structured around the idea of cohesion, as a common European value declined in all its dimensions: political cohesion, illustrated by the need for unity between Member States; economic and territorial cohesion, with a view to reducing development gaps between Member States and regions; social cohesion, important in terms of preserving the four freedoms of the European Union's internal market. This understanding of the concept of cohesion is transposed in a cross-cutting manner into our thematic priorities, which are part of four main pillars of action: Europe of Convergence, Europe of Safety, Europe - global actor, Europe of common values. The Convergence Europe is the first pillar of the Romanian Presidency's action at the Council of the European Union and aims to ensure economic growth, social development, bridge-building, competitiveness, connectivity and sustainability. The single market is, of course, the union's greatest achievement, the core of European construction. As a result, one of the objectives of the Romanian Presidency is to advance the legislative agenda in the field of the internal market, with the aim of finalising the framework necessary for its proper functioning. We need to strengthen the scientific and technological base of European industry, through which we can boost our international competitiveness and, at the same time, generate growth and jobs. We will continue to promote digitalisation, including in the field of European industry. The digital offensive has already been promoted by the previous Estonian and Austrian Presidencies of the Council of the European Union, and we will also aim to continue to work at the same sustained pace. We will focus on developing the functional links between east and west, between north and south, to facilitate connections of all kinds, to operationalise the four freedoms of movement and to increase the competitiveness of the European economy and the standard of living in less developed regions. I was telling you about the need for a long-term industrial policy, and just as important is the regulation of the Energy Union. These two themes will occupy an important place on the agenda of our presidency. The second pillar of the Romanian Presidency will be the Europe of safety. We are facing security challenges that threaten the safety of the citizen. The European Union faces a wide range of risks and threats that can undermine the values and prosperity of our open societies. In a world of accelerated digitalisation, we need to move forward in protecting citizens in cyberspace. It is necessary to strengthen the Union's resilience to cyber-attacks. Cybersecurity will therefore be a necessary condition for any project relating to the information technology. Also in relation to the security of the Union, we will treat with all seriousness the negotiation and completion of initiatives on the coherent management of migratory flows, the strengthening of the Union's external borders, emergency interventions, the fight against terrorism, the protection of citizens' safety in the virtual space, the operationalisation and even the extension of the mandate of the European Public Prosecutor's Office to terrorist offences, as well as the strengthening of judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters. We want to contribute to the formulation of viable solutions in these migration-related areas and to promote cooperation between countries of origin and transit, including in combating trafficking in human beings. The third pillar we have set for the Presidency of Romania is Europe - a global actor. In our view, the main direction of action in this area must start from the joint commitments made through the European Union's overall foreign and security policy strategy. In terms of security policy, we will promote the strengthening of the European Union's defence and security capabilities, in close complementarity with similar processes within NATO. At the same time, we need to focus our attention on our immediate neighbourhood, which means advancing the Union's enlargement policy. The anniversary of the 10th anniversary of the launch of the Eastern Partnership this year will be an important moment in this regard. We will also support the implementation of the Union's international commitments. Key milestones are the promotion of commercial interests, the modernisation of the multilateral trading system and the extension of economic partnership and free trade agreements. The fourth pillar on which the Romanian Presidency will be held will be the Europe of common values. In other words, in order to foster European political cohesion, we aim to promote intensively the principles and values that unite us. At the same time, we must firmly combat a number of problems still facing societies within the Union, such as racism, intolerance, xenophobia, populism, anti-Semitism or hate speech. We want a more democratic Union, so we will promote the equal treatment to which all Member States and all European citizens aspire. This is essential for citizens' confidence in the European project. I say this to you from the perspective of the Romanian citizens, whom I represent as Prime Minister and who, despite their very strong attachment to the Union, feel unequal treatment of Romania, especially when our country is criticised for issues that are natural in other Member States or when Romania is subject to certain conditionalities that do not exist in other Union states. Romanians feel inequity when they see that their country is being kept outside the Schengen area, and I want to thank President Jean-Claude Juncker and President Antonio Tajani on this occasion for the full support they give us for joining the Schengen area. I have given you these examples from my country in order to understand that certain decisions that are taken at European level with regard to some Member States ultimately fall to the level of the citizens of those countries and determine, in one way or another, the confidence they have with the Union. So, all the time, when we take decisions, we have to think about the citizens of the Member States concerned by our decisions and we have to eliminate any form of differential treatment so as to strengthen the common values of the Union. Education and culture are the key to Europe's future, both from the individual perspective of the European citizen and from the perspective of strengthening the European project. Solutions are also needed to help young people be involved in shaping a strong Europe based on common European values. Ladies and gentlemen, we are all following the decisions in the British Parliament and it is clear that Brexit will be in the spotlight during the Romanian Presidency at the Council of the European Union. We will turn this tab back on the history of the Union, but we must also learn from this situation. In May, our democracy, the largest transnational democracy, will elect a new European Parliament. I propose that we harness the future electoral context, as it is an opportunity for us who believe in Europe to promote a Union more strongly oriented towards its founding principles, in resonance with our European spirit. I believe in a strong Europe, through unity, in a better Europe, by fulfilling commitments to its citizens and globally and, why not, I believe in a more European Europe, by promoting genuine European values and stimulating citizens' sense of belonging to the European space. A strong and unified Europe in all its dimensions – political, economic, social – is the best solution for the future of the European project.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, speaking on behalf of President Juncker, I am delighted to be here for the start of this historic first—ever Romanian Presidency. Romania, just like my own country, Estonia, and many others in Europe, celebrated its 100th anniversary last year. It was a time for us all to remember the past, but also to look at how far we have come in that time, and Romania has come a long way. It is now in its rightful place at the heart of Europe, and there is no better symbol of that progress than this Presidency because, over the next six months, Romania will lead the Council of Ministers through a momentous time for our Union.  I was in Bucharest last week, along with all my colleagues from the Commission, to see first-hand the good level of preparations, as well as the enthusiasm for the task ahead. But with a Presidency always comes responsibility, even more so during periods of change and campaigns. As President Juncker has said many times, the Commission is at your disposal and is ready to support you every step of the way. We will work hand in hand with all of the institutions and parties involved to make sure that the next six months are productive, successful and a further factor of unity and solidarity.  But, just as you can count on us, we also count on you. We count on your leadership and stability, and we count on your ability to build bridges and build consensus both in Europe and at home. I say that because any successful Presidency depends, first and foremost, on national unity and political consensus. A united front at home will help a united Europe move forward. Romania knows the power of unity better than most. When preparing to enter the Union, the whole country worked in unison to make sure that it fulfilled all of its accession criteria. This was not a box-ticking exercise. It was the result of a country pulling together, uniting behind the goal of consolidating its young democracy in a union of solidarity and common values. These values – freedom, democracy and the rule of law – are what the country fought for, and these are the values that can never be compromised or weakened anywhere in Europe. We must all show that in the next six months and beyond. I started by saying that with the Presidency comes the responsibility to deliver for all Europeans. That will be Romania’s task in the next six months. It will be harder than usual: there are 242 proposals presented by the Commission that still need to be agreed by the co-legislators, and there will only be a short period of time to get as many as possible of them over the line before this House rises on 18 April for the start of the election campaign. Many of these 242 proposals go right to the heart of what matters, from Brexit preparedness to migration and asylum rules. In my area, the digital single market, seven of the 30 proposals we have made still need to be agreed. These cover issues that make a real difference in the lives of Europeans. It is about making it easier to buy and sell online across borders, about ensuring that we have rights to ePrivacy and can protect ourselves from cyber-attacks, and about having corporate rules fit for the 21st century.  The stakes are high in the digital world and across the world. This is particularly true when it comes to making real progress on the next long—term budget for the European Union. This is not about numbers or decimal points. It is about deciding what kind of Union we want tomorrow. It is our future in figures. The debate on the budget is about showing Europeans that our Union is ready to take its destiny into its own hands.  When leaders meet in Sibiu on 9 May, we should show Europeans a perspective for the future of a stronger, more united and more sovereign Union. There would be no better message to Europeans going to the polls just a few weeks later. I think, in particular, of those who will be voting for the first time. Whether they be in the East or the West, the North or the South, these young people have a lot in common. They are looking for hope, for a brighter more certain future for themselves, and they are looking for a union that breathes with both of its lungs – East and West – and unites people from different parts of Europe. We must reach out to them and show them that their Union will deliver for them.  That is the task ahead of this Romanian Presidency and we are all behind you to make it happen.  (Applause)

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, welcome, Prime Minister, to the European Parliament. The Presidents of the European institutions have given you their full support for the success of the Presidency of Romania. It is what we want here in the European Parliament, too. We have heavy dossiers on the negotiating table with the Council: migration, transport mobility, over forty reports concerning the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework and others. The solutions in these negotiations will foreshadow the future of the European Union in the coming years. As you well know, however, Prime Minister, you have many new ministers who do not have the experience of negotiating with the European institutions. That is why I ask these ministers to rely on the recommendations of the experts from the Romanian Representation, who are very familiar with the dossiers on the European agenda. You have rightly expressed concern that the Eastern Member States are not left on the periphery of the European Union, but as long as, for example, Romania is neither a member of the Schengen area nor a member of the euro area, our country is not fully integrated into the European Union. The Presidents of the European institutions have shown that Romania is ready and will support its accession to the Schengen area, but this is not enough. As Prime Minister, you have an obligation to all Romanians and to business in Romania to meet as soon as possible with the prime ministers of the Netherlands and France, with the chancellors of Germany and Austria and to convince them that Romania is worth it, it is ready to join the Schengen area. In the Netherlands you should also go to the Dutch Parliament, but without the presidents of the two houses of the Romanian Parliament, which are deprived of any credibility, for well-known reasons. With regard to the euro area, as Chair of the National Commission for the Preparation of Accession to the Euro Area, you have decided that you will make public the action plan for this purpose. The year 2018 has passed and we do not yet have such an action plan. Please fulfil your promise as soon as possible. I wish you success in the exercise of the Romanian Presidency of the Council.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Viorica to the European Parliament. Congratulations on the start of this first Romanian Presidency. We honor a lot your personal commitment to the European Union. As a former colleague, we experienced you as a very committed European and we see a basis for a very, very good collaboration with this Presidency, given the tasks you mentioned ahead of us and given the serious situation in many, many policy areas.  I listened to your speech with interest and yes, you are right, social cohesion, regional cohesion, is a decisive, cross-cutting issue, and your idea of organising a new mode of European convergence is very much at the core of what we have to talk about. The last hours of this day demonstrate how serious the situation is in London and how much work has to be done, whatever the decision is going to be tonight. The international financial markets, the tax questions – all of that we have to tackle, we have to re-fix, and the migration question is one of the most important ones. Here, let me praise you, let me honor you, because you decided in the Christmas period to join the camp of those who would like to help in the Mediterranean, to help save lives and not to turn a blind eye on what is going to happen or join the club of those who only celebrate their ignorance.  However, let me also point out that we have problems that we need to talk about. Yes, there are things that worry us. Much of romania's justice system needs to be reformed, and corruption must be vigorously combated. If there is a situation in modern Europe where in a country the secret services have influence over the judiciary and the public prosecutor's office, we cannot accept that. I am addressing this here, but I should also address it much more to your President, under whose responsibility the secret services are responsible here on this issue. In this respect, I can agree with the Commission and say that unity is fine, but then let us also call things by their names and place them clearly where they need to be located. If there have been injustices in your country – I am talking about the things that are being collated behind your back and not saying them here, that is not my way of doing – there have been injustices against people who have suffered innocently under the justice system, that must be clarified. But the answer to this cannot be a general amnesty, because it lumps right and wrong. We strongly advise you against this, that is not a basis. But create the rule of law where you think it is necessary. I know that you want that, and I want to encourage you: do this, because you will honour your presidency, you as a person and for your country! And Europe will be with you if you do that. The rule of law is an achievement of European societies that protects people, guarantees freedoms over the state and ends arbitrary rule. This applies to everyone. We Social Democrats know this because we set up for it more than 150 years ago, and we defend it against anyone and anywhere else. But the rule of law is not a cudfore for political competitors to take a back-together stance on the chances of forming political wills. We must respect this everywhere and on all political sides. Prime Minister, you are a courageous woman, I know that, and your willingness to reform can be an excellent prerequisite for the next six months, for fruitful cooperation. I would like to say something to you – to those who always know exactly what it is, especially to competitors from the European People's Party: if there is a country these days where universities are once again closed – for the first time since fascism – if there is a country in which journalists' rights are undermined and freedom of expression is no longer possible, then come to this door. And just because you do not have the confidence to say in the face to Mr Orban what you should say to him: do not brush off your shoes at the beginning of the Presidency! That is the wrong way of dealing with the political debate in Europe. I also said this to Mr Juncker, he knows it personally. He has already put himself in a better spotlight, only for the sake of honesty here also mentioned.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, first of all, welcome to the Romanian Presidency. Six months is a short period of debate and negotiation. It will therefore be a matter of getting our noses in the same direction, together with the two future presidents. European enlargement is a priority for the Romanian Presidency. For the first time in many years, the Union is once again expressing its ambition to expand. If they implement the necessary reforms, six Western Balkan countries will be allowed to join by 2025. But the best thing is for the EU to put its house in order first. I am referring not least to Brexit and the growing dissatisfaction among European citizens with the migration policy of open borders. For us, tackling illegal migration is indeed a priority. I am calling for a switch to the Australian model to discourage illegal entry. I hope that you will agree and that it will be reflected in negotiations on the EU asylum acquis.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Prime Minister Dăncilă that her country is taking over the presidency at a very critical time. We are just before the European elections and I have made a little list: the mobility and transport package; the completion of the banking union; the reform of the broken Dublin system; the Multiannual Financial Framework, where we need an agreement, and, last but not least, two Article 7 procedures – one against the Polish Government and one announced by this Parliament against Orbán. There is a lot on your plate. One thing I hope for you and your government is that during your presidency, there will not be a third case of Article 7 – a case against the Romanian Government – because my impression is that by continuing to ignore the opinions of the Venice Commission, you are not far from that at the moment, and there are a few legislative files that are under discussion in the Romanian Parliament. I was in Bucharest together with a number of colleagues here. I met Mr Dragnea, who is the leader of your party and the Speaker of the House, and he defended these legislative files and the attitude of your majority by saying, ‘well, the rule of law is a question of subsidiarity’. I have to tell you, there are many things in the European Union that are a question of subsidiarity, but that is certainly not true for the rule of law. That is not subsidiarity in the European Union. I said exactly the same, that same day, to Mr Tăriceanu and he promised me that your government and both parties forming your majority will change the proposals and will be fully compliant with the Venice Commission. Moreover, he agreed with me that the Venice Commission would have a second opinion once the change is made to these proposals. These proposals – on the restoring of the independence of the judiciary, on the repairing of the Criminal Code, on the repairing of the Criminal Procedural Code and on the changing of NGO law – will be sent back to the Venice Commission.  I have to tell you, very honestly, that since we met each other, with Mr Bullmann and others in Bucharest, not one of these promises has been kept. On the contrary, your government continues to follow the path of bad practices of other governments like Orbán and Kaczyński. I ask you, is the following true? I read in the press that you have a plan to approve a law to grant amnesty on corruption, so that means putting the big fish out of reach of the courts.  So let me tell you one simple thing in this debate: if this were to be confirmed, my Group in any case, and the whole liberal family, will not go into elections with such partners. We want to side with all new clean and democratic forces who want to stop corruption, clean up the country and are also anti abuse of power by the old secret service. That is not criticism of your country or of Romanian citizens. It is criticism of a number of practices of your political majority for the moment, and I think I can be critical of these practices as I am an honorary citizen of the Romanian Republic. I was bestowed that honour in 2001 after I defended in the European Council – and nobody asked me to do so – the interests of Romania in the Treaty of Nice. The other Member States had the beautiful idea of lowering the voting rights of Romania because it is only an Eastern European country, which which was pure discrimination towards them. Finally, we succeeded in obtaining the right thing for the Romanian Republic, the same voting rights as the other Member States. I’m also in favour, Mr President, of Romania’s entry into the euro and into Schengen. Don’t see that as criticism. Pick up this fight. Be the real Prime Minister of your country. Clean up the mess of the past and do that without compromising with the corrupt forces of the present.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, welcome to the Prime Minister and the whole Presidency. A Presidency is always a time for a country to shine, to show off its skills in diplomacy, its skill in finding compromises, achieving progress, impressing everyone with the opportunities and skills that you have as a government and as a country. The Presidency is a vital job in our institutional relations and for moving Europe forward.  However, a Presidency is also always a time when a country is put into the limelight, and what we discover there when looking at the Romanian Government gives us reasons for concern. Romania has a long tradition of fighting for freedom and for civil liberties, and the people of Romania overthrew a dictatorship after enduring it for 42 years. Romania has joined the European Union and has made important progress, especially against the evil of corruption. Those are achievements that the people of Romania can be proud of; we all should be very proud of those achievements. These days, thousands of people in Romania are out in the streets, asking for civil liberties and good governance, but the problem is that they’re not being heard because instead the government has been organising a backlash against those civil liberties and against good governance, and the proposed law changes will result in legalising corruption de facto. The government is even planning to reduce the rights to protest against that law change or others. A Presidency must lead by good example and with credibility. You still have time to become that good example that we need in Europe, but the clock is certainly ticking. The half year of your Presidency will be quite eventful. We have Brexit coming up – or not – and the EU elections, of course. At the same time, the European Union also needs a long—term vision, so it’s very good that you have planned the summit in May.  However, for the summit to be really helpful, it also needs to include some of the most burning issues that we have in Europe, that we need to solve. For example, how are we going to stop climate change? How are we going to manage the transition to a carbon—free economy? How do we make social rights for people a reality rather than just nice words? How will the EU respond to the backlash against the rule of law in several Member States? We wish you a lot of success with all those things on your plate and we hope to be positively surprised.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament. The Romanian Presidency will be called upon to manage the deep economic crisis and its tragic consequences, the widening of inequalities, the continuous increase in unemployment, especially among young people, and the poverty of a large part of the world without hope. The statistics for 2017 have recently been made public. One in seven pensioners is on the poverty line, with an increasing trend. It is all this that leads the people to the great challenge of the Union. The European Union and your Presidency cannot therefore ask for the confidence of the people in the run-up to the European elections, unless the obsession with promoting disastrous neoliberal policies, support for the Stability Pact, deepening economic and budgetary union and the logic of austerity budgets are stopped first. Prime Minister, GUE/NGL calls on you to listen to peoples' concerns, to promote the positions of Parliament's progressive forces on the need to strengthen social policy. The social poverty and the break-up of industrial relations which has become the norm require us to invest directly in a social pillar, which has real content on the basis of the needs of society. Because, unfortunately, today it is just a password, without any binding force. Measures must, at last, be promoted and investments made to boost the real economy, bring growth for the benefit of the people and strengthen social cohesion. These are the objectives to be set in the multiannual financial framework. Even digitisation, which is a priority of your Presidency, must be used to create new quality and decent jobs with full employment rights. It is equally important to show practical solidarity with the Member States for a humanitarian response to the crisis and not to strengthen the logic of a fortress Europe. Finally, instead of giving Turkey a lot of money and putting the upgrading of the customs union on the agenda, pressure must be put on Turkey to stop piracy at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States, such as Greece and Cyprus in the Aegean and the Eastern Mediterranean.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, Prime Minister, the promotion of economic growth in the European Union, the strengthening of security, the values of the Common European Union for years are increasingly the same questions and, most often, without implementation. Dear. Prime Minister, would you agree that today, I repeat, today the most important thing is to get an answer to two, in my opinion, substantive questions. Firstly, why have the interests of the European Union's reunification been replaced by the interests of division and how to change it? Secondly, why did seventeen million Britons vote for Brexit, which determined their self-determination, and what should be done to prevent the Germans, The French and other nations from doing so after you have completed your Presidency? Dear. Prime Minister, we will not solve these issues with the programmes of unification or re-educating Europe. Europe needs to change.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-Chief for the work he has Two things are remarkable to me so far in this debate.  Firstly, a socialist government that has put border protection and illegal migration on the agenda – congratulations on this – and the second is a Mr Bullmann, who, instead of dealing with the problems, falls into an old political pattern and launches a counter-attack. So, this is something that we know, but which certainly belongs in history. You are taking over the Presidency of austria. The Austrian Presidency has completed a considerable programme. I wish you all the best for yours, because there are difficult issues on the agenda, and you have chosen something that is certainly not easy. We have already heard all this about what is at stake.  I appreciate Romania. I value the country and its people, but I have doubts as to whether your government is also capable of shaping an orderly Presidency. These include moderation processes, and I do not know whether you are stable enough to do so. After all, you are already the third head of government in this parliamentary term and you should not get lost in power struggles just then. We'll see. There is legislation in the area of anti-corruption. All this is worthy of clarification and we will judge at the end of the day.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: – Mr President, I – unlike many who have criticised today, and argued, and less reasoned – believe that this presidency will be a successful presidency. I am convinced that the Romanian Presidency will be a successful presidency, because we need it to be successful. The European Union is going through an extremely difficult time. Everything I have said and we are discussing needs to happen here, which is why I guarantee you have the full support, and mine – as much as it matters. Because time does not allow me, I will bring up only two topics, which I consider important. Firstly, three quarters of the Member States of the European Union face an increasingly accelerated process of modern slavery: people who are deprived of their liberty, have no rights, their rights are not known. It is not only Romania that is affected, but three quarters of the Member States of the European Union are experiencing this phenomenon. In Germany alone, there were at one time more than 170,000 citizens who were victims of modern slavery. The second very important topic: I am talking about cohesion. Of course we need financial resources. The direct and indirect costs of corruption at European Union level are estimated at almost EUR 1 trillion. Of course Romania is affected and, according to some forecasts, about EUR 40 billion is lost annually, direct and indirect costs. But in Italy about 200 billion euros are lost annually, in Spain there are 120 billion and so on. So a thousand billion is money that we can recover and use at European level for that cohesion that you are talking about. I believe that this should be an important item on the Presidency's agenda.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected President of the Romanian Government, I am pleased that you are here today and that romania's first presidency is in action; And with that began the presidency of the first tria, this tria in which my country, Croatia, participates, and I hope that we will work well together. I looked at your priorities a little bit, and I heard what you were saying, and certainly that cohesion convergence is very important and adopting a multiannual financial framework will be your difficult task.  I also like that you mentioned inequalities in Eastern and Western Europe, north and south, and that you want to work on it. I hope you'll succeed because that would interest us all. Also, mentioning a safe Europe is very important because we want both Romania and Croatia and Bulgaria to enter Schengen and I hope that you will work on this intensively and that you will help all of us together to enter the Schengen area to finally get a two-speed Europe to the end. You also mentioned in your priorities a strong Europe, Europe as a global partner. You mention NATO, of course it's very important, however, what worries me the most, that's this last point of yours, and that's the point of Europe of shared values, which you also talked about. I have to ask you a few questions, since you have already heard about it from previous colleagues: there are a lot of protests on the streets of Romania, there is talk about the rule of law and it is said that the rule of law is subject to subsidiarity. There's nothing we can agree on. Have you heard what the citizens of Romania are saying on the streets? Have you heard what they want to tell you? And did you stand up for the rule of law? This is what is very important in order for your presidency to be successful as well, if you could answer those questions.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Dăncilă. The Romanian Presidency will be that country’s first presidency and the last presidency before the European elections. So this will be a very important presidency, and let me focus particularly on the Sibiu summit, because the Sibiu summit is our last opportunity to project another kind of Europe for all citizens across Europe before the European elections. So let me tell you what our expectations are, our wishes for the kind of Europe we’d like to project using the Sibiu summit. We think that you are coming up with the right priorities. In order to have strong unity among Europeans cohesion is certainly the key word – as you said: economic, social, political cohesion. We are with you in this central priority and you can turn this into something very concrete. The first thing is a social pillar translated into European law and powerful European financial instruments. The second thing is a pre-agreement on the multiannual budget, on which cohesion is a central concern, both for all EU Member States and the eurozone. Then there is a third very important issue: yes Europe is counting on the European border, hopefully with Romania already included in the Schengen area. The fourth one is better partnerships with all our neighbouring regions, including our course Eastern partners, which are very dear to us. And then if we manage all these issues it will be easier to manage migration properly. Finally, if we have this kind of Europe we will have unity whatever happens with Brexit. So this is a very important historical task, but also an opportunity.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: – Mr President, the Romanian Presidency is a safe pair of hands for the Brexit process. I want the Romanian Prime Minister to help the British Prime Minister in that process. Two years ago, we thought Brexit would be a piece of cake. Today it is a hot potato, and not a bed of roses for Prime Minister Theresa May, who, with amazing bottle has taken the bit between her teeth and is going the whole hog. In the House of Commons, it is going down like a lead balloon tonight, but the Prime Minister is not throwing the baby out with the bathwater, nor changing her horses midstream. She knows it is a can of worms, but is determined to get the best for Britain, warts and all. Tonight she is between a rock and a very hard place. We wait with bated breath on a wing and a prayer for some success.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to wish the Prime Minister the presidency as efficiently as possible and encourage us to talk first and foremost about her programme, because there are many things to do. There are budgetary negotiations, there is the question of reassuching immigration policy, a whole series of programme activities of the Presidency. I am very pleased with this theme of cohesion policy, which is particularly close to Romania for obvious reasons, and I also believe that Romania will make a geopolitical sensitivity, this sensitivity to the security of our continent in the east, in view of Russia's expansion. I do not downplay the rule of law in my country. I am admonished for these basic values, but I urge my colleagues to stick to the logic of our actions. First of all, let us talk about the Presidency, we wish Romania to overcome internal problems – including those concerning the rule of law – and a successful Presidency. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, there is no doubt that the rotating presidency will be a challenging presidency. It is not easy to talk about the future of Europe, as you are facing Brexit, but it is very easy for some to speak out of reality, and this misinformation and lack of coherence in making statements is one of the great challenges we face at Union level. Undoubtedly, the rule of law is a priority for Romania and this is seen from the way we strictly respect (the President interrupted the speaker)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: You must put a question to Mrs Ujazdowski.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: Mr President, we are two Nicolai. Which one has the floor?

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: You asked for the floor to ask a "blue card" question. That is a request to the speaker. But if you don't have a question...

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: "No, I don't have a question. I want to express myself.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Alors, vous interviendrez plus tard.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I say to the Prime Minister: I think it is fantastic that Romania now has the Presidency of the European Union. That’s a sign of how Europe has developed, but you need to make it fantastic. And I would like to say that you and your government need to fight corruption, as we require from any other government. Pardoning corrupt politicians because you say that the prisons are overcrowded is not acceptable in the European Union. Fighting those who are fighting corruption is not acceptable. Decriminalising corruption or giving amnesty to corruption for safeguarding your own is not acceptable. I heard that Udo Bullmann, the leader of the Socialist Group, defended you. I must say that was a disgrace for the Socialist Group. It devalued him. And you need to take on the responsibility of safeguarding Romania, because we believe it is a fantastic thing that you are having the Presidency. Don’t make a mess of it, you have a responsibility, take it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, but do you not think it is a shame that today the President of the European People's Party, Mr Joseph Daul, congratulated President Iohannis, the President of Romania, saying that he will lead the Presidency of the Council of the European Union excellently, when we all know very well that the rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union is being taken over by the Romanian Government, headed by the Romanian Prime Minister? Is it also a shame that the Austrian Prime Minister, Kurz, in Bucharest on 21 December symbolically handed over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union to President Iohannis, again making a great political error and, at the same time, a mystification towards Romanian citizens and European citizens, who must know the truth?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I think my colleague has missed the point, because I was talking about the problems of corruption in Romania – as demonstrated by the Venice Commission, Transparency International and many others – and the pardoning of corrupt politicians, which was just referred to by the Romanian Foreign Minister on the BBC. You’re talking about someone congratulating the president of your country. Well, I must say I’m not very upset about that. You and the Socialists here should be just as strict towards Romania as we shall be towards Hungary and Poland, because misuse of power is always misuse of power. You will fight it and we shall fight it. (Applause)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President-in-Office, Honourable Prime Minister, you have raised quite a few dust at the beginning of the Presidency, including here in the Chamber, but I believe and trust you to prove otherwise, as you have already done in your conversations with us. I support the priorities of your Presidency, especially as regards the Western Balkans. Positive stories in the region are urgent and, therefore, sincere congratulations to our friends in Macedonia for the parliamentary vote on constitutional amendments, and I hope for a similar outcome in Greece. Leaders have shown wisdom and courage to resolve one of the region's oldest conflicts. I call on you, politicians and citizens, in the era of the European elections, to condemn the spread of hatred and all attempts to demolish institutions in a period of European elections. A different, sensible Europe is possible. Either she's going to be social or she's not going to be there. Either stability or peace, or authoritarianism won over democracy. And I would like you to do this Presidency with distinction, and we must remind our citizens of all the achievements of the Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, Romania holds the Presidency of the Council for the first time at a very challenging time when a sustainable agreement must be reached on the multiannual financial framework and in which the Union remains without a very important member. This, together with the European Parliament elections, will determine the near future of this community.  I hope that the internal problems romania is struggling with will not diminish the ambitions presented in the programme of activities. The Union must not waste time, because while we rearx our political map and finances, the world is not at rest. Migrant challenges cannot wait, nor can our positioning in a rapidly changing world. I consider it extremely important that the Romanian Presidency plans to address these issues. The issue of security must also not remain in the background.
