Europe is not as insecure, but it is no longer as safe as it was until recently, as confirmed by frequent attacks. Protecting our borders and our citizens must be one of our top priorities.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, it is a great joy for me to be able to negotiate legislative dossiers with the Presidency of the Council provided by my country. My position as a Romanian MEP, a member of the National Liberal Party, is as follows: I am already working and will work – as before, for that matter – with the Permanent Representation of Romania and I will contribute to the closure of legislative files. I will continue to defend the interests of Romanians in all the files that are ongoing. I do not accept the positions against the European Union of the PSD-ALDE government. I will oppose strange proposals by some ministers, such as restricting the freedom of movement of Romanian workers. I do not support the PSD-ALDE government's attacks on Justice and the rule of law. Mrs. Dancilă, you have been talking a lot lately about domestic political consensus. I do not agree with a consensus against justice, the rule of law and European values. You have applied for entry into the Schengen area. It's not complicated. Correct the laws of justice. Send ministers to talk in European capitals, convince governments to vote in favour of Romania, and be careful who you send to preside over the Justice and Home Affairs Council. Don't run away from European funds. Use them. Romanians need highways, hospitals, railways. If you did all this, you would demonstrate that you are on the side of Romanians and a European Romania and you would earn the respect of your European partners. It is your obligation to represent Romania according to the wishes of the majority of Romanians and not the majority in the Bucharest Parliament. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – I am a little surprised that, in fact, not a single speech has yet been made on one of the biggest human rights violations in Europe, namely the treatment of the Roma population.  Since you are from Romania, I would like to ask you whether this is because things have got better there for the Roma population, or is it the case that this kind of debate is usually so polite that no really difficult issues are raised.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Yes, it is a question, in my opinion, for lack of information. Member, colleague, I invite you to come with me to Romania, right to me in the region, where other colleagues of ours have been and visited the city and the region. I invite you to come and see what is happening, in the topic you have raised here in Romania.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Every six months, the Presidency of the Council changes. It is therefore a routine process, at least for the European level. Romania's takeover of the Presidency deviates from this pattern – firstly because the Presidency is under particular time pressure because of the election to the European Parliament, and secondly, because the presidency puts the country in the presidency in the spotlight of pan-European europe. Romania is still part of the anti-corruption cooperation and control mechanism. The Commission noticed a stalemate a few weeks ago, and last November, in a resolution adopted by a large majority, this House expressed its concern for the development of the rule of law. The events in Romania will therefore be closely monitored over the next six months. There in this, of course, there is also an opportunity. The country can show that it is capable of solving its internal problems in accordance with the commitments it made with accession. We are convinced that Romania can make a great deal of progress at European level, and we will be happy to support you in this.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Before I start using my minute, I would like to point out that twenty minutes ago, after Mr Bullmann's speech, I asked to speak on the agenda in order to draw the attention of President Tajani, who was sitting at the time, that Article 11 of the Rules of Procedure obliges us to respect each other and to beware of defamatory statements. Mr Bullmann's statement, which one of the countries, one of the Governments of the European Union, has described as fascist, also insults this Parliament, one of the Member States of the Union and the largest parliamentary group in this Parliament, to which I do not belong, and to which Mr Tajani belongs and the government attacked. These are unacceptable things to which the President should react immediately – this is the first. Secondly, there is no reason why a Member who asks to speak on a formal matter should not give such a vote. Mr Bullmann is not the only politician who has the right – and we know that he has benefited from this – to react to the statements of other colleagues. Mr President, I ask you to draw President Tajani's attention to the fact that there has been something doubly, if not triple, unacceptable with regard to Mr Bullmann's statement, the president's lack of response and the failure to allow the Member concerned to speak. And now I will move on to my speech. No, no – I will now move on to my speech, Mr President. Mr President, this was a formal vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Excuse me, you spoke on an issue with reference to President Tajani, who was in the Chamber and therefore knows perfectly well, who knows the matter perfectly well. I will tell you, but that was the point of your speech.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr. President, Madam Prime Minister, welcome to your old home. I want to speak here about the multi-year financial framework. As you know, our Parliament's position on this issue is clear: the European project needs an ambitious level of expenditure, geared towards the implementation of the sustainable development goals, starting with the fight against global warming and the fight against social and territorial inequalities. Faced with the rise of extremes, the future of the European project depends on a just transition to a new model of economic development. The Council must be well aware that, without significant progress on the resources side, the European Parliament will not give a consistent opinion on the expenditure side. However, I note that progress on this area of resources is almost nil. I understand that you would like to outline in May the outlines of a possible agreement on the multi-year financial framework. Can you tell us, on the one hand, what you mean by "big lines" and, on the other hand, how you intend to take parliament's view into account?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, first of all many wishes for your Presidency, and thank you for the four thematic priorities you have indicated to us. I would like to speak on the point of territorial convergence. I do not believe that any territory, as you have also mentioned, should be left behind. And precisely because I believe so, I believe that we also need, as we said here in the European Parliament a short time ago, an agenda for the territories left behind, namely rural, mountainous and peripheral areas. As you know, there is an agenda for urban areas, but also an agenda for these territories. You want to take parliament's lead, including through an initiative that will launch a first thought that can then lead to the drafting of the agenda. I believe that this would be very important for your Presidency. Romania is a territory that has peripheral areas of Europe, rural areas, mountain areas, I think that would be important.  Finally – a second – more than 20 million young people will vote in the European elections for the first time. What do you intend to do to involve them more and thus to help them come and vote in the European elections?

name: Dan NICA
text: –Mr President, Prime Minister, honourable members of the government, first of all I would like to congratulate you on the clear manner in which you have presented the priorities and programme of activities of the Romanian Presidency. At the same time, please do not be misled or confused, because some of the speeches made by colleagues in the European Parliament were not related to either the programme of activities or the Presidency of Romania, but only to the premature start of an election campaign. And don't be mad at Mr Verhofstadt in any way. You have to understand him: he also has a small deal with a Romanian party. It doesn't make the electoral threshold, and this state of annoyance must also be blamed on this failure. Otherwise, I would like to encourage you, together with the nearly 200 officials from the Romanian Representation in Brussels, together with the hundreds of officials who, in Romania, are preparing the Presidency of Romania, to follow this timetable that you have presented, Prime Minister, because the four pillars you have presented – convergence, safety, a global Europe and the Europe of values – are something that , for Romania, it will remain in history and this will continue to be remembered and will be kept as the most important political step that Romania has had and that Romanians have in the European Union.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to extend a particularly warm greeting to the President-in-Office of the Council, at this stage the Romanian President, who has been a valued colleague in our group and, above all, in our Parliament. I would like to highlight a few points, because many issues have already been raised, especially by my colleagues in my group, with whom I fully agree, and I would like to draw attention to two important aspects.  The issue of the social pillar, which is one of the four pillars that the Romanian Presidency has put as the basis of its programme and which I believe can be a 50-qualified element in the action of Europe's capacity at this stage that is so critical for the European citizens of so many countries. In some countries, the social tension that feeds our citizens is more evident, in others it is more subsopiled, but everywhere there is this demand for a Europe that approaches needs, starting with work, starting with welfare, starting with children. My group is particularly insisting on child guarantee.  The other aspect is that of industry. I see them together because a Europe that grows more is also Europe that can be closer to demands and needs. And I would remind you of important dossiers from this point of view too, I am thinking of Horizon and others, which this Presidency must, with its capacity and with the contribution of all, bring to a conclusion.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, welcome back to the Chamber of the European Parliament.  The imminence of the European elections leaves very little time for the Romanian Presidency to finish important legislative work together with Parliament. In view of the short time available to me, I am focusing on an important issue which is particularly close to my heart, which is the subject of the single market, which is recognised by all as one of the great successes of European integration and which unfortunately still has many weaknesses and many critical issues that have fuelled fears and anti-Europeanism in recent years. I believe that we must continue decisively on the road to its completion, establishing an effective framework of rules that govern in particular the digital transformation of our society and our economy.  Finally, in this regard, I would like to focus on one issue, the regulation on market surveillance, which I hope, together with the Romanian Presidency, to be able to conclude in the negotiations in the coming weeks. I believe it is necessary to ensure that European citizens have safe and law-a compliant products in circulation, especially those sold online. It is a regulation that we need in order to better protect European consumers and to ensure fair competition for businesses on our continent.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: –Mr President, Prime Minister, every Presidency must act on three lines: 1. continue where the previous Presidency left them; 2. achieve their own objectives; and 3.  fit into the concrete landscape in which the European Union is at the time. Romania has shaped its programme in compliance with these requirements. Today, when the liberal international order based on clear rules is under assault, Romania aims, through the Presidency, to contribute to the strengthening of the European Union as the main pillar of this system. At the same time, let us not forget that the European Union remains strong not only as an institution in itself, but also because of the own effort of each Member State, for, in today's and tomorrow's world, the protection offered by the institutions of the order so far will have to be matched by the Member States' own political and military economic efforts, in parallel with those to strengthen our Union. These objectives cannot be achieved by pursuing petty political stakes, by discrimination or isolation, but also by fair and honest cooperation between all members of the European Union.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, madam Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the first taking over of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union is a historic moment for our country, and I want to say very clearly: this Presidency belongs, first and foremost, to the Romanian people. I want to say equally clearly: the Romanian people are ready for this first Presidency of the European Union. We see how, for two years, in Romania, people have been manifesting themselves – even publicly, in the streets – in defence of European values, in defence of the rule of law, of independent justice, and they do so with the flag of the European Union in hand. But in addition to the fact that the Presidency of the European Union is an honour, it is also a responsibility, and your government, Prime Minister, will have the responsibility to manage some major European themes. Firstly, the European Union budget for the next seven years: we must give beneficiaries of European funds as soon as possible certainty about the amounts of money and the conditions under which European funds will be received. Brexit: we will have to manage the situation as a result of tonight's vote and we will have to give millions of European citizens in the UK certainty about their own future. Thirdly, Romania has the opportunity to put the situation in the eastern neighbourhood of the European Union on the agenda of the European Union. But, above all, you have an obligation to respect European values. This is what the European Union is waiting for and that is what the Romanian people are waiting for.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister of Romania, I will refer to immigration, because we are back in the same play, with the Council unable to assume its responsibilities, as certain Member States continue 'business as usual' and refuse to change Dublin III which has turned Greece and Italy into warehouses of souls. Greece can no longer afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. The Aegean islands have been sunk by migrants and by the increased inflows, which now exist on land in Evros. The European Union's famous solidarity remains a blank letter. The relocation must therefore be carried out. He had only been executed by thirty per cent. I propose to change the asylum system, to abolish Dublin III and to regulate the state of first entry, to allocate asylum applications as well as refugees and migrants between Member States on the basis of area, population and GDP. This will express European solidarity. We are waiting for measures from your presidency.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, honourable members of the government, dear colleagues, I would like to thank you, those who have given confidence to the Presidency of Romania. I assure you that I, too, have been part of a government, I know very well the members of the Government, I am convinced that it will take the Presidency forward. I am not going to talk about the programme because, for the first time, there was a very broad Council, a very broad committee, and we MEPs worked on this programme. We have very well-trained people, both at the Representation, and in the Government. There's something else I want to say. It is regrettable that these colleagues of ours, who have come to Parliament with false information, are operating with false information when we, the European Parliament, are trying to eliminate fake news. We are on the brink of campaigning, but that does not mean that we have to attack a Member State that is taking over the Presidency. We need to talk about the subject, we need to talk about the Presidency, about the programme. I would have liked you to ask more things. What can be done? How can it be done? To propose priorities, not to start talking about things we don't know – and I assure you you don't know them. I wish the Presidency success and I assure you that today a dossier was voted on in plenary where I am rapporteur and we will start the institutional negotiations and I assure you, my fellow members, that in the end you will see what a good Presidency Romania has. Congratulations and good luck!

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, dear Prime Minister, it is good to see you here again. In 2018, you participated as an MEP in the event I organised with two colleagues from your political group, Mr Pirinski from Bulgaria and Mrs Grabini from Romania, to look for new avenues for cooperation in the Balkans. I hope that you will now do your utmost to move Balkan cooperation forward. We are concerned, however, when we hear that Romania is a very bad example of industrial relations, wages, social security and rights. Is that right? You have worked with us for four years and you know the priorities of the European Parliament: social pillar, human rights, revision of the Common European Asylum System. That must be your priorities, too. I wish you a good presidency and that everything will go the best way.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: – Mr President, I would like to wish the Prime Minister the best for your Presidency and thank you for highlighting some of the most important points. One of the most important for us is the cohesion that you talked about, and it is extremely important not only when it comes to the economic differences between people, as you said, but also among their access to their rights as European citizens. The social and regional cohesion that you are talking about is therefore extremely important, and we will be looking to you over the next six months, because we believe that you have a great experience on these topics. You are home to some of the poorest citizens of the European Union and you are trying hard to change their situation. Thank you for the question on the Roma, and thank you for Mr Marinescu’s answer. I understand why he said what he said. It’s very important that we revisit the dossier of the poor. Your Presidency should really send a message out to Europe that 120 million poor people who are living in Europe need to be lifted out of poverty in the next few years. I hope that your Presidency will push this dossier very heavily. Thank you for your future work on this.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, esteemed members of the Romanian Government, dear colleagues, perhaps not coincidentally, today, twelve years after Romania's accession to the European Union, on the occasion of presenting Romania's priorities at the Council of the European Union, Romania celebrates two extremely important anniversaries: 169 years since the birth of Mihai Eminescu, our great national poet, translated into over sixty languages, and the Day of National Culture. For us Romanians, what is happening today, here, now in the European Parliament, when Romania, through the voice of Prime Minister Viorica Dăncilă, presents its vision of the presidency of the Presidency of the European Union, is a third moment of celebration, a celebration that makes us truly feel the sons and daughters of this great European family of the peoples of the European Union. I take this opportunity to wish her Prime Minister Viorica Dăncilă and the members of the Romanian Government every success and to ask you, colleagues, to trust Romania's ability and vision during this mandate. It is an honour for me, as an MEP, to work on the files that will be led by the Presidency of my country. As Vice-President of the Committee on Agriculture in the European Parliament, I know that the common agricultural policy is a priority for Europe, and therefore, Prime Minister, I ask you: what is the vision of the Romanian Presidency and what is the Presidency of Romania proposing in relation to this European position?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, very briefly: Prime Minister, in recent months, you and the members of your government have criticised the European Commission. You have argued on numerous occasions that the work of the European Commission is based on misinformation, on superficiality. You have also criticised – and you, and the members of your government – the European Parliament's resolution, also claiming that foreign forces have manipulated it and are basing its position on untruths. How do you think you will be able to work with the Commission and Parliament, the institutional partners, after you have planted mistrust and also told Romanians that they should not trust the Commission and Parliament? Right here, by the way, some of your former colleagues have said the same thing. I want to tell you something else: when you discuss the priorities of the Romanian Presidency, in Romania, a television station has suspended the broadcast, because it dared to present images from the protest of 10 August. So tell Mr Bullmann that the situation of the press in Romania is a combination of propaganda, pressure on journalists and that there is no free press in Romania. That should worry you, Prime Minister, if you were not in a celestial logic, if you did not want to go back to the times when propaganda was preferred to the truth. You will be truly European if you wake up, ma'am... (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, under the Romanian Presidency, there are many important issues on the table that I hope will progress over the next few months. With regard to individual projects, I would like to stress the importance of the directive on the protection of whistleblowers. A person detecting abuse in the private or public sector must be able to report any offences and offences they have detected without fear of retaliation. If protection or handling cannot be relied upon, the abuses will go unreported and the same criminal expenditure may continue for years. Questions have arisen in the Council about the legal basis of the directive, to which the legal services of Parliament or the Commission found no comment. This must not mean that the matter is bogged down in the Council.  I hope that the presidency will make every effort to promote a positive outcome to the negotiations in order to achieve minimum standards of protection at European level for public interest defenders reporting abuses.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, colleagues, my country's takeover of the Presidency is a major event for Romania and Romania will prove to the whole of the European Union its value and administrative capacity, as well as the important role it will play in the management of European affairs and in defining the future of European construction. You must understand that Romania has a strategic position and will become a binder and a balancing factor that harmonises the divergent interests that have often separated eastern and western Europe. Romania is a deeply European country and I think it is more important than ever that, in this challenging period, we show unity and solidarity, for the good of all Romanians. I regret to tell you, Mr Verhofstadt, Mrs Keller and others who have spoken today, that you are in a great error and that your information is incorrect and you are the victim of gross manipulation. It is regrettable that you are making today on Romania and its government, and I believe that they are part of the logic of an election campaign. Romania is a rule of law, and the Romanian Government upholds the fundamental rights and freedoms of Romanians, while the President of Romania, your friend and the European people, ignores the Constitution and the decisions of the Constitutional Court. Finally, if we want a fair and equal Europe for all its members, I hope that 2019 will be the year of an CVM-free Union for Romania and Bulgaria and with a strengthened Schengen area, through the full integration of Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Prime Minister, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I would like to thank all of you for this very intense debate. As we know, during the Romanian Presidency there will be Brexit, there will be elections to the European Parliament and there will be ongoing negotiations on the next multiannual financial perspective. At the same time, we have to conclude negotiations on 242 different proposals. ‘We are going to do a good job together’ was what President Klaus Iohannis said last week in Bucharest. During our college’s visit to Bucharest, I got a clear understanding that Romanian ministers are taking those words seriously. I look forward to fruitful cooperation between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Romanian Government during its EU Presidency. I wish every success to the Romanian EU Presidency.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the speeches of my colleagues, former colleagues in the European Parliament. To be honest, I expected proposals, I expected solutions, a positive approach, so that all European citizens who today look to us, see answers to the problems that concern them, answers to the problems that exist for different social categories, for different regions and for different countries. As I said in a previous speech, I did not come to account for certain things. We have come here, to the European Parliament, as Prime Minister of Romania, to find together solutions that will make a strong European Union, a European Union that is much closer to the citizens of all the Member States. I would like to thank the Vice-President for his kind words, for the trust that the Commission places on the Presidency of the Council of the European Union held by Romania. We need your support and I am convinced that, together with the European Commission, the European Parliament, we will ensure stability and consensus for the dossiers and challenges we have on the European agenda. I'm going to try to answer some of the issues raised. Mr Stolojan, new ministers have experience. They secured the Presidency from the shadows and contacted both the Chairmen of the Committees of the European Parliament and the Line Commissioners on each area. We are certainly supporting the General Secretariat of the Council of the European Union. Please do not leave with a preconceived idea that Cabinet ministers do not manage the files or that they will not be able to give positive answers to the problems they have to solve. For your part, as a Romanian, I expected you to trust the romanian ministers and Romania's capacity. You tell me about the meeting and the Prime Minister's obligation to meet with the prime ministers of France or the Netherlands. I have every openness to do this, I have every openness to go to the Dutch Parliament and I have every openness to tell the President of Romania to address these topics in the European Council, because he is attending the European Council. On the euro area: the plan for joining the euro area was finalised in December 2018, is already printed and includes the steps we need to take in this direction. So, we have kept our word and, if you want this program, we are at your disposal to offer it to you. We thank the President of the S&D group for his support and guarantee that we support the rule of law but, at the same time, we also support human rights, we also support the rights of those who have suffered as a result of wrong decisions by the judiciary. Mr Verhofstadt – I'm sorry he left here. I want to assure him that we know the files and challenges that we face. That is why we have asked for consensus, because we need codecision, we need consensus and we will work in this direction. At the same time, I expected a political group leader to come up with assessments on the European Agenda, not on the internal issues of a country that has just taken over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. For credibility, I think we need to speak in good conscience, and I would like to know from Mr Verhofstadt what he is reproaching the Romanian Government. At the same time, I call on Mr Verhofstadt to let the Romanians decide for themselves, to believe in their honesty and not to try to induce their own beliefs towards the Romanians. And my colleagues, I am convinced that I can come up with suggestions for other countries, but I believe that we must let every people and citizens of every people believe, choose and have their own beliefs. Mrs. Keller, you say that thousands of Romanians took to the streets for good governance. I think you've been misinformed about good governance. I just want to give you a few figures, showing what good governance means in Romania: we have economic growth above 4%, economic deficit 2.92%, unemployment below 4%, investments in Romania increased by more than 10%. I believe that this means good governance, and I believe that the misinformation of some colleagues in the European Parliament has induced this perception. If you want, we send you all the figures and everything the Romanian Government has done to ensure an increase in living standards and good governance for Romania and for Romanians. I think you should also compare it with the results of other countries, and perhaps then you will see that Romania has a government that knows what to do and that has been concerned with the problems of Romanians and Romania. Mr Paksas asked us why the interest in the unification of the European Union has been replaced by that of the division of the European Union. I think it's a question we all have to ask ourselves. I think we need to work harder and we see what unites us and see less and appreciate less what divides us, because only together, united, only through cohesion, can we take important steps for the European Union. I want to thank Maria João Rodrigues for her very kind words and, indeed, the Sibiu Summit will give us the opportunity, together, to shape the future of the European Union. I believe that to talk about the future of the European Union is to find together, regardless of the political group and all the European institutions, the best solutions that bring us closer to the citizens, so that we have a united future and a best future for the citizens of the Union. Mr Hökmark, the government must fight corruption. Amnesty – I have said many times: I have no normative act on the government table on this. We don't want to protect anyone, we just want to protect citizens whose rights have been violated. I would be very happy that, when we talk about the rule of law, when we talk about justice, we will all fight corruption – and the Romanian Government will do so – but also protect the rights of citizens who have been affected by justice decisions, secret protocols between justice and the secret services. Those who are now loudly suing that they are fighting corruption, that they want to fight for the rule of law, many of them want to hide what actually happened in Romania and, in fact, were part of this system that led to human rights violations. Mr Marinescu, your position against the Romanian Government is unjustified. You said there were attacks by the PSD-ALDE government against justice. I do not remember and no one, no Romanian, i think can say that the Romanian Government has taken a decision against justice. All laws on justice have been passed in the Romanian Parliament, and the Romanian Parliament is the expression of the vote of Romanian citizens. You have spoken of European funds. I think you were referring to the technocratic government, because we, during our government, recovered in a year. We have 26% absorption of European funds, not counting agriculture, compared to 27%, as the European average. I believe that the fact that this government is on the side of the Romanians is proven by the measures we are taking and not by those who voted here in the European Parliament against their own country. Mrs Bresso, indeed, territorial convergence is very important and no region should be left behind. Rural areas, peripheral areas, mountain areas – we will receive with great openness all the suggestions, in order to advance this topic on our agenda. You told us that twenty million young people will vote for the first time and what we can do to convince them to come to the polls. First of all, we need to show that we have solutions for them. Secondly, we must show that our dispute is not between political groups, between citizens – often of the same Member State – and that our disputes and that our solutions are for them, that we can bring added value and that they must be found in the decisions we make in the European institutions. I think, I trust that together we can do this. I trust MEPs, I trust the European Commission, I trust the Council that, together, we will be able to give in the next six months the answers that these twenty million young people expect, the answers that the more than five hundred million European citizens expect. Mrs Járóka, you are telling us that we are a poor state and that we must do something in this direction. In the last year, that's exactly what I've done. I've raised my standard of living. We have seen that austerity is not a solution for our country or for other Member States. I've raised wages. I've increased pensions. I've increased doctors' salaries. I've increased teachers' salaries. I've increased benefits for disadvantaged people. We invested in the countryside, in the small towns. It is precisely these things that I think we need to do, so as not to talk about poverty, beyond the decisions that we have to make together, at European level. Last thing: the last question I want to answer – in fact, the latest accusations – I have thought a lot about whether or not it is worth giving this answer, but I think that citizens need to distinguish between a hostile attitude and an open attitude. Mr Preda, the Romanian Government and the Prime Minister of Romania do not criticise the European Parliament and the European Commission. I was an MEP and I have always supported the pro-European attitude. After nine years in the European Parliament, in which I have not made a scandal, like you, in which I have united with all the positive solutions for the European institutions, I cannot stand against these institutions. I criticised the resolution, because I believed and I think we need to have this unity of Able. You spoke about the protests in Romania on 10 August. What about the protests in France? What attitude do you have? I am not going to refer to this, because France is taking its own decisions, but France – and no other MEP in France – has come to criticise its own country here in the European Parliament. (intervention by Mr Preda, without microphone)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Preda, please.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – I believe that we must trust the European institutions and I believe that our attitude matters to the citizens who watch us from home. You have made a very serious statement about freedom of the press. I assure you, fellow members, fellow members, fellow Commissioners, I assure the European Parliament that the Romanian Government has nothing to do with this. But that means misinformation, that means what we don't have to do from now on. Indeed, a television station had its broadcast interrupted for ten minutes, as decided by the National Audiovisual Council. I don't know what the reason is. The Romanian Government has nothing to do with this. At the same time, we must see, in order to give more confidence in our decisions and in ourselves, as pro-Europeans, to pay attention to the statements we make and to speak what reflects reality because otherwise each of us will be judged but, more importantly, this European construction, which deserves a good future, will be judged. Thank you again. I am very much betting on the support of the European Parliament, on the support of the European Commission, and I wish and wish all of us success for our pro-European course.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the previous debate, following Mr Bullmann's speech, I asked for a vote on the procedural issue. A Member's right to speak on a procedural matter is not a privilege, it is a right defined by Rule 184a of the Rules of Procedure, moreover, while the first and third paragraphs of this article expressly mention the law, the fourth and fifth paragraphs oblige the President of Parliament to respond to reported violations of the Rules of Procedure. Exceptionally, in the fifth paragraph, this may be postponed by 24 hours, but the issue must not be cancelled.  You, Mr President, did not give me a voice after the outrageous statement by Mr Bullmann, who used the term 'fascist' in relation to one of the Countries of the European Union. As a result, Mr Sassoli, when I spoke in the normal debate, made it impossible for me to speak on the most substantive issue. This is really not how Parliament can be led, because the first duty of the President of Parliament, and I say this as a former President of Parliament, is to protect the right of expression of every Member. We very often talk about illiberal democracy, but this concern for democracy to function within the rule of law should, above all, start with this Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I'm going to get a transcript of what happened so I can evaluate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – The last two EU Presidencies, Bulgaria and Austria, have made enlargement a priority, taking advantage of their traditional political and geographical proximity to the Western Balkans. As a result of the priorities, strategies and declarations have been adopted, sound words have been uttered, but nevertheless the enlargement processes have slowed down rather, it is enough to take a look at the accession chapters that have been opened. On this basis, unfortunately, it seems that if the EU prioritises something, it serves to slow down the process rather than accelerate it.  The Romanian Presidency also prioritises enlargement in its programme, to which I can only congratulate it, and I hope that this will finally be seen in the dynamics of the processes and that we will see an acceleration of accession. The Hungarian People's Party delegation stands firmly and consistently in its position that the Western Balkans region should become an integral part of the European Union, and we therefore, together with the Government of Hungary, are effectively supporting the enlargement process, trusting that the accession deadline of 2025 is achievable. Thank you for listening.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – "Cohesion is a common European value" in my opinion is a very relevant slogan for romania's first rotating presidency of the Council of the EU. We cannot afford a two-speed Europe, separate budgets within the EU. This slogan also refers to the primary importance of cohesion policy. It is good that it was recalled during the negotiations of the new Multiannual Financial Framework. Cohesion is also about unity, convergence and equal treatment. I hope that we will be able to make up for the mistakes and omissions of recent years here.  The Romanian Presidency is also important in the context of Russian aggression against Ukraine and the illegal annexation of Crimea. I am convinced that, understanding the dangers of Russia's militarisation of the Black Sea, Bucharest will also see the dangerous consequences of the militarisation of the Königsnish Region and the risks associated with Nord Stream2. I hope that, unlike the previous Presidency, Romania will unblock the revision of the Gas Directive.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Romanian Presidency's motto and priorities seem to be an appropriate response to the challenges facing the EU today. The growing divisions within the Union, not to mention Brexit, such as attempts to divide the euro area and the rest, divide Europe into countries that may break European law, and those that, although not exceeding the deficit, have to negotiate their budgets or whose internal legal solutions are called into question make us need 'cohesion as a common European value'.  We believe that the first-ever Romanian Presidency will contribute to greater unity and equality with EU law and, in particular, to ensuring the 'coherence, convergence and equal treatment' of all Member States, including in the negotiations on a new financial framework. A Romania well prepared for the Presidency can contribute to overcoming the procedures that divide the EU. We support the Romanian Presidency's approach to migration, highlighting, like Poland, on-the-spot aid, i.e. the response to migration through 'cooperation with countries of origin and transit' and 'dialogue between all Member States to find an effective and sustainable solution'. We support Romania's approach to security, in particular cooperation with NATO, the enlargement of the EU to the Western Balkans, the development of its own defence capabilities by CORD, EDF and PESCO and the Eastern Partnership. The Romanian Presidency comes at a time of landmark elections to the European Parliament and the election of a new European Commission.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – As a Romanian MEP, I am proud of Romania's takeover of the Presidency of the Council of the European Union. There are, however, a few shadows at this festive moment. For several months there has long been a suspicious discussion of Romania's "inability" to exercise this mandate. It went to the point where, more jokingly, more seriously, another country offered to take over this mandate, so that Romania could better prepare for another term. Even at the debates on Tuesday, 15 January, there were interventions by MEPs, obviously motivated by electoral interests. The issue that I find more important is that of the priorities set by the Bucharest Government. Even at a cursory review, we see that "common values" and "convergence" actually say much the same thing. The implicit message is, in fact, that the Presidency Romanian defend a Union in crisis. But the real solution to a crisis is reform. And how could the Romanian Government reform in the European Union when it is unable to reform in Romania? I wish success to the Presidency of Romania, but I remain disappointed that this mandate will only perpetuate a crisis situation.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – I, too, would like to wish Romania a successful Presidency. One of the most important legislative proposals on the table in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection is the package on modernising consumer law. It also includes a proposal that, after years of taking of evidence and explaining, is finally intended to put an end to the so-called dual quality of products. Adapting the composition of branded products depending on where they are sold is not in line with the basic principles of the internal market. Dual quality must be an unfair commercial practice and properly penalised. The addition of the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive is a unique opportunity. Let us not be be besmed by arguments about preferences that the world has not seen. Romania has its own negative experience according to the double quality tests carried out. It should therefore be more receptive to justified consumer concerns than the previous Austrian Presidency and use this opportunity to strengthen citizens' confidence in a fair internal market.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – Priorities of the Romanian Presidency 15 January 2019 As representatives of the Hungarian community in Romania, we made an official proposal last year for the Romanian Presidency to add to its priority list the protection of indigenous national minorities living in Europe and, in this context, to encourage the sharing of best working practices. There are 50 million citizens of indigenous national minorities or linguistic minorities in the European Union, and their situation must be addressed by the EU and the countries holding the respective EU Presidency, since the Treaty of Lisbon stipulates a prohibition on discrimination on the basis of membership of a national minority. It is also very important for the rule of law to ensure the effectiveness of existing minority protection legislation in the Member States, which is causing serious problems in several countries.  It is important to be aware that in Romania, the laws adopted during the EU accession process to ensure the use of languages by minorities or for education are not being respected, so it is essential to address this issue at European level, as member states' solutions do not work.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. – Romania's EU Presidency has a glaring contrast between the beautiful words diplomatically worded and the inexorable reality. The Romanian Government has announced its Presidency programme under the slogan 'Cohesion as a common European value', with the aim of reducing divisions and eliminating discrimination. President Klaus Iohannis stressed the importance of unity and consensus and the need for a deal on the rule of law. All leaders in Brussels have urged the new Presidency to stand up for the rule of law, fight corruption and defend European core values.  On the other hand, the opposite applies to Romania, which has made statements, promises and expectations. The European institutions themselves condemn the deplorable state of the rule of law in Romania. Romania is not only strengthening European unity and cohesion, but it is also deeply divided in itself. The fierce war between the post-communist government and the president's office has brought society to the brink of a constitutional and domestic political crisis. Corruption is flourishing and, contrary to the xenophobic agenda, discrimination against ethnic and religious minorities is part of state policy.  In order to represent the cohesion and unity between the old and the new, eastern and western Member States in a credible and effective way, Romania must, above all, clean up its own house and establish a democratic rule of law. Let's be on this. And god help you with that.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: Writing. – The Common Agricultural Policy and Cohesion Policy must be heavily cemented in the European Union's post-2021 budget. This objective should be a priority on the agenda of romania's EU Presidency. We now know that the Member States do not support finalising the Eu budget before the Elections to the European Parliament. So those who will be elected on 26 May will decide on the new budget! The stakes of the Elections to the European Parliament in Transylvania are the continuation of developments and the future of agricultural subsidies. It is also up to us whether those who are in the majority are those who are calling for funding cuts or those who support the continuation of improvements. The union's next seven-year budget will be decided after the elections, but we are already working on the draft budget here in Parliament and in the Council. All consultations, all technical meetings are led by diplomats, experts and representatives of the government in Romania. We expect them to strongly defend the common agricultural policy and the future of the Cohesion Funds, because this is the common interest of Central and Eastern Europe and it is also in the interest of our community.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – (C) The Romanian Presidency of the Council of the European Union, in addition to its intrinsic importance, is also of increased political importance, as it is in its framework that elections to the European Parliament will be held. The priorities set are the ones to meet the aniggities and expectations that European citizens have been demonstrating in opinion studies, namely strengthening cohesion and convergence and strengthening the relationship between cohesion and security. The focus on strengthening the European Union's role as a global actor is also a key priority, as is the development of shared values in the context of great geopolitical and geostrategic instability. The key issue for the success of the Romanian Presidency will be the ability to move from words to deeds. In this area, the strengthening of transparency and the practice of the values which it intends to promote, on its own territory, is a condition of credibility. On the other hand, the progress made in the design of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 will be the touchstone to achieve the very timely and positive vision of commitment to cohesion and convergence. The success of the Romanian Presidency, to be made, will be an excellent signal to the European project.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Gabriel Mato, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the ECB's 2017 Annual Report (2018/2101(INI)) (A8-0424/2018).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, welcome, Mr Draghi. As always, it's a pleasure to have you in this house. And I would like to begin my speech by thanking the shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues for their great support and cooperation in order to be able to present what I think is a good report. The euro has turned twenty, and it does so at its most popular time. Three out of four citizens think it's beneficial to our economy. What started out as the common currency for 11 countries is today for 19 and 340 million inhabitants. And besides, the euro reaches its twentieth anniversary after a great year. In 2017 the European economy grew at its strongest rate over the past ten years. But more importantly, all Member States saw their economies expand. And we must recognise that this is due both to the monetary policy of the European Central Bank and to the structural reforms carried out by many Member States. The latest data published by Eurostat in July last year shows us that we are going in the right direction. Economic growth for 2018 and 2019 is consolidated above 2%. Unemployment is basically at pre-crisis levels of around 7%, while the number of people employed and the eurozone labour market share ratio is at its highest level since the creation of monetary and economic union in 1999. But it's not all positive. I am alarmed by the lack of upward convergence and the tendency of some Member States not to address their structural deficits. As far as inflation is concerned, the European Central Bank, whose statutory independence is fundamental, and I repeat, is fulfilling its mandate to keep inflation below, but around 2%. In the medium term, inflation is expected to remain around 1.7% by 2018, 2019 and 2020, which is undoubtedly thanks to the measures taken. We have also seen an improvement in credit to the private sector, which, in mid-2018, increased at a rate of 3% per year. That said, we have to be cautious because of the uncertainty that is emerging around the European Union with the resurgence of populism, negotiations and possible consequences of Brexit and protectionism, among many other risks. We must focus our efforts on the essentials, which is nothing more than ensuring that we remain on the path of economic growth and job creation, which is true social policy. To this end, it is key to maintain a scenario conducive to public and private investment, bringing it to its pre-crisis levels. In this respect, greater action is needed by the ECB to ensure that its monetary policy achieves the objective of restoring credit to the real economy, particularly SMEs, which are the backbone of our economy, and that monetary expansion measures benefit the whole of society as a whole. In the report we have prepared and will vote tomorrow we have taken up all aspects of the European Central Bank's monetary policy, taking the measures that had to be taken, but also welcoming the decision to progressively reduce these measures, provided that the economic situation permits. We highlight the potential interest rate hike, the reduction of the asset purchase programme, liquidity auctions, the launch of the corporate bond purchase programme and, of course, the public debt purchase programme in the euro area. But I would like to stress that the European Central Bank cannot solve the structural problems of the Member States. It is the Member States, in cooperation with the European institutions, that must act at national level to establish a solid foundation on which to establish the European Union. The ECB's measures are transitional in nature, and their main advantage is that they give Member States time to consolidate their fiscal situation and implement structural reforms that will create the conditions for continuing on the path of economic growth, something we are all involved in.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr Vice—President of the Commission, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I am very pleased to be here to discuss with you the ECB’s activities and your draft resolution on the ECB’s Annual Report 2017. Twenty years ago, on 1 January 1999, the euro was officially introduced and the Eurosystem started its monetary policy operations. Establishing a single currency area between 11 European countries was a historic step for our continent and certainly a quantum leap in our economic integration. Its twentieth anniversary gives us an opportunity to reflect on its successes, but also to consider what still needs to be done for the euro to deliver its full benefits.  In this context, I would like to use my remarks to take a look back at the ECB’s monetary policy, to take stock of what we have learned and to highlight the challenges that remain. I will mostly focus on the past seven years, which coincide with my term as ECB President. The two decades in which the euro has existed could hardly have been more different. The first decade was the culmination of a thirty—year period of macroeconomic stability – the era known as the ‘Great Moderation’. The second decade then produced the worst economic and financial crisis since the Great Depression. Naturally, these periods required very different monetary policy responses and different tools to implement them.  As the pre—crisis period was characterised by moderate swings in the economic cycle, the ECB was able to ensure price stability mainly by adjusting its policy rates. But the crisis of 2008 fundamentally changed the economic and financial landscape in which we operated. New instruments became essential to safeguard the effectiveness of our monetary policy and stabilise the euro area economy. This in turn required us to refine our approach to central bank communication and accountability. When I arrived at the ECB in November 2011, the euro area faced a very challenging set of circumstances. The economy had bounced back from the post-Lehman crisis in a similar manner to other jurisdictions. But, from 2010 onwards, a loss of confidence in the sustainability of sovereign debt had produced a vicious circle of rising borrowing costs, financial fragmentation, and contracting economic activity. Cuts in key ECB interest rates were not being passed on to firms and households to the same extent in every euro area country. We were witnessing a serious disruption in the monetary policy transmission mechanism which, if left untended, would have posed a profound threat to price stability. The ECB responded with two sets of policies. First, central bank liquidity was made available to banks for up to three years and a range of collateral that banks could use to access central bank money was expanded. This helped reduce fragmentation in banks’ funding conditions. Second, the ECB announced what we called outright monetary transactions (OMTs) in the summer of 2012, which removed the redenomination risk in government bond markets stemming from fears of a possible euro break—up. Yet the sovereign debt crisis left a deep scar on the economy. Unemployment rose steeply, firms cut back on investment and loan delinquencies increased. Even though financial fragmentation was diminishing, banks began to shrink their balance sheets and became less willing to lend. This produced a renewed cycle of contracting credit growth and weak demand dynamics. Inflation drifted downwards. With inflation now well below our objective, the ECB faced a new type of policy challenge. We needed not only to repair the transmission problems created by deleveraging banks. We also needed to expand our policy stance to counteract deflationary pressures. So, in June 2014, we launched our targeted long—term refinancing operations, which once more provided long—term liquidity to banks – but conditional on extending credit to the private sector. We introduced negative rates on excess reserves to further encourage banks to lend to households and firms and, soon after, we announced our asset purchase programme (APP), buying asset—backed securities and covered bonds. Faced with a continued decline in inflation and a heightened risk of de—anchoring of inflation expectations, in January 2015 we expanded the asset purchase programme to include public sector securities. Since then, both the size and duration of our asset purchases have been recalibrated in response to changes in the inflation outlook. Our asset purchases have also been complemented by further cuts in policy rates and the use of what we call ‘forward guidance’. Communicating our expectations about future policy, along with the conditions that would warrant a change in the policy stance, has successfully contributed to reduce the uncertainty around the expected future path of short—term interest rates, thereby helping to preserve accommodative financing conditions.  Supported by these policy measures, the euro area economy has steadily recovered. We have now seen 22 consecutive quarters of economic growth. There are 9.6 million more people in employment in the euro area than there were in the second quarter of 2013, which was the worst point of the crisis – so in five years. The unemployment rate has declined to 7.9%, its lowest level since October 2008, and the employment rate of people aged 15-74 has risen from 54% in 1999 to 59% in the second quarter of 2018, the highest rate ever recorded in the euro area. The main motor of the recovery has been the domestic economy, driven by a strengthening in domestic demand and improving labour markets. That underlying strength of the economy has underpinned our confidence that inflation would converge towards our inflation aim in a sustained manner. As such, since 2017, we have gradually reduced the monthly pace of net asset purchases. We decided to end our net purchases in December last year, confident that the sustained convergence of inflation to our aim would proceed. At the same time, recent economic developments have been weaker than expected and uncertainties, notably related to global factors, remain prominent. So there is no room for complacency here. A significant amount of monetary policy stimulus is still needed to support the further build—up of domestic price pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term. Our forward guidance on key ECB interest rates, reinforced by the reinvestments of the sizeable stock of assets we have acquired so far, continues to provide the necessary degree of monetary accommodation for a sustained convergence of inflation to our objective. So what have we learned from our experience? The ECB’s monetary framework rests on three elements: a clear mandate to achieve price stability; independence over the instruments we can use to achieve our mandate; and a strong accountability framework. The importance of each of these elements has been reinforced by the crisis. First, we have seen that a well—defined mandate is vital for our credibility with the public, because it guarantees that the ECB will always act in the interest of the whole euro area and will not be swayed by interest groups.  Second, we have seen that instrument independence is key to an effective monetary policy since it allows the central bank to act quickly and flexibly to shocks, especially in exceptional times. Indeed, a well—equipped toolbox, comprising both standard and non—standard instruments, has proven indispensable in conditions where monetary policy transmission is impaired or where space for interest rate cuts is limited.  Third, we have seen the importance of a strong accountability framework, particularly when central banks have to use new tools that are not well understood by the public. Central banks are powerful and independent, but they are not elected. The combination can only be squared if they are held accountable by elected authorities.  In light of this, we have stepped up our efforts to improve our communication and strengthen our accountability in recent years. The Governing Council has started to publish the accounts of its monetary policy meetings. The ECB and the European Parliament have increased the intensity and focus of their exchanges. All this has provided us with more opportunities to explain our decisions and demonstrate how the ECB is acting in accordance with its mandate, which is a fundamental pillar of its legitimacy. The crisis has offered many lessons beyond monetary policy too. The euro area entered the crisis with an incomplete institutional and regulatory framework, not only for the banking sector but also in other areas of economic policy. The creation of the banking union and the European Stability Mechanism has strengthened the ability of the EU authorities to intervene decisively in future crises. Reforms at national level and the strong political commitment to the euro shown by European policymakers were equally instrumental in strengthening the foundations of our common project. But the necessary changes took time and it was time that the euro area lost in its recovery. Our monetary union is now in a better shape, but further progress can, and should, be made.  As I had the opportunity to discuss during my regular hearing before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and as your draft resolution points out, the priority now is to increase the resilience of the euro area. This would also strengthen the transmission of monetary policy in future downturns. Resilience depends on the euro area being able to use a broad policy mix involving monetary, fiscal, prudential and structural instruments. Let me now conclude. The first two decades of the euro area have seen an evolution in the way the ECB conducts its monetary policy. Faced with unprecedented threats to price stability, the ECB adapted its policy instruments to continue delivering on its mandate. We will continue to do so if and when needed, in compliance with our mandate as defined by the EU Treaties, and with all the independence over our tools as defined by our legal framework. Today, we can say that the euro area has emerged from a crisis so severe as to threaten at times its existence. We are out of it primarily because of the resilience, the energy, and the entrepreneurial capacity of European citizens, as well as their trust in their leaders’ commitment to the euro. Our policy response and the important changes to the architecture of the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) in the meantime also helped the euro area out of the crisis. In many ways we have a stronger monetary union today than we had in 2008. This is also reflected in the euro’s popularity among euro area citizens, which is currently – as I was reminded a moment ago – at its highest level since it was introduced. But more work is still necessary to complete the EMU so as to make it more resilient in the face of future crises. To deliver its full benefits, the European Union requires permanent political commitment, at both national and European levels, and across policy areas.  In this respect I can testify to the essential role the European Parliament has played during the challenging years of the crisis and I am certain that it will also be fundamental in carrying out the remaining work until the completion of Economic and Monetary Union.  The credibility of the ECB rests on its independence and this is based on its accountability with respect to its mandate, as enshrined in the EU Treaties. The European Parliament, in holding the ECB to account, gives legitimacy to its independence.  Since this is my last hearing before this plenary as ECB President, let me thank all of you for how this process has been carried out during my mandate, for the valued interactions with you, and the opportunity you have given me to explain the ECB’s policies.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr President, for your words to the European Parliament, cooperation will continue until the end of your term of office, even though this was your last speech on this subject, but we will continue to work together until the end of your term of office. Thank you again for your presence and for your cooperation.  I now give the floor to the Vice-President of the European Commission, Valdis Dombrovskis.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Gabriel Mato and the members of the Committee on Economic Affairs for this report.  It’s a pleasure to be here to discuss it with you and Mario Draghi and that is all the more true in the context of the 20th anniversary of the euro. In those twenty years the euro has proved itself a successful currency which is widely supported by people. Around three—quarters of Europeans think that having the euro is a good thing for Europe. A debate on the European Central Bank’s activities by the European Parliament is an important manifestation of democratic accountability. Let me start by saying that the Commission largely shares the general thrust of the report discussed here today.  The Commission shares the report’s views that the ECB’s independence in the conduct of its monetary policy as enshrined in the Treaties is crucial to the objective of safeguarding price stability. Independence and accountability are intertwined and the Commission also acknowledges the European Central Bank’s efforts to improve transparency and democratic accountability vis-à-vis European citizens and the European Parliament.  We also share the view expressed in the report that monetary policy alone cannot sufficiently achieve sustainable economic growth and that the euro area economy should be supported by a mix of ambitious, socially balanced, growth—friendly and productivity—enhancing structural reforms and fiscal policies in line with the Stability and Growth Pact. Allow me also to welcome the call in the report to accelerate the Capital Markets Union in order to deepen financial integration. This will help in building up resilience to shocks and making the transmission of monetary policy across the Monetary Union more effective. The Commission shares the report’s view that deeper and better connected European capital markets, which will result from the Capital Markets Union and from the step—by—step completion of the banking union, will foster the international standing of the euro. This point was also emphasised in our Communication on a stronger international role for the euro that we presented on 5 December 2018.  I have no doubt that today’s debate will confirm the constructive engagement that has been developed between the European Parliament and the European Central Bank over the past years.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Mato for his good report and the President of the ECB for explaining what are broadly positive trends in this 2017 annual report. I note, for example, that you are satisfied, and you write this in your report, that many banks use these better times to make their balance sheets healthier. The percentage of bad loans has indeed fallen and you give all the figures. Unfortunately, however, there are still exceptions, and I am therefore proud that, together with Mr Gualtieri and together with a very constructive Council, I have managed to draw up for the first time rules that will now oblige all banks in the EU to deal with bad loans. Finally, I'd say. Then we must now, and the ECB rightly points out, tackle the already bad loans that already exists.  Finally, perhaps EDIS, because that is also the subject of Mr Mato's report. I think that the recent developments concerning the Carige bank in Italy illustrate well the concerns that are still alive in this debate. Although private Italian DGS is used where possible in this crisis, not to compensate account holders, but to provide the bank with capital. We know that this early intervention is permitted under certain conditions, but we also know that one country uses it more than the other, with the result that the bill is being shifted back to the taxpayer. That wasn't supposed to happen. This explains the deadlock in the Council. This explains why some countries have little appetite to create an exclusively European DGS. Why make a European pot of money when countries deal with it so differently? I think that as rapporteur of EDIS is a very legitimate question, but I think we should get out of this because at the end of the day we are better off in Europe with a solution and not a deadlock. As rapporteur, I have therefore also proposed a system that leaves responsibility for the national DGS first and then regulates the solidarity of a European DGS. I therefore have a very specific question for the President of the ECB, who has always been a strong supporter of EDIS. What do you prefer at the moment: a cautious start to the report as proposed in ECON or wait for the next Parliament to deal with this difficult issue?

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank President Draghi for being here and the rapporteur, Mr Mato, for the positive work he has done in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Without going into the details of the report, I would like to stress the importance of debating and adopting this report on the day when Parliament celebrates the twenty years of the euro, a work of integration that is not only significant economic and monetary, but in some ways truly unprecedented.  The euro is undoubtedly a success in European history, but it is also an incomplete construction. The incompleteness of monetary and banking union with the lack of a fully European deposit guarantee system and the lack of a social and fiscal arm of monetary union with its own budget are the most visible and critical weaknesses. Some people in this House and outside turn their noses up when they hear these assessments, almost getting up, if I may put it that way, at the end of austerity, underestimating that solidarity and responsibility go hand in hand. There is never enough national responsibility for them. In too many circumstances, every time, further steps have been added to be taken, creating and soothing internal divisions within the Union, as a result, we are still, twenty years after the creation of the euro, discussing at technical level Edis, the eurozone budget, social rights and I will stop.  And the spirit in which we conducted the debate on the ECB's annual report in the ECON Committee is this, aware of the fundamental role that the institution that you, President Draghi, preside over, has played very well. I therefore appeal to my parliamentary colleagues, to European leaders, not least in the light of the disappointing outcome of the last European Council in December. The extraordinary monetary policy measures put in place by the ECB have safeguarded the resilience of the eurozone, but our fellow citizens have nevertheless suffered from the crisis, Europe has not been able and still cannot respond to the request for protection.  What can we do? First of all, I believe that we must follow up our words with deeds, that is to say, let us not close ourselves off in the national fences.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Draghi, ten years ago the financial crisis arose. The crisis got out of hand in Europe because of too much debt and too cheap money. And what is the ECB's response? Even more debt and even more cheaper money. As we read in this report, this has major consequences. Insurance and pensions are getting into trouble. Property prices are rising super fast and houses are becoming unaffordable for ordinary people. We are seeing huge increases in debt from businesses, families and, in particular, governments. Structural reforms in the countries that need them most now are being postponed.  And on top of that, another clear effect of your policy: interest rates are so low that our savings evaporate. It's not going to pay off anymore. You are going to let the common man in the street, the people my age who have nothing to do with the crisis that started in 2008, pay for the mismanagement of the banks and governments. We now face the end of your mandate. For years, you cast yourself as the fireman who extinguished the fire of the crisis. I fear, however, that this policy will turn out to be the policy of a pyromaniac, the policy that is causing the next financial crisis.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr President of the Central Bank, dear rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, as our Parliament draws to a close, we will vote on the Central Bank's report. Happy combination of circumstances, we celebrated this morning the twentieth anniversary of the euro, and it is an emotional moment, Mr Draghi, since this is your last presentation to the European Parliament. The messages of this report are numerous. I think I can say that the European Central Bank has fulfilled its mission more than properly, especially during the second decade. Of course, the European Central Bank cannot do everything, and Member States are called upon themselves to be vigilant about public spending, its control and good direction in the service of citizens and the competitiveness of the economy. The European Central Bank will remain vigilant about many problems: the level of prices in the housing market, the loans made by banks - made intelligently - with a priority given to future investments. I think that the recognized success of the euro is a wonder because, twenty years ago, we created a currency without a state, and it is a unique situation in the world. This is to say how urgent it is to give the euro area the economic, financial, budgetary and social government necessary to fill an original infirmity as soon as possible. While multilateralism is being called into question, and the world economic war is looming, I think it would be good if we had the ambition to make the euro a weapon, as the United States does, namely that it can, in certain circumstances, sanction banks and third-country companies. Ladies and gentlemen, in these times of crisis, the euro and the European Central Bank are making a major contribution to the resilience of the European Union. Euro and the European Central Bank are emblems of our confidence in the future of Europe. But beware, the European Central Bank should not be the crutch of the inadequacies of political governance.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the European Central Bank, with its unconventional measures, has kept the economy of a very unre rationally designed euro area afloat. There are a few things about these measures that need to be seen, elements of democratization. Also, as President Draghi knows, we are concerned about the purchase of carbon-related assets, which do not contribute to the fight against climate change. But these measures have held the European economy afloat. Now what we need to know is whether we will be able to make the reforms we know the eurozone needs to avoid future crises. And we are concerned that there will be a strange coalition between those who do not want to reduce risks and those who do not want to mutualize them that effectively prevents them from doing so reform. We do have to move towards automatic stabilizers; progress is needed towards countercyclical mechanisms at European Union level, with a budget of this name. Without this, the weaknesses of the euro in the future will remain very great, and it is therefore essential to take this leap which the euro must undoubtedly take after its creation, twenty years ago.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the European Central Bank (ECB) has never protected borrowers in distress. They say that that is the job of Member States. But the central banks in many states, including Ireland, have also failed utterly to protect borrowers from repossessions and violent evictions. The Irish Central Bank now warns us that a new wave of mass repossessions is coming. The fact that the EU institutions are legislating on how to deal with non—performing loans (NPLs) could and should be an opportunity to put in place strong protection for borrowers. But we can already see from the Commission and the Council’s approach, that their only interest is to actually restore the massive profits of Europe’s banks. The Commission’s proposal on the secondary market for NPLs will have extreme and, in my view, appalling consequences on mortgage holders. If the ECB won’t protect ordinary people from debt vultures, if the national central banks won’t, if the Commission and Council won’t, then people will rightly ask who will. The Commission’s proposal needs to be scrapped. It is up to us in the European Parliament, alongside civil society, to block its progress.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Mr President, Mr President of the ECB, I would like to thank the President of the ECB for his excellent work and for the work he has done. Their record is not good.
