You were considered a hawk when you started in 2011. That was wrong even then.  Interest rates are at an all-time low. You have not increased it once in your seven-year term. Germany, the euro area's main driver, is facing recession. This will energise the euro area. They no longer have the opportunity to respond with a cut in interest rates.   They have bought billions of dollars of bonds and have greatly expanded the ECB's balance sheet. They have made the poor poorer and the rich richer. They have been driving the most expansionary monetary policy ever. The target balances are completely out of control. Germany has claims of almost one trillion euros, which are likely to be worthless. Your last move now is to play for the rest of your term of office on a temporary basis to leave this heap to your successor.   My hope is that the historians will realise that it is you who is in fact responsible for the economic disaster in the euro area. This disaster will be unheard of in the long run, and you will enjoy your retirement for a long time.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Draghi, today you have celebrated the twenty years since the birth of the single currency, and I believe that this is a good time to draw up a concrete balance sheet, looking at the numbers and evolution of the economies and the living conditions of the citizens of the eurozone, because all this wanting to celebrate, looking at the data, I do not see. All the promises that had been made to the citizens of Europe regarding the birth of the euro have been broken. In these twenty years the euro has brought income and performance divergences between countries, has brought low growth. Today, the eurozone is the continent or agglomeration that grows less than its competitors, and unemployment remains high: today it is twice that of the United States. And even your term as President of the Central Bank has seen you not even achieve the statutory objectives that the ECB has: inflation is running, above all it remains at the stake and far from autonomous sustainability towards 2 %, and the ECB has printed a lot of money that has not reached the real economy. For every hundred euros printed by the European Central Bank, only around 29 have reached households and businesses. Well, I believe that looking at this framework there is very little to celebrate, and it is an important moment of reflection for what have been the failures of the euro and its mandate as President of this Central Bank.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, despite the triumphalisms about the European Union economy, for example the supposed reduction in unemployment by generalizing part-time work, you cannot hide your fears. Anemic growth, slowdown, anisometry, protectionism, trade wars that often get hot with thousands of victims, Brexit, political turmoil and fear of a new worst crisis. This is the European Union and capitalism. Make recommendations-threats: continuation of unpopular reforms, tax exemptions in capital, tax hunting to the people, salaries at the option and profits of capitalists, abolition of collective agreements, survival with crumb allowances and banks that you control with redundancies, for example in Greece at least fifteen thousand bank employees over the next two years. Thousands of auctions-loops in the throats of millions of people or arrangements with a pistol in the head for capital support of banks and for-profit funds, i.e. memoranda generalized and lasting. The false "maintenance or progress" dilemma goes to hide the single strategic coalition of far-right, conservative, social democrat, neo-left-wing Tsipras congratulating Merkel and Trump. The difference is in the organized struggle of the people and in the reinforcement of the communists to overthrow this barbarity.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, I would like first to congratulate President Draghi on the 20th anniversary of the euro and also of the European Central Bank just a few months ago. Contrary to other speakers, I am absolutely convinced that you, President Draghi, can be proud of your leadership. You have been very efficient in fending off the existential crisis that hit the euro area in 2012. Thanks to your determined stance, the euro has survived and now flourishes. Many of these critiques that we heard just a few minutes ago simply give a picture of some ignorance on the part of our colleagues, who unfortunately don’t understand how monetary policy works. That was on the past. Now to the future. We, and especially the ECB, face three important challenges. We have to recall that a slowdown is under way in the European economy and that the next recession is probably around the corner. Is the ECB prepared to face this challenge? What is important is to build room for manoeuvre in monetary policy, because at the zero/lower band interest rate level there is not so much flexibility on the monetary policy side to help the economy. Finally, the question of non-performing loans in the banking sector has to be addressed very quickly.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteurs and President Draghi for their work.  Today, twenty years after the introduction of the euro, this report is one more piece to remind you of the important role that the Central Bank has played in recent years. Despite the nonsense spoken by some of my fellow Members, there is no doubt that strengthening public confidence in the common currency at such a difficult time is an important signal: the fight against deflation, the maintenance of the Union's monetary stability, and the development of the European Banking Union. However, it would also be important for the European Central Bank also to take account of the social repercussions of its policies, as called for in the Paris Agreements. The recent case of banca carige's commissionership in Italy highlights a positive role that the ECB can play and plays in protecting small savers and investors. We must generalise this role, continuing the reasoning that is first and foremost to complete the Banking Union with a deposit guarantee system that is safe and achievable for all. We will be here in Parliament attentive to future progress and results, and we wish you every success in your term of office.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today, Parliament celebrates 20 years of the euro. But what are we actually celebrating? If we are honest, we have to say that the euro has given us one difficulty after another. Let us look, for example, at the sovereign debt crisis: we would never have had a sovereign debt crisis if we had not had the euro. For as long as states have their national currency, they can always service their national debt by printing their own money. We would never have had a banking crisis of this magnitude if we had not had the euro, because the banking crisis came about only because the states were sitting on huge holdings of government bonds, and these government bonds were at risk because the states could no longer print their own money. We would not have had a banking crisis, we would not have had a sovereign debt crisis, and we would not have had mass unemployment – and there would have been enormous youth unemployment almost everywhere in southern Europe. After all, all these difficulties have been broken by the euro. We have nothing to celebrate at the euro. We must work hard to somehow get to grips with all the problems that the euro has piled up. The euro has not lived up to expectations at all, and the euro is actually a completely failed experiment.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Draghi, I speak to you as an Italian, that is, as a citizen of a founding country of the European Union, which I remember is also the third contributing country among the taxpayers of the Union.  Italy has had a primary surplus for twenty-five years, so the story that italians have lived beyond their means is a colossal bale, probably invented by German or French bankers. If we have a deficit every year, it is only because of the interest on a public debt that has grown disproportionately, especially in the 1980s thanks to interest rates of up to 10 %, which is a real bottleneck. In this absurd way, we have reached 2 300 billion in public debt, on which the Italians have so far paid 3 500 billion in interest debt, so once and a half the debt itself. A real scandal. Now European banks buy this public debt, german banks, French banks also buy it and they also buy it with money lent by the ECB at very low interest rates, at very low interest rates and without any conditionality, which has allowed these banks to speculate precisely on those countries with high spreads. But unfortunately they also buy it with money created out of nowhere, simply by adding zeros to the computer.  The problem, however, is that italian citizens pay for them with the real economy, they pay for them with real sweat, not with a sweat invented out of nothing. However, this system seems to please everyone, the banks are happy because they are in fact speculating quietly, bringing their capital back, the states that place their government bonds are satisfied, unfortunately it is the real economy that pays.  It is those small and medium-sized enterprises that pay for the real economy, those companies that no longer have access to credit, and where there is no access to credit, unemployment is rising. Unemployment in the European Union has reached appalling levels precisely in those countries where public debt has grown; I am talking about Greece and Spain and, unfortunately, Italy as well.  Now, if we read Article 127 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is said that, in addition to price stability – you said that this has essentially been achieved – the ECB must contribute to achieving the Union's objectives, namely to combat unemployment and promote balanced economic growth.  So my question is: does the ECB really intend to combat financial speculation? Does the ECB really intend to act in a targeted and differentiated way to eliminate the spreads of individual Member States? Does the ECB really intend to wipe out the spread mechanism that destroys the economy of Member States such as Italy and invariably destroys or irreparably weakens the European Union itself?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. For 20 years of Euros you are currently celebrating yourself. The fact is, however, that imbalances within the euro area are still huge. On the one hand, this is reflected in the target balances, which are still at record levels. This is reflected in the differences in economic development, particularly industrial development in France and Italy, for example. However, this is also reflected in the fact that Germany, for example, is still lagstiating massively in wage developments. The euro area is one of the least economic growth areas in the world in recent years. Even in Africa, we have large parts that have developed better in recent years than the euro area has done. Venezuela is perhaps another example that has developed even worse. This applies precisely to all systems governed by the socialist and planning economic. It is also a fact that we have continued to accumulate public debt and that you, Mr Draghi, are largely responsible for this.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, behind your institutional status, the real culprits in this shadow theatre are your principals and those national leaders who - surrendering to promises, ephemeral benefit and transient cheap money - have surrendered sovereign rights, substantiated citizens' property and sold off national savings. You are a central banker who controls the supply of money but is not in the process of stimulating demand. Responsible for price stability but not for the soundness of the economy, maximising healthy employment and boosting wages and purchasing power. You have offered everything for a union by cheque and for the sole benefit of Germany and its satellites. For a Germany that, since 2008, has, thanks to your low borrowing rates, save EUR 368 billion. Each of your actions demonstrates the distortions of the construction of political and discriminatory decisions: a central bank of an imperfect union with limited responsibilities and in the absence of mandates.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr Draghi, ladies and gentlemen, this afternoon we celebrated the 20th anniversary of the euro, but not so long ago the survival of our single currency was really hanging by a thread. In the end, it was the European Central Bank, which, to the regret of many critics here in the Chamber, guided our euro through the crisis. Why was it the European Central Bank that had to remove the chestnuts from the fire? Before a single currency is created, political and economic integration is normally the first to be implemented. The euro has taken the exact opposite path. We threw the newborn euro in the pool and he will learn to swim by himself, but that has not happened, or not quite, and that makes our currency union very vulnerable even today, because the economic differences between Member States are still very large. Such differences are difficult to maintain unless sufficient solidarity mechanisms are built in, but that is not the case for the time being.  So why did the ECB have to save the euro? Because there has been a lack of political courage to finish our currency union. Today, the economic outlook is a little gloomier again. We are faced with the choice: either we complete monetary union so that it is able to withstand the next crisis, or let the ECB do the work again. For me, the choice is very clear: allow me to invite colleagues who have not spared the ECB's rod this afternoon and who have gone beyond its books, to join the cart and to create a currency union with sufficient solidarity mechanisms, including in the area of fiscal policy and a deep banking and capital markets union.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the report on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank states how the EU economy grew in 2017 at the fastest rate in 10 years and unemployment was at its lowest level since 2008. At the same time, attention is paid to uncertainties, one of which is the continued indebtedness of households. Often indebtedness is caused by quick-cut ones, the actual annual interest rate of which can reach hundreds, in the most blatant cases up to thousands of percentage points. Old loans are paid out by taking out new loans, which can lead to years of debt in custody. Over-indebtedness is a personal tragedy, with the result that relationships, health and the general quality of life suffer. The activities of fast-track companies are not about helping customers, but about exploiting their financial plight. I have long been calling for greater consumer protection for those who have fallen into quick-releases. The most effective way to tackle this harmful business would be to ban it altogether. I hope to have broad support for the quick-button ban.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, let me admire you. That's a lot of nerve! On the eve of a financial crisis expected by all the specialists, you come and tell us that everything is fine.  You should have known - and you know - that a federal budget was needed for the euro. Since no one wanted this budget, you had a possibility, which was to use the Central Bank, which Mr Maystadt had also proposed, the President of the BPI and the Italian Deposit Fund, to finance the real economy of the countries of the South and reduce the disparity. This policy, in 2012, the Germans did not want it. Today, you got away with buying $2.6 trillion in public debt and cancelling rates. The result is more debt, less wealth creation and more deficit. It's a bankruptcy!

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Draghi, the euro area needs immediate changes. We need to abolish the draconian Stability Pact and abandon austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. The ECB must become the ultimate lender of the Member States and the European System of Central Banks must be decentralised, Member States should regain their monetary sovereignty, and the central banks of the Member States should be able to pursue an independent monetary policy up to the amount corresponding to their shareholding in the capital of the ECB. The ECB must stop serving German Europe, a Europe in which Germany accumulates trade surpluses and the European South has increased deficits and debts. Finally, Mr Draghi, the ECB and you personally must apologise to the poor Greek people, to whom, as a troika, you have idly idyxed memoranda in order to rescue foreign banks, as Mr Dijsselbloem himself has confessed.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the ECB has pumped EUR 4 000 billion into the euro area economy in recent years. An amount greater than germany's gross national product. All that cheap money was good for countries like Italy and France, which helped to implement real reforms. But now they still face high public debt, high unemployment and high youth unemployment.  That cheap money is also pleasant for the banks, but these low interest rates have put pension funds in trouble and, unfortunately, saving has become pointless. THE ECB policy has been too soft and too generous, which is why I fear that we will soon be presented with a hefty bill as economic growth slows. I call on the government to really reform now. And not in the form of a transfer union, but more efficient governments, fairer taxation and investment in people and sustainability.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the huge burden of more than 650 lawsuits and lawsuits of various kinds that have been brought by various parties, not just banks, towards the single resolution authority and the various European institutions involved in the supervision and management of banking crises, is a very serious matter, which should concern us all. I would like to draw your attention to this issue, which is not being addressed, despite the alarm raised very clearly by the European Court of Auditors, which has in fact counted the extent of the potential liabilities that are in the hands of the European financial system as a result of the resolution procedures in banks at risk of bankruptcy. Do you not think that this has a very heavy and very important impact on the credibility of both the Resolution Committee and the European Commission and the European Council? We need to speak out and say things as they are when we are addressing those of us who represent the real people and therefore, as has been said very well, the real economy that you have slaughtered.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, in my introductory remarks I recalled the constructive engagement that has developed between the European Parliament and the European Central Bank over the past years, and the large convergence of views in many aspects of Mr Mato’s report shows that this continues to be the case. However, in my concluding remarks let me come back to a point which was also highlighted in the report: the need for financial integration, amongst others things, to improve the transmission of a monetary policy. And this brings me to the topic of the Capital Markets Union and completion of the banking union. But there I would point out that out of the 30 legislative proposals which the Commission has put out on the Capital Markets Union, only three proposals have been adopted, and there is political agreement on a further two. So, therefore, we count on your continued support for the Capital Markets Union project, which would lead to deeper and better-connected capital markets and thus also foster the international standing of the euro.

name: Mario Draghi
text: President of the European Central Bank. – Mr President, first of all, I thank the rapporteur, honourable Member, Mr Mato, for his report. I certainly thank you for all the compliments the ECB has received and I will respond to the criticisms. First of all, about the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS). The ECB has always been a supporter of EDIS, of the insurance. I want just to make three points about that. First of all, whatever the road is to EDIS, the final goal of having a fully mutualised EDIS should always remain in sight. Now the road to that goal is not going to be simple, we all know that. And so various steps and delays and compromises and negotiations are necessary. But the direction and the sense of final results should always be present. So what you decide about how to move ahead, will be really in your own judgment. The important thing is that, whatever you decide, we’ll never compromise over the final outcome. The third point I want to make about EDIS is that there is no clear progress on this road unless there is convincing risk reduction everywhere. By the way, big progress has been achieved on that front already but more needs to be done. The ECB has shown in various places on various occasions that risk sharing also itself contributes to risk reduction, so the two arms of this journey towards the final goal of a fully—neutralised insurance system should go hand in hand.  Several questions addressed the economic effects of the policy of the ECB. Comparisons were made with non—euro parts of the world and with before the euro – how the world was beautiful, fantastic, before the euro. I’ve gone through these comparisons in a recent speech I gave. It was not fantastic, especially for the countries that complain most today about the euro; it was not fantastic at all before the euro. Let me make a comparison with the United States, because someone raised that point. The employment rate in 1998 in the euro area at 19 was 59.8%, now it’s 67.3% – the highest ever in the euro area. In the United States, it was 73.9% in 1998, today it’s 70.6% so it went down, not up.  The jobs created in the euro area over this period of time have been 19.8 million. And the jobs created in the United States were 17.2 million. Of course we have to be careful about making these comparisons because the units have to be standardised and the same thing we get on the employment numbers, in millions. So when I’m asked about the side effects of our monetary policy in the euro area, the response is that the main side effect between 2013 – when the situation was at its worst – and today, has been the creation of 9.6 million jobs, which is more than ever. That’s the main side effect.  Other questions related to the presence of financial stability risks. Well, it’s true that in certain localised areas over the euro area we observed that valuations are stretched in prime commercial real estate. Also in some areas of some countries in the residential real estate, in some segments of the bond market. But are any of these risks prone to generate systemic financial stability risk? The answer that we give so far is no. But of course we monitor all this very carefully. And the answer to these local situations cannot be a change in monetary policy. It has to be the use of macroprudential tools by the national governments. We’ve said this and, in fact, national governments have indeed responded, with their national instruments together with the ECB. More generally, some questions addressed the role of the ECB and very rightly, as observed by the rapporteur, the ECB has its role but cannot fill all the roles that everybody else should fill. The ECB has a role which is limited to monetary policy, which is circumscribed by its mandate. It cannot do everybody else’s job. In this sense, as I have said on a variety of occasions including this morning, not all its benefits have accrued to all the members of the euro area. Why is that? Because of two main reasons. Reforms are necessary in these countries whether they belong to the euro, or are outside the euro. You have got to make the reforms that are necessary. There is not a blueprint which is the same for all countries. It does change from country to country; each country has its own history. And so that’s the basic thing: no reforms, no growth. But then there are also problems, also incompleteness in the Economic and Monetary Union. And the first incompleteness is to finish the things that had been decided already, namely the banking union. The second is to start to move fast on the capital markets union and the third is to build fiscal capacity. But if you do the first two things – and the European Parliament has really carried out a very positive and constructive role at each and every point in time of this discussion – if these two things are done, we are way better, even if the next steps on the creation of the fiscal capacity may take longer for pretty obvious political difficulties. There was one question about what the ECB could do about certain specific loans that banks have lent to citizens. Generally, the ECB cannot do anything about that, it’s the national competent authority. Very often, these issues are a consumer protection issue, so it’s the national consumer protection authority that has to monitor the conditions of lending. But generally speaking – and this holds true also in other countries where the non—performing loans (NPLs) problem is really very dramatic because of its social consequences – in non—performing loans you always have two types of debtors: the ones who are normal or even strategic debtors and the ones who are part of a big social problem. For these problems, the response is not to change the payments culture but rather to help the poor people who cannot pay back. One should keep the two things separate. Don’t change, don’t affect, don’t damage, don’t harm your banking system, your financial system because the result of this will only be that they will not be able to lend as much as they could to the private sector of your economy, but rather help the poor people who cannot pay.  Now, one question that has been asked from several sides is if we are heading towards the next recession – and I will say something about that in a moment – does the ECB have the tools to address this? The answer is yes. The ECB has the tools to address this but keep in mind that our present monetary policy stance is very accommodative already. We have negative interest rates and they are expected to be like this for an extended period of time. And, even though we have decided to stop the net asset purchases, we also decided that the current stock will stay what it is for a considerable period of time. What does it mean? It means that, as bonds come to maturity, we repurchase the bonds. What does it mean in terms of numbers? It means that we will continue buying, by and large – at least this year or the next year – 15 billion euros of bonds a month, which was, by and large, what we had been buying in the last 3 months of last year.  There was perhaps more than one question about whether our monetary policy has helped equity. We went into some depth in trying to understand what the effects are of monetary policy on the distribution of income, distribution of wealth. It’s quite clear that each monetary policy decision has distributional effects. When we change interest rates we change distribution between creditors and debtors, or between young and old. But certainly the asset purchases, the quantitative easing (QE), have distributional impacts which are even more visible and direct because asset prices go up and the owners of assets are usually the wealthy ones.  So the question we ask ourselves is, is our policy worsening the distribution? If you consider all the effects, the answer is no. Why is that? It is true that it worsens the distribution in the short term. However, what is the factor that worsens the distribution more than any other factor? It’s the unemployment. Where the monetary policy of the ECB has been a success was in fostering strong employment growth, as I presented at the beginning of this response.  One question addressed the point of access by SMEs to credit. Has our policy prevented, restrained, or shrunk access by SMEs to credit? The answer is absolutely no. Both our corporate bond programme and our QE programme created space in the bank’s balance sheet for lending more to the SMEs. All data since 2013, since even when we started with the longer—term refinancing operations (LTROs) – by the way the LTROs are not unconditional lending – and the targeted longer—term refinancing operations (TLTROs), is lending to banks on condition they lend to firms, to the real economy. I don’t know where the fairy tale thing about EUR 29 out of a hundred actually came from.  In terms of another interesting irony of some of the questions, was that one hears that monetary financing of the deficit is now the solution to all problems. That’s one of the questions that was raised before. That is actually interesting. First of all, because when monetary financing was available, for the countries that actually vastly used monetary financing before the euro, the situation was very bad. They got very high inflation and they got unemployment higher than countries that did not use monetary financing. What is actually quite paradoxical is that you hear this solution of monetary financing from people who were against monetary financing as an utmost crime until yesterday.  I think I have responded to most of the problems, and now one word about the outlook. If we take a snapshot of the situation as it is today, statically, we still see a situation where consumption is still expanding, relatively strong, investment still expanding, supported by our monetary policy, export growth is less, but still good. And the labour market keeps on being very strong.  However, all this is happening at lower and lower growth rates. And we have been receiving weaker data than expected now for a longer time than we had expected a few months ago. In other words, at the beginning we had lower data and we said – and we continue to say, by the way – that some of this weaker momentum was due to temporary factors, and specific to sectors and certain countries. For example, what happened to the car industry; this is one example which is a temporary drop. But then we also said that there are also some more permanent causes of this slowing—down. And the causes of this slowing—down are going to stay. One of which is simply that 2017 was a pretty exceptional year when compared with historical averages. And so we return to a lower growth path.  But then the question that we should ask is, first of all, is this what is called a sag or is it heading towards a recession? And the answer we give is no, it’s a slowdown, which is not heading towards a recession, but it could be longer than was expected before. And on what does the length of this slowdown depend? To answer this question we have to go back and ask ourselves what are the factors that originally caused this weakening in growth. And the factors deal primarily with some slowdown in China, of course, but with what we call geopolitical uncertainties. And here, the natural question to ask is how long will these geopolitical uncertainties last. These geopolitical uncertainties put into question the pillars upon which the order, that was built after the Second World War, was constructed. And they put into question the European Union. They have to do with Brexit. They have to do with trade tensions with China. They have to do with the denial of the multilateral system. And we notice, however, that some of these things get better and some others get worse.  The result of this, however, is that, at least for some time to come, there’s going to be a continuing uncertainty that changes nature, and this has a cost. And the cost is lower confidence – lower business confidence and lower consumer confidence. That’s why we are now assessing the situation, as I said. My impression is, Mr President, that I have responded to all questions. If I missed someone I apologise.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to reiterate to you, Mr Draghi, that I am pleased with your presence here, even though today it has resulted in it becoming almost more of an appearance than in the analysis of the 2017 annual report. But that's all right with me. And I would like to thank, of course, for your appreciation of the work that this Parliament is doing. I hope you set your example! I would also like to thank Vice-President Dombrovskis for his positive analysis of the report. And of course, thanks to the colleagues who have intervened. Also to those whose positions I do not share. I do agree with Mr Draghi that we must not be complacent and that we must strengthen our capacity to adapt and provide ourselves with tools to deal with new crises. We already have experience in crisis. Let's not make the same mistakes. True, we have a stronger monetary union, but there are some outstanding issues left. Here some have been highlighted, the SEGD, delinquent credits and others also important that we have to deal with decision. I also share that reducing risks and sharing risks should go hand in hand. And I'm done. I want to remember the importance of not conforming and moving on. I would therefore like to highlight two points which have been included in the report with the almost unanimous support of this Parliament: the importance of continuing to move towards greater financial integration through the union of capital markets, which will help the good transmission of monetary policy and ensure greater stability in the euro area; the need to meet sustainability objectives in the context of monetary policies — the ECB is under the Paris Agreement and, like all European institutions, has to support the fulfilment of the stated objectives; and finally, I would like to acknowledge something that Mr Draghi has also highlighted: the ECB's work on transparency to improve the communication of its policies, especially given that the ECB has absolute independence in the conduct of its monetary policy, as set out in the Treaties. The accountability triangle, greater transparency and independence is key.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 January 2019.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on nils Torvalds' report on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the Banking Union - Annual Report 2018 (2018/2100(INI)) (A8-0419/2018).

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his I am sorry that Mr Draghi is leaving us precisely in this discussion because it really concerns him as well. I am a little concerned when I listen to the previous discussion for the reason that it appeared that some of my colleagues would not really remember what history really looked like in the decades after the Second World War. If you look at the economic development from 1945 onwards, you could say that it perhaps consisted mainly of a lot of devaluations. So financial mistakes were repaired by going down that road. This was the case for Finland. That was also the case for others. You may remember that Britain was still in great difficulty around 1956, and from 1956 onwards we see that the problems of monetary, monetary policy are only increasing and increasing. At some stage, a young Social Democratic politician took to the stage. It was Willy Brandt. He had just been elected Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, and when I read what he wrote at the time, I have a faint feeling that he was quite led by the council and the inability to solve the economic problems that could be seen in Europe. He therefore proposed that the European states, the EU Member States, should solve the problems by creating a European Monetary Fund, and he offered twenty per cent of their currency surplus espart for Germany to create, as it were, a nest egg for future solutions. There were, of course, conditions in this nest egg. One condition was that we should learn to stick to the rules, and this is where the difficulties arose. I find a rather interesting quote in Willy Brandt's memoir "Begegnungen und Einsichten": Our iron-fisted rules on the parallelity of our currency economic decisions have always come true. He says this in German if you want to hear the original: "Unsere Eisenregeln der Parallelität von Währungs- und Wirtschaftspolitische Massnahmen war immerhin bestworden". This is what happened after Mr Brandt's initiative for ten or twenty years of increasing and increasing problems in the European banking world, in European monetary policy, and at some stage the politicians are minding and creating what we have today celebrated the 20th anniversary of. Today, then, we have a much more robust system than we have ever had before. Is that system waterproof? Does it hold for all the trials? We know that's not true. During the crisis of 2007 and 2008, we saw that the system did not quite hold up to all the trials of European banking policy at that time. After that, however, we have actually created reasonably functioning rules. Anyone who follows economic policy in recent years can see that Banco Popular – a Spanish bank that failed to meet its obligations – was simply dissolved by our current rules. And we have another example that also speaks volumes: Banca Carige from Genoa has, of course, been brought under the administration of the European Central Bank. So we have many problems, we have loans that are not repaid, we have a lot of other problems, but at least today we are in a far better position than we were ten or fifteen, not to mention 50 years ago.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Mr Torvalds for his annual report on the banking union. The report provides us with an excellent account of how the banking union has helped foster a single market and contributed to creating a level playing field and financial stability. Much has been achieved since its inception in terms of the overhaul of the regulatory and supervisory framework for financial institutions. But the work is not complete yet. Completion of the banking union is one of the Commission’s priorities, and we very much welcome the fact that the report also underlines a continued commitment towards this goal. Since last year’s debate, I am pleased to say that we have made some tangible progress. Firstly, we have an agreement on the so—called banking package. Gunnar Hökmark and Peter Simon negotiated this on behalf of the Parliament. The banking package will strengthen the prudential framework and increase banks’ ability to absorb losses in times of crisis without the need for taxpayers’ money. The technical work aimed at its finalisation is ongoing, and we look forward to early completion so that Parliament may still have the final word before the recess.  Secondly, significant progress has been made in the implementation of the action plan adopted by the Council in July 2017 to tackle non—performing loans (NPLs), including through the adoption by the Commission of a number of proposals and communications. Under Roberto Gualtieri and Esther de Lange’s rapporteurship, you have reached a very quick agreement with the Council on the prudential backstop to prevent the accumulation of non—performing loans in the future. Recent data has shown that in 2018, bank capital and liquidity positions continued to improve, and bank leverage decreased while loss absorption capacity improved. At the same time, NPLs on bank balance sheets have continued to decline and MREL buffers are being built up. The Commission is encouraged to see that NPL ratios have fallen in nearly all Member States, facilitated by determined actions by banks and policymakers. But at the same time, the different levels of NPLs among Member States must be further addressed and the NPL Action Plan should be fully implemented.  Thirdly, a number of money laundering scandals involving European banks surfaced in 2018, and the Commission came forward with a legislative proposal, as well as an accompanying communication, on strengthening the Union’s framework for prudential and anti-money laundering supervision. Our proposals are part of the wider package of measures that will strengthen the three European supervisory authorities and their anti—money laundering tools. I welcome the position which Parliament has just adopted on the basis of report by Pervenche Berès and Othmar Karas. I count on your full support to conclude negotiations on the legislative proposal before the end of this legislature.  Bank exposure to sovereigns is another area where the Commission shares Parliament’s view that this is a problem with significant implications. In 2018, the Commission also presented a proposal for a regulatory framework for sovereign bond—backed securities, with the aim of further reducing the link between banks and their respective sovereigns.  Regarding think tanks, the Commission fully agrees with the need to ensure a level playing field between market participants, while supporting the uptake of innovative technologies in the financial sector. This has been reflected in our communication on Fintech, which took the form of an action plan and covered a number of initiatives to strengthen, among other things, cyber resilience.  But, as I mentioned, despite all the steps forward, we are not yet there. More needs to be done on the common backstop for a single resolution fund and a European deposit insurance scheme (EDIS). I very much welcome that the report recognises the importance of continued work on these proposals. As regards the common backstop, we are making progress. The agreement, reached in December 2013 at the Euro Summit, must now be swiftly implemented into ESM treaty change, hopefully by the middle of this year. Going forward, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), as a backstop provider, should be integrated into the Union framework. This will enhance the democratic scrutiny of its activities.  We are unfortunately less advanced on the establishment of EDIS, which is the essential third pillar of the banking union, so I urge you to finalise the report under Esther de Lange’s rapporteurship before the elections to show Parliament’s support for this project. I also urge you to look at the banking union as an initiative that benefits all Europeans. We have achieved a lot since the crisis broke out, with a real positive impact on businesses and households. At the same time, we will be held accountable for the risks entailed by an unfinished banking union. So let us use the remaining time in this political cycle effectively and make tangible progress towards completing the banking union.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, my thanks to the rapporteur and the Commissioner. Today when we are celebrating 20 years of the euro it is important to see how much things have changed recently. Financial markets are about analysing risks, taking risks and distributing risks, and by the different steps and cornerstones of the banking union, we have today a better opportunity to analyse risks. That is one of the advantages of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD), but also the establishment of supervisory authorities. We have provided a more secure framework in which to take risks; but there will always be crises. The question is how are we to deal with them, and how capable are we of getting out of them? The establishment of both a backstop and better legislation, hopefully, coming out on the non-performing loans will be a part of that, and the BRRD as such also clarifies that all those who invest in a bank are taking a risk. And then we come to distributing risk, because the legislation we now have in place with capital requirements and a BRRD establishes a very good precondition for the economy of the European Union to face new upcoming crises and come out of them in better shape than we have previously been able to do. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Commission. It is true that we still have a lot more to do, but let’s not underestimate how much we have achieved.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, thank you very much, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, for being here.  First of all, nils Torvalds, as rapporteur for this report, should be thanked for his collaborative spirit, and the other rapporteurs for the effort we have made to reach this agreement, to this text of agreement which we vote on tomorrow.  In any case, I would like to point out that these reports in which we assess the functioning of the banking union are timely, necessary, but it is key to be able to complete the institutional framework of the banking union at once.  This Parliament has made a great effort in this parliamentary term and, in particular, in recent months to deal with risk reduction packages — the banking package, the Regulations to regulate failed appropriations - but we need additional effort in recent months to be able to finish designing deposit insurance for the whole banking union , to ensure a product — that securitisation of public debt — that is a secure public bond and also a safeguard mechanism, an endorsement, for the Single Resolution Fund.  We have taken steps," as I said, to reduce the risks, but we have the steps to share them ahead of us.  And that is why I dare to ask this Parliament to be able to take advantage of these four months, to be able to negotiate , as we can - to finish having that deposit insurance, those other instruments so necessary for the banking union to work and not have to live crises like the one we have experienced in the last decade.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I thank the rapporteur for a balanced and balanced report, which contains the comments of all the factions. I appreciate that the importance of risk reduction and at the same time increasing financial stability is emphasised. I am pleased that the report sets out to maintain the diversity of stable banking models and to prevent the emergence of a monolithic European banking system. The rapporteur rightly draws attention to cases of money laundering and the still high share of non-performing loans and the size of the parabanking system set at the end of 2017 at around 40% of the value of the European banking system. The Polish delegation in the ECR Group will support the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the question that should be raised here is whether or not we have a financial system capable of solving the problems of the economy and the truth is that the same financial system remains a problem for the European Union rather than a solution. We remain concerned about the cleanup of banks' assets without questioning the mechanisms that led to the speculative spiral that underwent the financial crisis. Over the course of this year we have had a make-up of the bank accounts with the Basel 3 ratios, but the truth is that leverage levels remain very high. We have had mergers and acquisitions that have formed mega-banks that will create huge problems in the future and in the final stretch, governments have finally been able to put governments, through the European Stability Mechanism, at the service of the Single Resolution Fund, that is, more public funds for banks and this, of course, reinforces our conviction that only public control of the financial system can put banks at the service of the economy.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, for the French patriots, the federalist directive of the banking union is totalitarian and anti-democratic legislation. Totalitarian because, since November 2014, the Member States have lost their banking sovereignty to the ECB, which is absent today. This supranational institution, independent of any state, does not submit to any real democratic control. With the transfer of political power to the unelected technocrats in Frankfurt, our national political leaders have committed the grave fault of cutting the organic link between the state and its banking system, making states totally powerless. In the next major systemic shock or a major financial market crash, bank deposits and customer savings in their banks will be plundered.  In a euro area where financial globalism exposes the banking system to a risk of permanent insolvency, the federalist directive of the banking union is extremely dangerous for the financial and socio-economic stability of European countries. In the name of democracy and the general interest of citizens, we must urgently put an end to this European aberration of the banking union and repatriate the supervisory power of our banks at the strictly national level, and therefore to the peoples.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thanks to the rapporteur. He has largely taken over the positions of the PPE-DE. I would like to express my thanks for a good report.  We have just heard the last two speakers: the representative of the GUE and the representative of the EFDD. Both have tabled amendments. The GUE wants to dissolve the banking union and the EFDD wants exceptions for Italy. If we get this far, if we see this as a solution, then we can pack up here right away.  I would not only like to thank the rapporteur, but also to say where we were focused. Anyone who has dealt with the banking crisis knows that it was the greed and lack of regulation that led to this huge banking crisis, and nothing else. The greed of the industry! We have adopted more than 30 legislative proposals, and I would like to thank the Commission for proposing them, even though it has taken time to implement them in the Council.  For us, it is important: firstly, proportionality between small and large banks. In America, there is regulation for Wall Street – the big ones – and for Mainstreet – for the small. We have not yet achieved this in Europe. Secondly, the fight against money laundering will only be successful if it is implemented by the Member States. Thirdly, problem loans must be further reduced. We are in agreement on this. Fourthly, the diversity of EU banking models must not be called into question. My impression was that this is being tried again and again, especially in the example of Germany. The final point is the Deposit Guarantee Scheme. This is only responsible when the risks are reduced, and that has nothing to do with the end of the parliamentary term.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I believe that we are looking at a very useful report on the state of the banking union here. You have already mentioned a number of points, and I would like to point out how essential the proper functioning of this banking union is to the very functioning of our economy. I would like to draw your attention to two messages. The first message is that we need to go further. As you mentioned, the issue of the fight against money laundering obliges in particular to strengthen the European Banking Authority - that is the choice you have made and this Parliament has supported you - so that it becomes a real pool with the other supervisory authorities, to make the fight against money laundering a decisive factor. This will only be possible with a review of the governance of the supervisory authorities, and we hope that the Commission will fully support us in the mandate given to us by a large majority of our competent committee.  The second message I would like to make here relates to this famous debate between risk reduction and risk-sharing, because we have the impression that sometimes some Member States, some Members of this Parliament, have the capacity to exercise the gradual slippage of requirements in a way that is completely unacceptable. The European deposit insurance system has been part of the banking union since day one. We therefore have a requirement: what has been done for risk reduction, under the pressure of time and at the request of a number of Member States, must be accompanied, in a way, by what is due, namely this commitment to the European deposit insurance system. On this point, we are also counting on the Commission's determination to move forward.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mario Draghi said in this House a year ago that EDIS, the common deposit guarantee, would be an indispensable pillar of monetary union. As Mr Fernandez has pointed out, Mr Langen has highlighted the risks. I say that the common deposit guarantee does not make the banking union safer, but more uncertain. Firstly, we have the risks in the banks that are already there, which can also be retouched by bank balance sheet tricks, as we all know. Second, Mr Draghi is again producing bad loans by forcing banks to take risks they would not normally take. And thirdly, we have the moral hazard problem. Aristotle has already said that if everyone is responsible, in reality no one is responsible. Or as the vernacular says, when others pay the bill, you like to drink you over the thirst. In other words, we will not make the banking union safer, but will bring contagion effects into the banking union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, eleven years ago the start of the financial crisis, and the great reform of the banking system that was being announced has failed. Europe is no longer protected from a future financial crisis today. The banking union is pushing for a growing concentration of the sector, where small and medium-sized banks are devoured by the big ones. This situation of progressive oligopoly is difficult not to guarantee that any bank will not be saved with public money. The European Central Bank acts as the most ruthless of private banks, pressuring banking to dispose of its low-quality assets, leaving its clients in the hands of vulture funds. Consumer protection and access to housing are the supervisory body's latest concerns. Gentlemen, we need a stable financial system under democratic and popular control. Unfortunately, the banking union clearly takes us in the opposite direction. We're no better prepared. We continue to defend banking against people.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry that Mr Langen has left. large stocks of non-performing loans. And I am sorry that very often the ECB, which perhaps takes suggestions from some private banks through its supervisory mechanism, as has also recently been published in the press in Germany, by BlackRock during its assessments and in stress tests, could, in my opinion, be more sensitive to such an issue. In Germany, France and so on, banks have received hundreds of billions in public money to save their banking systems. Italy is making great efforts: it has reduced non-performing loans a great deal in the last year and I think it is appropriate to have a little sensitivity and respect for those who are doing things at the moment to avoid, precisely, creating much greater problems for the whole of Europe.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Sch I agree that we have made very good progress in building the Banking Union, but I would also like to point out that we have been building it for almost 7 years and it is still an infinite construction. I would like to draw attention to three elements which, in my opinion, are crucial for it to finally become operational to its full potential. Firstly, we must complete the process of subsidising the restructuring and liquidation fund. This is an issue that has been going on for years. We have projects to transform the European Stability Mechanism into such an instrument of support for banks. You have to finish it as soon as possible. Colleagues have said before that we do not still have a European deposit guarantee scheme – this is also an essential element. Finally, the third thing: we are not coping with an excess of bad loans – loans that are partially lost. This is a huge burden that can make it difficult for us to recover from the crisis (Mr President, I have one minute thirty seconds) or from the next recession.  I encourage everyone, both the European Commission and the Member States, to speed up work on completing the Banking Union.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, ten years after the financial crisis, it is the right time to look at this issue and to pay significant tribute to all the European institutions for their management of the banking crisis and for bringing about a banking union. I am grateful to the Commission's demands and measures to promote the completion of the Banking Union during this parliamentary term, at least with an understanding at political level.  We lack three factors in addition to managing a bad loan base for over-indebted people. We do not yet have a proper firewall between risk investments and basic banking. The legislation on the so-called Liikanen report was halfway left in all the institutions.  The second point is sustainable financing, i.e. the including of environmental indicators in banks' activities and loans. And the third factor that I also read into the banking union is how we regulate other actors, such as peer-to-peer loans and crowdfunding, so that these actors are subject to the same standards from the consumer's point of view and do not pose any greater risk to small investors or operators than the banking sector. These will remain for the next parliamentary term and for the Commission and Parliament to resolve.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to ensure financial stability, it is necessary to continue towards the completion of the Banking Union by taking measures to reduce banking risks. The objective of the Banking Union is, in addition to ensuring financial stability, to preserve the diversity of the European Union's sustainable banking models, avoiding leading the European banking system itself towards a single or penalising model for small banks, because this diversity makes it possible to better meet the demands of citizens and their projects. The response times of European banking supervision need to be improved, in particular a common EU approach to anti-money laundering rules in the Banking Union is needed, clearly assigning competences and strengthening the action of the European Banking Authority. Finally, I make no secret of my concern about the spread of the so-called shadow banking system in the European Union, which now accounts for 40 % of the Eu ropean financial system. On these points, I call on the Commission to help fill as a matter of urgency the gaps that still exist in the regulations in force.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we are discussing the Banking Union, in which the European Central Bank plays an important role in overseeing systemic banks. Yet Mr Draghi, who was here, departed. He did not stay in this debate to listen to the European Parliament's comments, although he said he was interested in consultation. However, on red loans, he said that, in practice, the European Central Bank could do nothing. And yet, he, as the European Central Bank, is pushing the banks in Greece in order to sell off the red loans, to sell them to the "crows" at a price such that, of course, it is too cheap and then the "crows" to grab the homes of the Greeks, while there is a solution to this issue. There is a solution, which we have proposed: the creation of a borrowers' rescue fund, so that Greeks do not lose their homes. Unfortunately, Mr Draghi did not stay here to listen to our concerns and to be able to have specific directions. He's made his own decisions on red loans.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make my speech on, ladies and gentlemen, your irresponsibility. Irresponsibility, because at a time when banks no longer lend to each other, when the markets no longer trust the banks, you want to make the European banking union. Irresponsibility, because you do not want to recognize that it is the monetary union that creates the responsible debt because it is always the other who will pay. Irresponsibility also, because now it is the citizen who will pay because we come out of the lease-out to enter the lease-in, so it is the citizens themselves who will pay.  Behind this irresponsibility, there is only one responsibility: to take matters into our own hands at the national level and to renationalise central banks in order to cope with the crisis to come.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you once again, and thank you, Mr Torvalds, for your excellent report. I listened attentively to the Members’ interventions. The debate shows that we continue to agree on the importance of the banking union and the regulatory and supervisory frameworks which allow banks to contribute to economic growth, while ensuring the financial system is sound and stable. From the Commission side, we believe it crucial to keep making progress on the files on the table in the area of financial services – including in the last term before the elections. We also count on you to help secure tangible progress to complete the banking union, the capital markets union and, ultimately, a strong economic and monetary union – resilient and strong enough to withstand any future crisis.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Today's discussion has shown that we are actually quite in agreement on the conditions for how to proceed with the banking union. We all agree that we need a deposit guarantee. Perhaps the most important thing was that we managed to find a formulation in which we got a little out of the old trenches between the various political parties. We therefore agree that we need a more sustainable system in order to meet the challenges ahead. Nevertheless, I would like to replicate to my colleague Mr Viegas, who was concerned about the levers in the banking world. If we look at the levers in the banking world, we see that they have gone down sharply in recent years. On this point too, we can also refer to great successes. Finally, I shall conclude by thanking my colleagues, my shadows as it is called, for a very constructive work. At the same time, I am pleased that the discussion we had in this Chamber was also, for the most part, a particularly substantive discussion showing the way forward, showing that Parliament is prepared to take the steps that the Commission has been calling for for so long. I would already like to thank Commissioner Dombrovskis in advance for the proposals we can eventually wait from the Commission to move forward.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 January 2019.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by José Manuel Fernandes and Roberto Gualtieri on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing the InvestEU programme. (COM(2018)0439 - C8-0257/2018 - 2018/0229(COD)) (A8-0482/2018).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to greet you, I would like to greet all my colleagues and tell them that in good time we have moved forward for this InvestEU which brings together thirteen financial instruments. It will simplify and make it possible to fill market failures. This InvestEU has four windows, in the area of infrastructure, research and innovation, of small and medium-sized enterprises and also in the social area. It is a continuation to which other financial instruments of the Juncker plan of the European Fund for Strategic Investments are added. Some had doubts, but today it is proven that it is a programme that has helped some 1.2 million jobs exist in the European Union and has supported more than 800,000 small and medium-sized enterprises.  A programme that helps economic growth, a programme that helps small and medium-sized enterprises that is underway. With InvestEU, our ambition cannot diminish and we should have the same amount of the guarantee that we have at the moment at least for the three financial instruments, and so we propose to strengthen the guarantee to stick to this objective which is maintenance. We have a small difference from the Commission and I would like to welcome the Vice-President and all the work that has been done in this area. The Commission proposes EUR 650 billion, we propose EUR 700 billion. In addition, we believe that, of course, the Union's policies must be absolutely guaranteed and the objectives in the area of climate, in the area also of what is the strategy we want for sustainability, but also for growth and inclusion. The European Investment Bank, we give legal certainty so that at least 75% of the guarantee and then all other national promotion banks and other financial institutions should have access to the other 25%. It is extremely important that this programme also contributes to social cohesion, territorial cohesion, economic cohesion of the European Union, and therefore the geographical balance is extremely important and has here a point that is the Advisory Hub - the platform for investment advice - which should be strengthened and which should allow projects in the regions to , projects from the most remote cities in the European Union can have access to this programme and hence the concern with the smaller projects. The need to continue to be able to have investment platforms is essential. May this Advisory Hub have a more active presence, a more proactive stance. In our proposal we have also simplified governance. Furthermore, with regard to additionality, we want it to remain, of course, adapted to what is the new reality and the three financial instruments and that there cannot be an additional definition that prevents, for example, social investment. I would like to end and thank all my fellow rapporteurs and, in particular, the rapporteur who is the rapporteur of the Socialist party, rapporteur Gualtieri, for the work we have done together. Othmar Karas too, for the excellent contribution he has made and all the rapporteurs and shadows, all the shadow rapporteurs who participated in this InvestEU. Thank you very much, we have made a great contribution to economic growth in the European Union.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Mr Fernandes and all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation. The 2008 crisis led to an unprecedented fall in investment, both public and private, across the European Union. Investment conditions in Europe have improved in recent years thanks to a more favourable economic situation, flexibility in the interpretation of the Stability Pact, new initiatives such as that of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, but the volume of investment in Europe still remains below the average level reached in the decade before the crisis, and new and more important gaps have also opened up in innovation-related sectors. , physical and social infrastructure, climate change. This situation is worrying for the future of Europe's competitiveness and social cohesion, for its long-term growth and for the creation of new jobs. That is why it is good that the Commission, by proposing the establishment of the InvestEU programme, has sought not only to renew but also to step up investment support.  However, InvestEU is not only a tool that continues the positive experience of EFSI and other projects developed in recent years. In addition to further strengthening support for small and medium-sized enterprises, research, innovation and sustainable infrastructure, this programme aims to begin to address the huge social infrastructure gap, denounced by the task force's report on investments in social infrastructure last January, ensuring the feasibility of projects in the field of education, health and social housing.  The primary objective of investEU is to close the investment gap in the sectors and geographical areas where it is most needed, and to do so Parliament has intervened with a series of improvements to the Commission's text.  Firstly, we have established that the cost of the guarantee for investment promoters should be exclusively linked to the characteristics and risk profile of the underlying transactions, and that more favourable conditions can be applied to promote the construction of investment platforms, to encourage investment in areas where the investment gap is greatest, or to encourage intervention in those sectors where the need for investment is most pronounced. Secondly, in addition to reiterating that the EIB will continue to be the Commission's main financial partner under InvestEU, we have enhanced the important role of national promotion banks in financing investment projects. National promotion banks will have direct access to the European guarantee, which will allow greater flexibility and therefore greater possibilities for financing projects, with positive consequences for the level of investment and the creation of new jobs. Finally, we have established that the Member States will not only have the opportunity to channel part of their resources allocated under the cohesion policy funds, but will also be able to contribute with additional resources which will, in principle, be considered as one-off contributions to the calculation of the structural deficit for the purposes of the Stability and Growth Pact.  The text we are about to vote on is, on the whole, balanced, including the part requiring that at least 65 % of investments under the sustainable infrastructure window contribute to achieving the objectives set out in the Paris Climate and Environment Agreements. I would therefore ask you to keep the text voted on by the ECON Committee with regard to this 65 % ceiling. With this text, I believe, we are giving a concrete response to those who are calling for Europe to do more for investment, growth and jobs.

name: Seán KELLY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, InvestEU is one of the flagship programmes of the new EU budget 2021-2027 and will mobilise over EUR 650 billion of additional investment in the EU. We have only to look at the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) to see the potential. It enables us to get more investment for less cost to the taxpayer. Over the last two years I have been holding regular public meetings on the investment plan around my constituency, in collaboration with the European Investment Bank and Commissioner Katainen and his officials, who deserve great credit. I see huge potential for InvestEU and I know in particular it is an instrument that business owners in my constituency – Ireland South – are looking forward to and have huge appetite for. I particularly welcome the emphasis on small businesses, and this is something that we in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) committed to in our opinion, and it has been endorsed by all groups, and I am very pleased about that. This is not about big business, which has its own independent way of raising capital. This is about small businesses, in particular, that we need to help and I am pleased we are doing that. Finally, I must say that this also has to be taken in the context of what is happening in Westminster this evening. Whatever happens, this is the perfect antidote to Brexit because it will help businesses which will be affected to get the finance needed to survive.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Kelly. Unfortunately, you only had one minute. I know that you are normally very correct, but you did not have more this time. That is why I do not permit a 'blue card'.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs who are going to bring this important dossier to a successful conclusion. We in the Committee on Transport need these investments very much. The plan is of great importance to the transport sector, especially when it comes to road construction and, in particular, motorways in Europe. We need more private money in our sector.  There is only one aspect that I am calling your special attention to, and these are the environmental objectives in the approach of the rapporteurs of the Committee on Budgets and ECON. We all know that Europe must become cleaner, but at the same time we must not overestimate the capacity of private investors in this area. That is why the Committee on Transport is calling for a lower environmental target than has been agreed.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to participate in this discussion. It is also a pleasure to see so many colleagues here who have wanted to implement EFSI in their own constituencies by presenting what EFSI can do, what advisory services can do and raise awareness, and this is the reason why EFSI has already been a success story. It is a good opportunity to continue this success story and that is why we have initiated the InvestEU proposal.  I want to thank this House for its continued backing throughout this mandate to the Commission's initiatives in support of investment.  When this Commission took office in late 2014, investment had fallen by 15% in the EU as a result of the financial and economic crisis.  We had to take comprehensive action to tackle this investment gap and to reinstate confidence both in the Union economy and also in the capacity of EU institutions to deliver for citizens. The investment plan for Europe was the Commission's answer to the situation and you were vigilant allies in setting up the European Fund for Strategic Investments to this end.  Today, the investment conditions in Europe have improved. However, there is still a sizeable investment gap in Europe, especially when it comes to social infrastructure and investments in the environmental and digital transition.  In the context of this proposal, for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the Commission has therefore put forward a single multi-policy investment support instrument – the InvestEU fund.  The InvestEU fund will combine 13 centrally managed financial instruments and the EFSI into a single EUR 38 billion budgetary currency.  It will have a strong policy focus and, while the EIB will remain the Commission’s main strategic partner in this implementation, it will also be open to other partners such as the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Council of Europe Development Bank or national promotional banks and institutions. The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s report on InvestEU. The report touches on many important items but broadly endorses the Commission's proposal.  Regarding the proposed changes, the Commission is open to considering those related to covenants, in particular those that increase the independence of the Investment Committee and safeguard the Commission's policy steer.  As regards the concerns expressed regarding the role of the EIB under InvestEU compared with EFSI, let me inform you that the Commission and the EIB have jointly proposed a partnership that would enshrine the EIB group’s 75% share of the EU currently in the regulation. The partnership would also put the EIB’s banking expertise to the best use for the design of a rationalisation of financial risk monitoring and reporting of the InvestEU programme. This partnership proposal is, of course, subject to the co-legislators’ consideration.  Some of your amendments are linked to the broader MFF discussion, such as the overall amount of currency and the climate targets. For the time being, we will take note of them and see them as a testimony of the Parliament's commitment to a strong Union with a strong budget and to the Union’s COP 21 goals.  On behalf of the Commission, let me express our appreciation for the tremendous effort the rapporteurs, the shadows and also associated committees have done to reach a position within a very ambitious timeline with a view to an agreement before the European elections. I very much hope that these tireless efforts will also be reflected in tomorrow's world. It is now up to the Council to step up their efforts in order to reach a partial general approach and allow for the beginning of trilogues.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, indeed, there is also full support from the Committee on the Environment. If we compare with the current EFSI programme, the share of investments in renewable energy and energy savings is already very ambitious. We are now at 19%, but we obviously want to take bigger and faster steps forward with the new InvestEU programme, especially in the area of renewable energy. It is a good thing that climate and sustainability are a common thread throughout the investment programme.  We are convinced, including from the Committee on the Environment, that strong industry and investment in europe's strong industry, with many jobs, can go hand in hand with sustainable and low-CARBON production. That is why, as the Commissioner said, it is good to bring together all the investment instruments to make that happen. In short, Mr Kelly has already said: InvestEU is the flagship, is the most important instrument we have for the leadership of Europe, certainly for the energy of the future that must be sustainable, which must be affordable and which we do not introduce, but which we generate ourselves.

name: Kerstin WESTPHAL
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European The InvestEU programme is a good programme, and I do indeed believe that the report by colleagues will improve this programme. Nevertheless, as a regional politician, allow me to pour a little water into the wine, because I do indeed have reservations. In my view, the Structural Funds, with their decentralised approach, with their shared management, are something completely different from InvestEU. The Structural Funds are there to improve the lives of all the people of Europe. They bring jobs in the regions, improve infrastructure, fight climate change, support companies and universities. This support must indeed continue, even if the budget is reduced. That is why I reject the idea that the Structural Funds should contribute to the financing of InvestEU.
