I say 'yes' to the idea of creating synergies, but no to the plans to mix the two instruments financially.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Rapporteur CULT. – Mr President, in his opinion on the proposal for a regulation establishing the Invest EU programme, the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education stresses the need for further investment in the field of culture, education and youth. These cultural and education investments will help to preserve Europe's cultural heritage, which undoubtedly plays a civilisational role in the development of world history. The Invest EU programme also needs to help small and medium-sized enterprises be competitive in the rapidly changing conditions of global competition and the use of new technologies. I am sure that this will lead to the creation of new jobs in the cultural and creative sectors. However, the more important effect is undoubtedly the preservation of local and national identity and self-awareness. The cultural heritage of each Member State is based on that identity and self-awareness.  I therefore believe that every Member State of the European Union, as well as any region, should make the most of the opportunities provided by Invest EU. This would help to preserve the regional and, in particular, national identity of the European peoples.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank all those who, since the beginning of the parliamentary term, have been trying to increase investment in the European Union. Mobilising investment is not a sprint, it is a marathon. We have succeeded in learning at every step and improving something with every step. We launched the Investment Plan for Europe with EFSI 1 at the beginning of the parliamentary term. We have improved it with EFSI 2 and extended it until 2020. We have extended the Investment Plan to third countries, especially Africa, and we want to open another chapter with the new InvestEU initiative. We want to mobilise EUR 700 billion in additional investment over seven years, reduce bureaucracy and increase efficiency by concentrating funding instruments, better supporting smaller projects and businesses, increasing the effectiveness and, by extending the direct allocation of the EU guarantee, ensuring political independence and transparency of investment decisions and ensuring the implementation of the climate targets.  That is our objective, and we hope that this will enable us to take a major step forward in terms of more investment in Europe, growth and employment.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, I too would like to begin by joining the rapporteurs, Mr Gualtieri and Mr Fernandes, on their great work in this report. It is true that we were on a good basis with the proposal put forward by the Commission, but I believe that in the parliamentary process, thanks to the rapporteurs and negotiators of other political groups, we have improved that proposal. From the beginning of the economic crisis for the Socialists, it was a priority to establish an investment plan that would allow economies to be relaunched, but relaunched on the right path; and this is for sustainable growth. In this mandate we have already worked on the first strategic investment plan, which we know as the Juncker Plan, and on its expansion. And, as always, everything is improveable, but the results I think can be described as satisfactory. This new investment plan is based not only on these good results and on the experience of the previous plan, but also brings together under one umbrella financial instruments that were dispersed by different programmes. We also had been demanding time, and what it's going to do is have a much more flexible, more efficient and simpler instrument, and therefore with a better impact. The aim of this programme, it has already been said, is to mobilize almost EUR 700 billion, thanks to the European budget, and to allocate them to investments that will enable the European Union to grow in a smart way, that is by investing in knowledge, in sustainable infrastructure or by facilitating access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. This new plan will also enable us to social infrastructure and give a fundamental impetus in the fight against climate change. I also think it is important to highlight the role given to promotional banks that exist at the national or regional level, because it will create very positive synergies and bring investment closer to the specific needs of the territories. So I hope that negotiations with the Council will begin quickly, that we will be able to reach a good agreement in line with what this Parliament is going to vote on tomorrow, that is, in line with the objectives, but also — fundamentally - in line with the budgetary volume we will vote on.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her With Invest-EU, the EU is once again trying to eliminate structural deficiencies by spending money. That will not succeed. This has not worked so far, and it will not work in the future. Structural deficiencies must be eliminated in such a way that they are first analysed and the right conclusions are drawn from them. But if we just go and say, 'We want more investment', we act as if any investment is good. But that is not the case. Investments are only good if they have a sustainable effect. Above all, we must finally ensure that the EU does not rise above the private sector. We need private investment. But when we see that we have a zero interest rate policy, we have a flood of money, there is enough money – why not invest? In other words, we have very different problems here than providing the private sector with money. What we will achieve with InvestEU is the same as with the EFSI, with the Juncker Plan. We will support projects without knowing what will come out of them in the end, without measurable results. In other words, we will have misinvestment, we will have misallocations, and we will not do anything for the citizens in the end, but that will ultimately have a take-away effect. What we really need to increase competitiveness would be a reform of the euro currency. Because it is completely out of place, it does things the same, which cannot be done in the same way. That is where we have to start. That would be a significant improvement on our economic importance.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, when we began this long walk and debate on the Juncker Fund years ago, most of us were perhaps somewhat sceptical then: will this become a wheel that will go forward. Now we are somewhat wiser and understand that this bike actually runs, although some are trying to say that it does not spin anyway.  There are, of course, many challenges, now that we are still taking the second or third step forward, because InvestEU is pretty much a different bicycle from EFSI 1 or EFSI 2. Now we are also including sources of power outside this institution. When we discussed this at these meetings, there was almost a slight doubt as to whether we would actually be able to receive them with open arms. We are politicians, we easily think of things as if from a state point of view and from a national perspective. Although we are talking about self-employed and small businesses, this state perspective, 'thinking like a state', as the English sometimes say, can be problematic.  I therefore wish us every success and thank our rapporteurs for this tremendous work. Perhaps today and tomorrow we will take a huge step forward, and if the Council were still able to go at the same pace as the Commission and Parliament, then perhaps tomorrow we will be in a better world.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to stress that it was urgent that the Union took stronger action to increase investment, so therefore we welcome the original plan. We saw the deficiencies and we learned lessons from that and now have a new proposal.  The Union has to be bolder, to increase investment, and this is also what the new InvestEU programme will deliver. But at the same time, I would like to stress that good investment is only sustainable investment. Only investment which learns the lessons of the climate crisis is good investment and therefore it was positive that the compromise coming out of the leading committee foresaw an increase in the share of sustainable investment in the infrastructure window to 65%, and it is important for our Group that this House sticks to this proposal.  Second, we believe strongly that military and civil objectives in budgets should be well separated, and this principle should also be respected in the plenary vote. I count on the co-rapporteurs to follow the original compromise rather than changing that here in the plenary and making it more difficult to achieve a broad pro-European majority which this programme deserves.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, as Commissioner Katainen said, we need more investment support. We are still well behind the level of pre-crisis investment. Therefore, the steps taken with InvestEU, in the view of our political group, are not enough. It is a fact that the proposal brought by the European Parliament improves the Commission's original proposal in several respects. But I'm identifying some negatives and some risks. There is a risk that InvestEU will remove funds from the Cohesion Fund and this will be unacceptable when we already have a reduction in cohesion funds in the Commission's proposal for the new Multiannual Financial Framework. The second risk is that real small and medium-sized enterprises will be wronged. We will insist on more investment, particularly in those areas that have the greatest disinvestment and in those areas that have suffered the most from the recession.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this pork—barrel legislation invests EU money managed centrally by the Commission. Can we please remind ourselves of two things? First, there is no such thing as EU money. It comes from the taxpayer, and it is taxpayers’ money. Secondly, a profit that motivates a business that is investing taxpayers’ money into it is a subsidy that distorts the market on which taxpayers must themselves rely, whether it is consumers, investors or both. State aid rules were intended to ensure a level playing field in the use of subsidies. That’s why the EU wants to impose the EU state aid rules on the UK during, and even after, transition. But it won’t be a level playing field because this legislation will streamline the approval process for EU businesses, but not UK ones. You might say we will be at the back of the queue, but it need not be a disadvantage. After all, Oliver Twist was at the back of the queue for his subsidised thin gruel. Asking for more didn’t help him, but escape from a 19th century workhouse most certainly did. That is what British business will, and must, do – escape from a 19th century-style customs union to a more entrepreneurial and liberating future. Unfortunately, our Prime Minster sees it differently, but she looks as if she’s going to get a good beating tonight, so I’m off to enjoy that. We will be out of the European Union soon, I hope, and have free trade deals with the rest of the world.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work The InvestEU programme will bring together a wide range of financial instruments – 13 of them you mentioned – under one roof in the next Multiannual Financial Framework, making financing simpler, more efficient and more flexible. From 2021, InvestEU will seamlessly connect to EFSI 2 and hopefully help to close the investment gap that you also mentioned. With a budget guarantee of EUR 38 billion – according to the Commission, Parliament wanted more: 40 – public and private investment of EUR 650 billion is to be mobilised. And, very positively, the most important point of contact and resolution partner is the European Investment Bank, which has already successfully handled the EFSI. 75% of the volume is transferred through this bank. In addition, national promotional banks, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the World Bank and the Council of Europe Development Bank will be involved. It is also positive – and this is where Parliament comes back to bear – that a steering committee is set up and that there are decentralised advisory hubs, the so-called advisory hub partners – both, as I said, parliamentary positions. 650 billion in the four policy areas to be invested from the EFSI or InvestEU is important. It's a big challenge. I thank the rapporteurs. Let's start!

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I also wanted to thank Wilhelm Molterer, because he has shown that such a programme can be implemented very successfully.  We see that Europe needs investment. Mr Katainen has put this in a good place. The share of production in GDP is still declining in Europe. We have set ourselves the target of 20%, but we are now around 15% and France and the United Kingdom are already scratching at the 10% mark. So, here we can see that the European Union really needs to act.  My personal objective would be to increase the share of production in Europe back to 30% by 2030, so we too need to get production from the rest of the world, which has been relocated to other countries in recent years, back with Industry 4.0 and with the Skills package, the training package that has been created here. I believe that the SME window benefits us very much, including in risk-sharing. Small and medium-sized enterprises in particular need to take on risks. On the other hand, they also pay taxes, and if, on the one hand, they pay the taxes, they also have a right to be involved in taking on risks accordingly.  For the 22 million SMEs that produce 50% or more of GDP and create 80% of the new jobs, the money is well spent. The risk-sharing between the EIB at 75% and the national banks at 25% will also be felt here, and good blending will enable a good and secure future for this Europe.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, I believe that this Parliament has improved the Commission's proposal and that we can only welcome it because this proposal is absolutely essential to boost investment in the European Union, which we know is so lacking. This is essential for our citizens, for our businesses and for our territories. We welcome the Commission's proposal to simplify the terms of this investment and to allow for complementarity with other instruments, including cohesion policy, which is a significant step forward in our view. Moreover, the investment objectives that have been adopted seem to us to be quite exemplary in relation to what the European Union's economic strategy should be, since they reconcile both sustainable development, the objectives of the Paris conference and social investment, not to mention the creative and cultural industries. Finally, we believe that, at the initiative of this Parliament again, the rise of national development banks will only improve the capacity of such a plan to achieve success and to finance, where necessary, the investments useful for better growth creating sustainable jobs in Europe.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: Mr President, this is the first legislative dossier I have been negotiating for the ECR and for my party, the N-VA, and I was satisfied. Because often the Commission comes up with proposals that make you wonder whether they are useful. But this is a sensible reform. It brings together all existing EU investment programmes and turns them into a streamlined programme. The Commission's original proposal was not entirely right. Governance was too complex and the EIB's expertise was underused. I am glad that we were able to improve this text considerably. We have emphasised strengthening the role of national investment banks. Our Flemish private equity company, the PNV, can therefore take full responsibility for the implementation of the investments. I thank the rapporteurs for their work and look forward to the negotiations with the Council.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, I would like to underline three specific aspects relating to InvestEU. Firstly, there is a clear need to further mobilise public and private investments in the European Union, but this investment should follow a rationale, serve a clear purpose and aim at achieving common goals. In other words, the InvestEU programme must be a useful tool to transform our economies into carbon-neutral inclusive economies. They must foster energy transition and take into account social and environmental concerns. We definitely have to be determined to accomplish the Paris Agreement and the SDGs. That is why we strive for bigger climate spending targets when it comes to supporting strategic investments and exclude projects that could be environmentally harmful. Secondly, we strongly oppose the funding of defence projects with InvestEU. The militarisation of the EU budget, be it through investments or through research support, is not the proper way to solve the security challenges that we are facing. InvestEU funds should be invested in many other areas with a much more evident need of investment, not least in the social economy.  Thirdly and finally, the stronger participation not only of national, but also of regional promotional banks, is a key factor in the better allocation of projects due to their knowledge of the local markets and of the needs of the economic and social agents.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, déarfainn leis an gCoimisinéir go bhfuilimid tar éis imeacht ón Juncker Plan go dtí an EFSI go dtí FC1 go dtí FC2 agus anois tá ainm nua againn, InvestEU. Ach i ndairíre, cé go bhfuil an t-ainm difriúil tá an bunphrionsabal mar an gcéanna agus an infheistíocht dírithe i dtreo infheistíocht phríobháideach a mhealladh seachas infheistíocht phoiblí. Ní bheinnse dóchasach go bhfuil an infheistíocht chun imeacht go dtí an earnáil phoiblí. Ní fheicim, mar shampla, go mbeidh córas iompair ann do mhuintir tuaithe na hÉireann atá ag streachailt faoi láthair. Ní fheicim go mbeidh na hinfheisteoirí príobháideacha seo ag infheistiú i seirbhísí poiblí.  Do bhí reachtaíocht ann an uair dheireanach a bheadh ag cur leis an ngeilleagar sóisialta agus a bheadh ag cur airgead ar fáil do chomharchumainn; agus nílim róchinnte – mar níl na fíricí faighte agam agus aon uair a lorgaím na fíricí seo, ní gheibhim iad.  Níor chóir dúinn a bheith ag cur aon airgead i dtreo fórsaí míleata, táimid glan i gcoinne é sin. Agus mar sin, cé go bhfuil infheistíocht tábhachtach, agus táimid ar fad aontaithe air sin, braitheann sé ar cá bhfuil an dua chun an infheistíocht sin a dhéanamh agus is insan earnáil phoiblí ba chóir go mbeadh sé ag imeacht.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are discussing the InvestEU programme today, but I would like to go back for a moment to its predecessor, the Juncker Plan, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which has been a great success. It has certainly contributed to the Fact that the European Union , especially the euro area, is experiencing 22 quarters of continuous expansion. This is certainly a success, and I am pleased that we are continuing this idea in such an modernized, modernized shape. I would also like to say that the Juncker Plan has contributed to the development of my country, and especially my region, from which I am an MEP, from Western Pomerania and from the Lubusz Region, where it finances, inter alia, the modernisation of the chemical plant in Police, as well as investments related to improving shipping on the Oder River.  Speaking of the InvestEU programme, I would first of all like to emphasise the fact that by focusing on the various financial instruments in this programme – from grants to loans and guarantees – there are thirteen of them in total, we are getting a very flexible instrument that can actually be used under different conditions and for different projects. I would also like to say that I am in favour of the Guarantee Fund, which supports this investment programme, already increased to EUR 40.8 billion as proposed by the rapporteurs. We are confident that this money will be well used. Finally, I would like to say that I hope that the Fund will take greater account of the needs of the developing economies of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, besides paving the way for more private investment in Europe, which we really need, I also think we have to ask how we want to spend taxpayers’ money. So InvestEU is a question we need to ask on that. Do we want to invest in business as usual, spending money on outdated approaches and supporting the technology of the past, or should we invest in the tools of the future, the Europe of tomorrow, where growth doesn’t have an equal burden in terms of climate and sustainability? When we are voting on the InvestEU Programme tomorrow, that is the question we all need to ask ourselves. With InvestEU we have a chance to show in what direction we, as policymakers, wish to direct Europe. We have a chance to vote for a fund that puts climate first when investing taxpayers’ money.  Along with ambitious colleagues from a number of parties, I have fought for higher sustainability and energy targets. Dear colleagues – and especially the colleagues on the conservative side of this Chamber – please join us in voting for an EU investment programme that puts climate and the future first.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, for me, the central element of InvestEU is to continue to turn its back on a policy of austerity and to invest in innovative, sustainable projects that might not find investors without the support of the European Union. Do you realize that? EUR 38 billion to carry out projects such as small and medium-sized enterprises that promote the inclusion of people with disabilities, or research without animal experimentation, a wind farm in the North Sea, a thermal renovation of buildings. These are projects that our future generations need. Unfortunately, a sword of Damocles hovers over these projects: the attempt of the lobbies of the arms industry to seize these investment funds. Colleagues, resist the siren song of the arms industry, and invest in the future of our planet!

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Madam President, we have already taken a lot of steps during the last years as part of the Juncker plan, and I’m glad to see that some of these changes that we wished for have been taken on board. For instance, a better relationship with regional policy, and a better relationship with Structural Funds and Horizon Europe.  It’s possible to have a greater impact and more visibility if you combine those funds with the new InvestEU fund to bring better visibility for our citizens, for instance through smart specialisation.  Second point, the transfer from the Structural Funds has been realised now in this regulation. This is very important. It’s a free transfer, and it can be done on the priorities that are regionally accepted.  Third point, assistance from the InvestEU Advisory Hub is absolutely necessary all over Europe, and the EIB can work together and share its expertise with other partners. This is a partnership that is now possible. And my last remark, the geographical balance can be done better than before. It’s no good that one part of Europe takes away a lot of young people to work in other parts. It’s Europe, and our goal is that we want to have balanced development. This has been taken on board in a much better way. As REGI coordinator, I support your initiative and I think it’s good for a green, growing Europe with jobs.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, I welcome the InvestEU programme, which in the last place is to make financing for investment projects in Europe simpler, more efficient and more flexible. We are talking about investments of 650 billion euros: good news for all, a new opportunity to stimulate job creation, investment and innovation. But this opportunity must also reach the outermost regions. To this end, obstacles to the full use of these funds by these regions must be removed, with the necessary exceptions for this purpose. The Canary Islands wants to be an important part of this program, but for this you have to take into account its uniqueness and special characteristics. Solidarity is a fundamental value of the European Union. In this case, moreover, any derogation in favour of the outermost regions has full legal support in Article 349 of the Treaty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, investEU can prove to be a positive programme provided that certain conditions are laid down. Firstly, the outermost regions, in particular the Aegean islands, must be supported. Secondly, to support the regions and not the centre of the hard core of the euro area. Thirdly, to support small and medium-sized enterprises. These are conditions for us to be able to take a different direction. The areas we must deal with are certainly culture, environmental protection and employment. The money must not be used in order to further militarise the European Union and, above all, we must not follow the example set by the Juncker plan because in Greece the money that came in practice was used in order for Fraport to buy the Greek regional airports and, secondly, to finance Cosmote, which is a German company. Let the money come to Greece to support Greek businesses, not multinationals. So let us avoid the bad example we had in the Juncker plan.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, this programme has two problems: firstly, it represents yet another instrument for subsidising the private sector, i.e. there is hunger, there is social inequalities, there is poverty, the European Union whistles to the side; investment has been broken, the instruments to support companies immediately appear.  Secondly, this does not meet the needs of the European Union and the people because what the European Union really needs is an ambitious public investment plan that responds to the needs of the people and streamlines the economy and sees that a tiny part of the means that have been spent by the ECB in its quantitative expansion operations would have been more than sufficient to finance this plan , relaunching economic growth and combating asymmetries. But this was not the orientation and there we have another competitive instrument, a financial instrument, which does not guarantee additionality, that will feed public-private partnerships and which has the novelty now that we can also finance the arms industry, which we deeply regret.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to welcome my colleague José Manuel Fernandes for his work on the InvestEU dossier in order, on the one hand, to bring more justice to it and, on the other hand, to simplify this tool by adding other scattered financial instruments to date.  InvestEU is essential to the Union, especially at a time when investment lines are still manifestly insufficient for Europe's development objectives. I therefore believe that to play a decisive role here for the European Investment Bank is to recognise the good work that has been done by this European institution with years of success in this area. There is no doubt that the InvestEU fund will guarantee a slice of the Union budget dedicated to its main strategic axes, in a shared responsibility and in complementarity with other member states' financing instruments, and this will allow smaller countries such as Portugal to have more opportunities to see projects born that to date, due to unfavourable risk analyses, could not be financed by private investment. Ladies and gentlemen, this is the opportunity for which they expected some projects so essential to combat climate change and the decarbonisation of the economy, for blue growth and sustainable development, as well as for the protection of biodiversity in the oceans and on land.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The InvestEU programme can be an important instrument to stimulate investment in regions undergoing an energy transition. Thanks to my amendments, the ENVI Committee makes it clear that investments supported by InvestEU include expenditure to support regions undergoing climate policy transformation, both social and infrastructure.  Unfortunately, in the final text of the leading committees, these objectives are no longer so clearly enshrined. I would therefore like to ask whether we will be able to finance investments in mining regions, in regions undergoing energy transition, from this programme. This is extremely important.  Climate policy is one of the european Union's main policies. It is well known that countries that have a coal-based energy mix bear great costs when it comes to adapting to climate rigour. Will we be able to use these funds? I say this as a Polish woman, I am concerned about this issue.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I thank the Rapporteur, my colleague Fernandes for his excellent work and I particularly welcome Vice-President Katainen, who has worked hard and visited all Member States under the previous programme, EFSI. Thanks to the success we have with EFSI, we can now talk about a new program, the InvestEU program.  What we have actually learned by implementing and working on EFSI is that it is very important to prepare projects and that this project pipeline in the Member States is extremely important for their quality inclusion in this programme, and that is why I think that in implementation we must dedicate ourselves specifically precisely to the use of technical assistance and as much investment as possible in less developed Member States that do not have sufficient administrative capacity to prepare projects and participate in this programme. That's the first. Secondly, which is very important, is our willingness to take greater risks. So, not just to fund public projects, but to start funding innovators, innovations, start-ups as much as possible because that's what's going to lift the economy and drive development.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for this very good and encouraging debate. I will answer some of the concerns or questions and comment on some of the ideas raised by honourable Members.  First, I have to say that the InvestEU fund is more of a policy driven fund than the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) has been. This doesn’t mean that projects are selected politically – not at all. They are selected according to the quality of the project and whether EFSI can really create some added value. The idea is to address policies like climate change or improve digitalisation or increase financing for small and medium-sized companies, which are lacking finance in certain Member States. This is what I mean when saying that it’s a more policy driven fund.  Second, the basic idea of EFSI will be maintained, meaning that InvestEU is also a demand driven fund. Nobody is forced to use EFSI if they are not willing to, but on the other hand you can get EFSI financing if you apply. The third element is that EFSI’s idea is to crowd in private liquidity, private money for investments – from the bank account for investments – which creates jobs and competitiveness and addresses our policy targets. By pooling together 13 existing financial instruments, it should be clear to everybody that, from the end user’s point of view, InvestEU is much easier to use. So you don’t need to know all the 13 different funds and think about what might be suitable for your use. You only have to know that there is an InvestEU fund which can provide guarantees of different kinds of financing for your projects. In addition to this combination or pooling together of 13 funds, we will pool together 13 different advisory services. Again, from an end user’s point of view, applying technical assistance becomes much easier. The novelty in the InvestEU fund – or one of them – is that we will allocate 25% of current fees, according to demand, from financial institutions other than the EIB. The EIB is a valuable partner for the Commission – also in the future – but we want to improve and encourage new financial innovations. The EIB is not always willing or capable or it doesn’t want to invest in all the different projects which someone else could do – national promotional banks or the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) or the Council of Europe Bank. I believe that this 25% allocation to banks other than the EIB will create clear added value.  I also want to remind all honourable Members, if you are interested, to look at what EFSI has achieved. Just visit EFSI’s website. You can easily find it if you google EFSI or go to the EIB’s website. Every single project which has been signed is mentioned and you can just click on your own country and there’s a list of the projects which are already signed in your country.  EFSI has not been the medicine for all diseases and neither is the InvestEU fund the medicine which addresses all the probable problems in the world, but it’s a valuable additional investment tool which can create concrete jobs and modernise our economy, making it more sustainable, and create added value to our welfare societies.  A final point, on EFSI: one thing which makes me especially happy when looking at what EFSI has achieved is to look at the countries which have mostly benefited from EFSI. Looking at EFSI investment per country’s GDP, the number one user is Greece, second Estonia, third Portugal, fourth Spain, and fifth Lithuania. Latvia is sixth, Bulgaria seventh, Finland eighth, Poland ninth, and Italy tenth. So mostly the financing has gone in the right direction, exactly to the countries and regions of those countries which have had some financial constraints. When looking at the quality of the projects, it’s also impressive. It has improved since we started EFSI and I am sure that InvestEU will do the same in the future.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I thank you for all your contributions to this debate. I am not yet impressed by the voices that are against private initiative, fortunately few, but have still been heard in this Plenary.  It is businesses and, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises that create jobs. I would also remind you that this fund can and should be used by regional, local public authorities, and is therefore an added value and an additional instrument that is very important for investment and particularly in places where there are market failures. That is why, in my view, it is incomprehensible that those who claim employment are then against instruments that help job creation. Furthermore, this instrument also helps inclusion, has a window that we reinforced, which is a window for the social area and also the investment window for small and medium-sized enterprises. I also think it is very important that there should be no confusion about the compartment that is for the Member States. In addition to the EUR 700 billion that we propose, in terms of investment, with the guarantee of around EUR 40 billion, we have the possibility that Member States can use this InvestEU by placing a guarantee from the Structural Funds. But this is no transfer, these Structural Funds and this percentage belong to those same Member States, Member States which can allocate and mobilise with a triple A, also use the possibility of avoiding the difficulties resulting from State aid and can move forward with additional investments for well-defined projects.  It is important now that Member States also make the definition of the projects they consider important as regards the use of this compartment. I expect a vote, as in the Committee on Budgets and the Economy, a vote with an overwhelming majority of those in favour of investment, job creation, strengthening the competitiveness of the European Union and respecting the commitments we have made, particularly in the fight against climate change.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it has been a rich debate, reflecting the broad consensus of this House on the text that has been approved by the two Committees on ECON and BUDG.  I believe that, as vice-president Katainen also said, we are facing a positive incremental process. EFSI has been a success, but it has certainly not been able to make the most of its potential with regard to the quality of investments and the ability to fully fill market deficits. InvestEU, as proposed by the Commission, all the more so as improved by this Parliament, I believe it defines a good balance between policy orientation, flexibility, granularity and at the same time economy of scale.  Of course, certainty about resources is essential, so we hope that the MFF will also be equal to the quantitative reinforcement as well as the qualitative improvement that we have achieved with our InvestEU text. Our group will be strictly in line with the outcome of the committee vote and I very much hope that some pejorative amendments will not be adopted, in order to give a strong signal also with regard to the centrality of the sustainability objective. For all this, I thank Parliament.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday 16 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – I welcome the co-rapporteurs for this comprehensive report and European Commission’s proposal to further expand and simplify the European Fund for Strategic Investments, by establishing InvestEU as a single EU investment support mechanism for the financial period 2021-2027 that aims to further boost job creation, investment and innovation across the Member States. Building on the leverage principle of Juncker’s Plan, InvestEU aims to trigger almost EUR 700 billion of private and public additional investment by providing an EU budget guarantee of EUR 40 billion. The purpose is to supply financing to economic actors with a risk profile that private financiers are not always able or willing to address. This is definitely the case of SMEs, which are currently facing considerable challenges when accessing finance across within the EU. Accordingly, I express my support for the increase of EUR 2.8 billion for SMEs and Social Investment windows, as I find it crucial for InvestEU to succeed in simplifying access to finance in all phases of SMEs’ lifecycles, but also in providing them with more diversified sources of funding. These measures can significantly increase SMEs’ capacity to finance their growth, competitiveness and resilience to economic downturn, and will eventually generate new jobs and social well-being for our citizens.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I strongly welcome the Commission’s decision to establish another programme, in continuity to Juncker’s plan in order to boost investment, job creation and innovation in Europe. Such a programme is very much needed. We see that the Juncker plan has delivered great results in this mandate: around 856 000 SMEs are set to benefit from EFSI funding and EFSI is expected to trigger EUR 371.2 billion in investments. These are positive numbers which show that Europe has chosen a good direction to boost its business growth and innovation. I hope that the InvestEu programme will bring not only financial support but also better technical support for SMEs who will apply in order for them to gain the most out of it. I hope that especially smaller Member States such as Lithuania will be encouraged to apply more actively to this programme. For that we need to spread the information about the programme in Member States because as I have learned with EFSI and the Lithuanian example, people were simply not aware about this programme. As a result, the application level was non-existent in the first years of EFSI.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - On 6 June 2018, the Commission presented its proposal to establish an InvestEU programme which aims to ensure support for investment and access to finance in the EU. InvestEU is based on the success of the EFSI, which was established after the financial crisis and has become a springboard for investment in the areas of the economy most in need.  The programme proposes a single fund based on a guaranteed €38 billion of Union funding to mobilise public and private funds in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other market instruments for strategic investments that will support EU internal policies.  In order to facilitate access to the Fund's funds, the InvestEU Advisory Centre and the InvestEU portal are envisaged. The programme is dedicated to four policy areas with the following investment amounts: sustainable infrastructure (up to 11.5 billion), research, innovation and digitalisation (up to 11.25 billion), SMEs (up to 11.25 billion) and social investment and skills (4 billion). InvestEU support should primarily be able to deliver projects that can contribute to the climate and energy objectives the Union wants to achieve by 2030 and the long-term objectives of the Paris Agreement.  I believe that InvestEU will contribute to improving the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union's economic growth and the integration of the Union's capital markets.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The following point is a joint debate on the following reports: the report by Santiago Fisas Ayxelà on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on behalf of the European Union and Colombia, (2018/2010 (INI)) (A8-0446/2018) and the report prepared by Reimer Böge on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the implementation of the Trade Pillar of the Association Agreement with Central America (2018/2106(INI)) (A8-0459/2018).

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, the Trade Agreement signed in 2013 by the European Union with Colombia and Peru has been provisionally implemented over the past five years and, after analysing its implementation and relations between the three parties, we can say that it has been an advantageous agreement for all.  This Agreement outweighs strictly commercial aspects, as it implies a relationship based on international standards, common values and standards that has had a very positive impact on the socio-economic development of the parties. It is also a tool that allows us to consolidate our strategic partnership with Latin America, which is of vital importance to the European Union.  The Trade Agreement has contributed to economic stability, modernization and diversification of exports in Colombia and Peru. It is important for these countries to have a reference market outside Latin America that allows them to diversify their exports. The Agreement has helped Colombia and Peru modernize and diversify their exports and have been beneficial to their small and medium-sized enterprises.  For European companies too, the Agreement has led to an improvement in access to these markets, not only by eliminating tariffs, but also by reducing bilateral trade barriers. However, I believe that effective action must be taken by the Commission and the Member States so that our SMEs can exploit the full potential of trade agreements like this.  We must welcome the progress made in finding solutions to existing trade barriers, especially on sanitary and phytosanitary issues, but work remains to be done by Colombia and Peru to resolve issues such as the certification of certain meat and dairy products, the protection of union geographical indications or the taxation applied to the importation of spirits.  The Agreement has also enabled the development of cooperation mechanisms between the Commission and the Governments of Colombia and Peru, in mainly on trade and sustainable development issues. The objective has to be to work to ensure that international labour and environmental regulations are applied correctly.  Accompanied by a roadmap, the Agreement has also served to monitor social and environmental issues. We can say that positive progress has been made on the part of Colombia and Peru, but there is a long way to go and we must insist on compliance with the provisions reflected to ensure freedom of association, the right to collective bargaining, labour inspections, informal work, child labour or environmental issues.  I would like to congratulate the Government of Colombia on the bilateral and definitive ceasefire and hostilities agreement reached with the FARC guerrillas, and also on their entry into the OECD on 30 May, which recognises the important reforms undertaken in the country.  I also encourage Peru to make progress on its reforms under the OECD Country Programme. Finally, I would like to recall that this Agreement should also have been signed with all Andean countries, including Bolivia and Ecuador, which for political reasons did not want to negotiate it. I welcome Ecuador's request to join in 2015 in realizing the benefits it represented for its economy and for Ecuador to ratify its accession in December 2017.  We must encourage these partner countries to continue working in the right direction. There are still improvements to be made, but they must be congratulated on the path taken and ensure that they are supported by the European Union.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This report on the implementation of the trade part of the Association Agreement with Central America was adopted by a large majority in the Committee on International Trade. In a globalized world, rules-based trade agreements are not only an important instrument of trade relations, but generally an element that can help bring stability to this rapidly changing world. There are positives to this report, but also worth thinking about. I would like to say first of all that this association agreement does indeed consist of three pillars, and unfortunately, to date – although the countries of Central America have all agreed to the agreement in 2013 – three Member States have not yet ratified the two pillars outside trade. We are seeing this time and again, and this undermines it, undermines the credibility of the European Union when it tries to launch trade agreements and association agreements with partners from other continents. From the point of view of this, first of all, the appeal itself to the three Member States concerned to get serious about ratification, so that the pillars can finally achieve a balance between trade policy, cooperation and political dialogue. I would like to make it clear once again that this agreement is the first – so to speak – from region to region agreement. We are, of course, dealing with countries in Central America, all of which also have specific challenges. You can see this in the figures, for example, if they are available to us: there are countries where trade has increased considerably in recent years, and there are countries where things are moving a little slower. At the same time, we see that there is also a certain vulnerability to change, if I take, for example, one of the countries where trade has increased particularly, namely Costa Rica, followed by Panama and Guatemala, where, on the other hand, changes in the south-east Asian region have dramatically lowered trade relations between this area and Costa Rica. We also need to look at these things in more detail. We also note – and this is also seen in other trade agreements – that both the partners and the European Union still have room for improvement when it comes to using the agreed tariffs and figures for trade. Certainly, the questions are also important from the point of view of Central America and 'What does the European Union export there?', which we have to see, which are still relatively one-sidedly oriented towards certain primary products?  It should also be pointed out in this context that, for example, certain areas of debate need to be discussed more intensively, namely the question of services. I believe, Commissioner, that there is also a need for action. And, of course, the appeal to the European Union and all Central American states to take into account the full implementation and ratification of environmental agreements at international level, including the Paris Agreement. There is still some catching up to do with the ILO agreements. There are some challenges that still need to be addressed, and we must not let up there. Finally, to name it, Austria, Belgium and Greece should finally ratify this association agreement.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to start by wishing you all a Happy New Year and I am looking forward to close collaboration in the remaining months in this plenary, and between, of course.  I would also like to thank very much the European Parliament, the Committee on International Trade (INTA), and the two rapporteurs, Mr Böge and Mr Santiago Fisas Ayxelà, for the reports that you have just accounted for on the implementation of the Trade Pillar of the Association Agreement with Central America and the Trade Agreement between the EU and Peru and Colombia. Both of these reports deliver a very valuable contribution to assess the results of these agreements on the ground and the Commission is also launching this year a comprehensive evaluation study of both these agreements. As you rightly point out in these reports, implementation has gone well and they have had a positive impact on bilateral trade despite the negative impact of an unfavourable international economic context. At the same time, we need of course to pay close attention to the implementation of the trade and sustainable development provisions in certain Central American countries, particularly relating to labour provisions. There has been some progress, as you said; for example, with the recent establishment of the tripartite labour council in Guatemala. The Commission has also provided funding for events on corporate social responsibility, for strengthening the domestic advisory groups and directly to the ILO regional office. Colombia and Peru have also made some progress concerning effective implementation on sustainable development provisions. Contact with Peru has been particularly intense. I sent a letter to Peru’s Trade Minister last July stating our concerns about the insufficient implementation of commitments to protect fundamental labour rights, about Peru’s relaxation of environmental standards, to promote trade and investment, and about the non-sufficient consultation of civil society. Peru engaged very constructively in these discussions and we have achieved positive results.  The report on the Andean Agreement correctly highlights the importance of consultations with civil society. Here as well there has been progress. Last year Columbia established a dedicated domestic advisory group and Peru has committed to dedicated discussions on labour and environmental issues in some of the existing civil society consultation mechanisms that the government has chosen to rely upon. We need to continue to pay close attention in this area and we will engage with the countries covered by the Agreements in line with the 15-point action plan on trade and sustainable development presented last February.  Some issues are only partially covered in these Agreements, or not at all – gender, anti-corruption provisions or a complete chapter on investment. This is of course mainly due to the age of the Agreements – the negotiations were concluded in 2010 – so we need to see with our partners how we can move on with these challenges in the future.  Finally, let me underline that we fully share your view that in light of the challenging political situation in Central America and the Andean region, it is urgent – and also for our credibility as you so rightly said, Mr Böge – for both Agreements to enter fully into force. So we strongly support the call that Parliament has made for the Member States that have not yet ratified the Agreements to do so as soon as possible. I am very much looking forward to this debate.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on their work. I am honoured to be rapporteur of the Committee on Foreign Affairs at the time of approval of these two agreements and, therefore, I welcome the success of being useful instruments for our citizens and our businesses in both the European Union and Central America and the Andean Community and that they have contributed to a fairer international trade order , inclusive and rule-based, especially at this time of protectionist temptations. As Mr Fisas said, we must optimise the advantages of these agreements and, as Mr Bége said, we need to improve our procedures. It is inconceivable, Commissioner, that there are still three Member States which have not ratified these agreements. In the case of Colombia, the achievements achieved have somehow been overshadowed by the terrible situation in Venezuela, and I believe that our president's commitment and determination must be welcomed by expressing solidarity with the Democrats fighting in Venezuela. And also, in the case of Central America, a delegation from this Parliament will visit Nicaragua to see if the terrible situation this country is experiencing is compatible with an essential element of these agreements, which is the democratic clause.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, I too, first of all, would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs and thank them for their constructive attitude which has led to broad consensus. I sincerely believe that as important as signing good agreements is assessing their compliance and impact.  The implementation of the European Union Trade Agreements with Colombia, Peru and Central America has common ground that I would like to highlight.  First, their strategic value: both Agreements seal partnerships in defense of global economic governance, multilateralism, regional integration as fundamental pillars of sustainable development. The Agreement with Central America is the first bi-regional agreement signed by the European Union; and the one signed with Peru and Colombia, to which Ecuador fortunately acceded, remains open to the Andean Pact bloc.  From an economic point of view, all parties have seized new opportunities, and the diversification of their economies too dependent on their raw materials and agricultural production has been favored.  With regard to socialist claims in defence of the sustainable development objectives, I would like to stress that both agreements have sealed long-term commitments and created dialogue tables to ensure more respectful trade in human, social, labour and environmental rights.  In Peru, civil society is making use of formal channels of participation and has requested an investigation that would have been unthinkable in the absence of this Agreement.  Without further delay, I believe that in all countries independent advisory groups should be set up to ensure the participation of civil society in the follow-up to the Agreements. Because when we see human tides migrating from Central America seeking a better life and come up with a wall, or when we denounce the violation of human rights in Nicaragua, or when we strongly defend the peace agreement reached with Colombia, we need to be very aware of the tools provided by trade agreements and seek their full effectiveness.  That is why, from the S&D Group, I call for the greatest efforts to fully implement these Agreements and to review them, to make them more effective and inclusive, including a chapter for SMEs; another to combat corruption, fraud and tax evasion; another on trade and gender; and also the possibility of implementing a sanctions-based mechanism, as a last resort if sustainable development clauses are breached. And—of what not!—the commitment to implement the Paris Agreement.  I sincerely believe that the European Union and Latin America share principles and values, and we have much to contribute for fairer and more inclusive trade. Let's make it possible, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The advancement of a values- and rules-based free trade policy is undoubtedly one of the European Union's greatest success stories. It is increasingly becoming a core competence of the Union with a liberal signature. We recently concluded what is arguably the most modern trade agreement in the world with Japan. SMEs are supported, digitisation is affirmed, with strong chapters on public procurement and sustainability. This is how we enface a modern trade policy.  More than five years after the conclusion, the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru is now in an important phase of implementation. It sets out common values and international standards for human and labour rights, as well as sustainable development, which offers immense future opportunities, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises in the partner countries. The strategic value of the agreement is high for Europe, because In Latin America, too, China is aggressively entering the markets and thus binds sales and partner markets in the long term, except that the Chinese do not rely on a trade policy based on values and rules. In Colombia in particular, the agreement with the peace process, which unfortunately has recently stalled again, must once again be actively supported. A stable Colombia is the economic anchor of this region. But the much smaller market in Central America must not be overlooked from an EU point of view either. The Association Agreement does not always work well in terms of trade relations. Tariff quotas are not being fully utilised and European products and services still do not have satisfactory access to Central American markets. However, we are counting on constructive cooperation and also on improvements in the future. Europe must once again become a continent of opportunity, because strong global trade relations are an important building block for this.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is a bit inconvenient to discuss in such a joint debate such vastly different countries like Colombia, Peru and Central America, and I wish that you could keep the tradition of bringing compact individual implementation reports from a precise country to us so we could discuss them in depth, but I’d like to thank Mr Böge for his very balanced report on Central America. We see very important notions there, for instance the reference to the special production zones and that the trade preferences should not be used there. But let me also express my strong concern on developments in Guatemala and the expulsion of the UN International Commission against impunity, which is a very serious deterioration of the political and business climate in the country. I think we need to be much more stringent on such developments. On Colombia and Peru. On Colombia I think it is now time to activate the human rights clause proper because there are so many killings of human rights activists. And Commissioner, I’d like to hear from you about the complaint by the Peruvian trade unions on their suspected lowering of environmental and social standards, due allegedly to the free trade agreement. How has the Commission followed up this interesting complaint by the Peruvian trade unions?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done 2019 is only two weeks old, and six human rights activists have already been murdered in Colombia. The horrific record of political assassinations in 2018 continues. Why does the Commission not mention these facts in its balance sheet of our trade relations with Colombia and Peru?  The climate of violence, repression and murder is not a side issue. Our trade policy, based on values and rules, requires clear announcements: the agreement must be suspended until the human rights situation improves significantly. The fact remains that the agreement has so far brought little economic support to the majority of the Colombian population, and domestic advisory groups should be given more space here.  If we, as the EU, remain inactive, there is a threat of an increase in violence, the erosion of human rights and the further destruction of the environment, not only in Colombia, the Andean region or Central America. I would also like to make it quite clear that the election of Mr Bolsonaro as Brazilian President and his announced regulations threaten to clash with the interests of the indigenous people and climate protection – not only in the region, but in a global sense. With a man who speaks only contemptuously about human rights and environmental protection, we in the European Union cannot negotiate a trade agreement with Mercosur.  Now, I think, is the moment for a signal from Europe, both there and here.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an additional ingredient that is added to this explosive cocktail and adds to the others, including the Mercosur agreement. This will have terrible consequences for our agricultural and fisheries sectors, for our overseas territories, particularly with regard to bananas, sugar and rum, of course, and for the health of consumers in general.  Colombia, as you all know, is an economic heavyweight that does not respect health standards, environmental standards, human rights, children's rights or labour law. Trade unionists are murdered, drug cartels are still thriving and access to health is highly unequal. In Peru, nearly 3 million children between the age of 6 and 17 work outside of any legal framework and without any social protection.  You develop slavery and famine in these third countries, you ruin the health of our fellow citizens and you destroy our chains. Merchants of everything, do nothing. These negotiations benefit multinationals and are against the people.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Dear President, Peru is one of the fastest growing countries in the region and Colombia's third largest economy in Latin America. That is why the implementation of the EU agreement with them is important for the European Union as a whole. We strongly support the Colombia peace agreement, and in this context it is particularly important to make effective use of the trade agreement in order to facilitate the implementation of the peace agreement.  Both countries are strongly affected by the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela, both countries have welcomed large numbers of migrants, which needs to be assessed. On the other hand, it is positive that Ecuador has acceded to the agreement and that the agreement is open to other countries in the region.  Here I want to thank my colleague, Santiago Fis, for a comprehensive report listing areas where further progress is needed. In addition, a complete list of areas to be included in the agreement, such as the chapter on the fight against corruption, money laundering and tax evasion, has been listed. This may be done by means of the possibility of reviewing the Agreement.  Let's take advantage of those opportunities.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, the implementation of the sustainability chapter in the agreement with Peru and Colombia does not work at all. Violations of human rights and trade union rights occur time and again. Since the beginning of 2019, there have already been six murder victims. There is an urgent need for action here.  After the conclusion of trade agreements, it is our task that we monitor implementation, especially in the area of sustainability chapters. We cannot conclude contracts, be proud of the inclusion of a roadmap for respect for human rights and then stop worrying about follow-up. That is why it is important that we talk today about the implementation of the agreements and also mention the problems by name.  Finally, I would like to stress once again that existing rules cannot be enforced without sanctions for violations of human rights, social or environmental standards. It is therefore essential to include sanctions in the sustainability chapters.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Madam President, as we discuss how to use tariff preferences, the human rights situation in Central America is terrifying. Particularly serious are the cases of Nicaragua, Guatemala and Honduras. In particular, the expulsion of Guatemala from the International Commission Against Impunity is a heavy blow to justice. And the sad thing is that it will be good news for organizations that benefit from corruption and impunity. We should be ashamed that some of these organisations are named after European companies or their subsidiaries. It is unacceptable that only trade is operational from the three pillars of the agreement, and it is symptomatic of what are the priorities of this model of the European Union, neoliberal and extractivist. Trade is urgently needed that puts people and the planet at the centre, but for real and at once, through binding human rights and environmental clauses. We welcome this report being clear in this area, but we regret that the text is hating the terrible situation in Central America today in terms of human rights, indigenous rights and land rights.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, once again we are presented with yet another trade agreement between the European Union and an area of third countries. The issue is worrying and includes negative points, such as a huge trade deficit against the European Union, a totally deficient overall estimate of trade flows and a lack of protection - as is specified - of the geographical indications of European products. While it is smaller than the Mercosur agreement, this new agreement contains a number of major hidden flaws. Central America is fully integrated into the large Continental American market, such as Bayer Monsanto's transgenic seeds, Mexican giant SuKarne's beef transiting through Nicaragua, or transgenic salmon passing, without a bad pun, through the Panama Canal. Once again, we must say no to such an agreement in the name of our agriculture, our independence and our food security, as well as our commercial interests.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, these agreements are laudable as they strengthen the process of regional integration between Central American countries, ensuring fairer and more inclusive trade and promoting sustainable economic growth in the region.  It is true, as Santiago Fisas said, that it has been advantageous to all parties, it is also true that the agricultural sector that pays the bills of these Agreements, emblematic products of the outermost regions , such as bananas, tomato or sugar – have been harmed.  In the case of bananas, while safeguard clauses and a stabilisation mechanism were established as counterparts, which, by the way, ends this year and should be extended, the reality is that it has never been activated so far, even though the thresholds have been far exceeded.  An example: in September 2018, Nicaragua and Guatemala exceeded their thresholds – 349% and 102%, respectively – and Peru has repeatedly exceeded it in the last four years without any action. And I am concerned that this has negative consequences for Community banana producers. We are talking about implementation; I hope it will be accompanied by appropriate measures.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, Latin America is a key partner for the European Union. It is a geopolitical partner, also a commercial partner. These agreements make that relationship easier for us. I thank the rapporteurs for having the intelligence to propose a reflection on them. My contributions are, in relation to Colombia, that the agreement with Colombia has to be closely linked to the peace agreement. Europe must press the Colombian government to deal with a wave of violence, again, against human rights defenders, which is not compatible with an economic and political agreement like the one we have with Colombia. That is why Europe has to establish a link between the two agreements, and I believe that in Central America, as has been said, it is particularly about agreements with Nicaragua, Honduras and Guatemala, three very poor countries with many internal problems. We have to help them. I think more than sanctioning, we have to help. These countries need agreements to be an instrument for them to become fully democratic countries.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, Latin America and the European Union have great potential for cooperation on a range of global challenges, especially on trade. As such, we need to strengthen these relations through an extended dialogue on politics, social inclusion and economic and trade relations. As we can see, EU trade with the region has doubled in the past decade. The EU holds preferential trade agreements with 26 of the 33 countries from the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States, including the free trade agreements with Colombia and Peru. These agreements provide for progressive and shared liberalisation through a comprehensive and balanced free trade area. I cannot stress enough that the strategic values of the agreement extend beyond the sphere of trade, as it provides a solid foundation for a deeper relationship with a long—term commitment to human rights, social rights, the rights of indigenous peoples and farmers, and obviously the environment. This furthers trade, attracts investment to these countries and, as a consequence, helps local businesses develop the strength in their regional markets to compete internationally. It’s also an opportunity for the EU, leading to additional growth and wealth while also representing unquestionable geopolitical benefits.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, I am very happy to be able to speak here, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and as a Belgian just before the end of the debate.  It goes without saying that I am in favour of free trade and that we need to develop good relations with our Latin American partners, as I think the European Commission is just doing. However, we also expect the same ambitions of our partners in this case. It is therefore very surprising in Belgium to see that Colombia has recently taken anti-dumping measures against frozen fries. It could be said that the dossier has only a marginal interest in the broader framework. Indeed, the measures are limited in time and the levies are relatively low. One might also laugh that the Belgians come to talk about their fries again. But we need to talk about the principles here. The method is, first of all, very questionable and therefore all the more destructive for our processors and our farmers, who have to adapt their processes each time. Secondly, this is a dossier in which, in my opinion, Europe can – and above all must – show that we are fighting for our people. Not only the big ones, but also the little ones. In any case where a European farmer or family entrepreneur is treated unfairly, it is our job to protect them. That is why, as the Commissioner responsible, I am clearly asking you not to count down and to raise this matter urgently with the World Trade Organisation.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, I always stress the importance of relations between the European Union and Latin America. In today's world, European and Latin American countries are natural allies and we need to strengthen our ties. In the current context, where protectionist forces grow, we must continue to defend the advantage of balanced and mutually beneficial trade agreements.  Agreements with Latin American countries contribute to their economic growth, to the modernization of their economies and also to the diversification of their exports.  As far as European countries are concerned, we need to export. Our population does not grow; nor does domestic consumption, as a result of the aftermath of the crisis, nor does public spending increase because of fiscal consolidation needs. Therefore, foreign markets are essential for European countries and for creating jobs.  Finally, I would like to request once again the conclusion of the negotiations on the Trade Agreement with Mercosur. Commissioner Malmstrom, who is playing such a good role in this portfolio, is fully aware that we are facing a historic opportunity and we do not have to waste it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Malmstrom, as a European socialist I am strongly in favour of an association agreement with Central America and Latin America containing clauses on sustainable development, anti-corruption and gender equality. As a Spanish socialist, I whole of course support to make Central and Latin America a strategic partner of the European Union. But as a socialist living in an outermost region, the Canary Islands, I express my concern about the impact on particularly sensitive products and sectors. Because I link this agreement with the Regulation on Safeguard Clauses between Trade Relations, which provides exactly for compensation mechanisms where that impact is negative for sensitive products in the outermost regions. I believe that nothing harms both European construction and divorce between what the European Union promises and what the European Union actually does. If it promises compensation to particularly sensitive sectors that are harmed by trade agreements, the European Union has an obligation to compensate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are discussing the European Union's trade agreements with latin American countries and association agreements, but it is a given that these countries must comply with certain standards, certain clauses. First of all the protection of the environment. Secondly, to ensure the protection of human rights. Also, labour standards, because otherwise we have a pronounced social dumping. These are issues that need to be taken seriously. The European Union must also insist that the protection of local people should be protected, that they should not be grabbed by the land, that there should be a restriction on the promiscuity of multinational enterprises, and of course that we should send a message about protection and gender equality. It is obvious from the attitudes that have been made that there are also negative effects on the European economy. We must take all this seriously in the way in which these trade agreements will be implemented.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, in such a report, in a debate which touches these parts of the world, what would have been serious in this Parliament is to have a debate on each of the regions, on each of the territorial areas on which this part of the world is being debated and not such a broad joint debate for what this part of the world deserves , so important also to us and its inhabitants. Nor does it seem very serious to our group that the European Commission should carry out a review of trade agreements at the conclusion of trade agreements, but we demand that it also be done during their implementation. I am referring specifically to the report on Peru and Colombia voted in 2013 in this Parliament, which provoked strong opposition from European society, but also strong opposition from a large part of the civil society of these countries. I am also referring to the situation in Panama, which is frankly overlooked in the report on Central America, because a central issue has been forgotten, which is the issue of tax havens and the impact of the effect of Panama's papers. That is why we are calling for a review of the areas of anti-corruption, money laundering and tax evasion. We love to drink bananas from Honduras; we love to drink Colombian coffee, but we are deaf in the face of money laundering in Panama.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, we cannot have a debate about trade agreements without discussing the very worrying situation in Nicaragua, where attacks against the independent press and critical voices in civil society are becoming more and more intense, with threatened and real violence against journalists and NGOs in particular. Press freedom is one of the cornerstones of democracies, and the EU must use its political influence to ensure its partners respect their international human rights obligations.  The Commission continues to present trade policy as one of the best ways to promote human rights at the international level. But the results are not here. The EU must stop prioritising its own home-grown investors over human rights concerns. Putting in place binding rules that oblige companies to respect human rights is very urgent, and we in this House voted for that in October. So let’s step up to the mark.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Hello Sir, hello Sir! If possible, I wanted to inform you, because before i was coming I watched the internet, that the British House of Commons had rejected the divorce agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom. In this regard, the Prime Minister announced a discussion tomorrow on the votum of confidence in the government. This is important information that may not have arrived here. That's why I let myself start with that. (No more room requests)

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are not discussing the Mercosur agreement today. There is no agreement yet, but I will be happy to come back to the plenary to discuss this when there is one – very soon, I hope.
