But what we are discussing are these two Agreements and it’s of course up to the Parliament how you want to organise the debates. With a regional agreement it can be difficult to discuss every country per se, but the Commission has just launched preparations to do full evaluations of both these Agreements and we will be looking into every country.  We can say that on trade these Agreements have delivered, a lot, but there is of course still much to do. As has been said by the two rapporteurs, we need to focus on implementation. There is work to do on SMEs, as you said. We have been focusing a lot to give special attention to the small and medium—sized companies in the countries we discuss through dedicated information on our website. We have the Market Access Database with the latest information on tariffs, rules of origin, statistics and different requirements and we are trying to put our companies together with the Latin American companies.  These Agreements are good in a way, but they are a little old. That is true. They were concluded in 2010, almost 10 years ago. Today, we would have asked to put other things and additional things in them and we will reflect with our partners on how to do that at a future stage. There are concerns about human rights in many of these countries. I fully agree that the situation in Nicaragua, for instance, is of great concern. We have raised it and, apart from these Agreements, there are different tools where we can address it and I know that the foreign affairs ministers will discuss Nicaragua in particular at their next meeting – I think next week – and possibly there will be a statement at that point as well. We are raising this in the Human Rights Dialogue on a regular basis and we are engaging with the countries, but we should also not deny that there has been some progress. I have been engaging particularly with Peru on the issue that Ms Hautala – who is no longer here – raised, on the labour issues, and they have started to engage with civil society, starting a dialogue on these issues, which is good. There are other examples as well. On the banana issues: as you know the conditions to suspend temporarily the preferences for bananas are defined in the Agreement. That is not an automatic decision. It depends on the impact of the imports on the stability of the EU market and each time that those thresholds have been exceeded for Central America, including last year, from the Commission side we have made an in-depth analysis and we have concluded that the excessive imports did not cause any destabilisation of the EU markets and had very little impact on the prices either. But we will continue to monitor this.  On the issue of frozen fries, as the Belgian gentleman mentioned, we are of course very much aware of this. We have raised it with the Colombian authorities several times and I do share concerns here. There also seems to be a problem of how they had been calculating it so we will be engaging with them in Bogota next week or at end of this month, with the trade team of the Colombian authorities to look at this in detail. We will keep you informed about the evaluation of these issues. So, as I said, we will launch a comprehensive evaluation of both these Agreements. We will be happy to share those results with Parliament and to come back and discuss these issues at a later stage.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I wanted to thank Commissioner Malmstrom and all my colleagues for their interesting contributions to this afternoon's debate. Latin America is a friendly region, to which we are joined by very strong historical ties. The trade agreements we have just discussed only strengthen this relationship and give a perspective on the strategic and geopolitical importance it has for the European Union. Dear and appreciated Helmut, I know there are many things to improve, but you have to see where they came from and where they are now. Suspending treaties would only make the situation worse, as Ramon Jáuregui has said very well. And it is true, dear Gabriel, dear Juan Fernando, that you have to be very vigilant on the banana issue. We have also been explained what measures the Commission is taking, as Commissioner Malmstrom has just told us. Since Peru and Colombia, and Ecuador as a recent incorporation, are strategic regions for the European Union, it is essential to continue to push the agreement forward so that it can reach its full potential. And we must remember that the agreement remains open to new additions, as it provides for an accession clause that leaves open the door to participation in it by other member countries of the Andean Community of Nations. And I would not like to end my speech without thanking all my colleagues in the Committee on International Trade, and in particular the shadow rapporteurs — a special mention of Inmaculada Rodríguez - Piñero who, with his contributions and help, has enabled a balanced and positive report which I hope will be adopted in the House tomorrow, with broad support.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the In view of the diversity of justified criticism and comments, I would like to say first of all where we have many construction sites in relation to what we have negotiated with our partner countries. Yes, we must approach this with vigour, but also with a sense of proportion. And I would like to say explicitly, Commissioner, that I believe that you and your team have done a really good job in the area of trade policy in recent years. I would like to express my agreement with my colleague, who said: yes, we must also look at where our partners come from and not only demand the absoluteness of 100% implementation, but also see how we develop, how progress progress is made, and that too must be properly taken into account. I come to another point. When I look at the fact that the very countries we have been talking about here, namely Peru and Colombia – Peru alone 500 000 and Colombia over one million – have taken in refugees from Venezuela, these countries are almost on the verge of collapse in their fragile situation. Are we doing enough together with the UNHCR, or are we still doing too little? We have a damn duty and guilt as the European Union to take care of this situation and to ensure that the departure into dictatorial regimes does not poison and destroy the entire neighbourhood of Latin and South America. Then all our efforts will be done overnight. And here, I believe, we have another task in the Commission – not only in trade policy – to insist very precisely that what we are asking for is actually implemented everywhere, and in view of the arrogance of the United States not to pretend, in the face of the cancellation of the Trans-Pacific Trade Agreement, that we simply casually leave this continent to the arrogance of large neighbours or even the insistence of other important partners such as China. Our partners expect something very different from us, and that is something we should think about.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. The Association Agreement between the European Union and Central America, the first genuine interregional association agreement ratified by the European Union, despite the complexities of the international economic framework, has undoubtedly produced positive developments in the field of trade policy. However, the failure to implement the pillars of political dialogue and cooperation has not led to significant progress in promoting democracy and the rule of law. Five years after its entry into force, the agreement should therefore be updated by introducing a dispute settlement mechanism that even provides for the use of sanctions in the event of serious human rights violations; and the European Union should support the Central American states to promote legislative reforms aimed at preventing and eradicating widespread phenomena such as child labour and violence against trade unionists, human rights defenders or indigenous peoples. Finally, I would like to stress that among the provisions to be updated in order to make the agreement more effective, those concerning small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) stand out so that they can benefit from the benefits of the agreement. The Commission should promote information campaigns on the opportunities arising from the agreement and develop legal, financial and administrative instruments to support the internationalisation of SMEs.

name: David McALLISTER
text: in writing. – In November 2018 I chaired a delegation of the AFET and INTA committees to Buenos Aires to participate in the first ever ‘Parliamentary Forum in the context of the G-20 Leaders’ Summit’. The additional discussions with Argentine interlocutors were mainly dominated by the EU-Mercosur Association Agreement. Its relevance has been clearly demonstrated to me. However, the European Union must not only remain committed to a promising and speedy conclusion of new ambitious and comprehensive agreements. The successful implementation of already existing settlements is equally important. Among other things, our focus should lie on the agreements between the EU and Colombia and Peru and on the EU-Central America Association Agreement, all signed in 2012. In this context, regarding the latest implementation reports, regional cooperation as well as bilateral cooperation is progressing, bringing benefits to both sides. However, further progress is needed, especially in terms of money laundering and tax evasion. In addition, neither Latin America nor the EU make full use of their granted tariff rate quotas. Therefore, potential sectors should be identified to excite further exchanges. Latin America is a key partner for our European Union and, at present, the EU has enormous opportunities to strengthen its close cooperation with the region.

name: Bogusław SONIK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The EU-Central America Association Agreement was the first interregional agreement of its kind concluded by the EU and its trade pillar has been provisionally applied for five years. Trade flows between the parties have proved to be resilient to adverse trends in the world economy, but the tariff quotas agreed in the agreement are not fully exploited by the parties and products exported by Central American countries are only beginning to diversify. In this respect, it would be worth identifying potential sectors that should be encouraged for more exchanges. Parliament has repeatedly encouraged the Commission to strengthen the monitoring and implementation of trade and sustainable development chapters, including an effective mechanism for enforcing commitments in the field of labour standards and environmental protection. I am therefore convinced that the Commission's 15-point plan in this area is a step in the right direction.  In view of the current political and social situation in central American countries, a review of the agreement with a view to introducing an effective dispute settlement mechanism, including sanctions in the event of serious infringements, is most needed. I hope that, in the near term, all the provisions on the trade pillar of this agreement can be fully implemented and that Austria, Belgium and Greece will ratify the Association Agreement so that the political pillar and cooperation can be applied within the framework of this agreement.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Maria Arena, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) (COM(2018)0380 - C8-0231/2018 - 2018/0202(COD)) (A8-0445/2018).

name: Maria ARENA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, is a solidarity fund, which is important to point out, which provides assistance to workers who are victims of corporate restructuring linked to the opening of the economy to globalisation. For more than a decade, this fund has been able to support more than 150,000 workers in more than 150 cases of corporate restructuring, and in most Member States. In addition, there are 4,000 NEETs, those young people who are not trained and have no jobs, and who today have also benefited from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Despite an initially available budget of 500 million euros per year, its use has remained low, not because its action is irrelevant, quite the contrary, but because its organization is complex. Moreover, the commission's proposal was well received by the European Parliament. It has been changed a little at the margin, but there has generally been a broad consensus to be able to work on this proposal on your part. Indeed, the threshold for the number of workers affected was too large and we worked on that reduction. You have proposed a threshold of eligibility; we propose to set it at 200 workers, not 200 workers from the same company but 200 affected workers in several companies. On the other hand, globalization is not the only adjustment factor in our economy. Technological changes, energy transitions and ecological transitions, which are also important in the context of corporate restructuring, must also be taken into account. Co-financing must also be a determining factor, or the multi-sector or multi-regional approach. All these changes are aimed at improving the effectiveness of the fund currently known as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which we propose to call the Transition Fund. I would like to add a dimension that could not be taken into account in the fund, but for which I will table an amendment in plenary tomorrow. For while it is important to help workers in the context of a restructuring - I would even say that it is essential, because if globalisation makes a winner, it also makes a loser and European solidarity is necessary - it also seems useful, in the context of a major restructuring, in a region of Europe weakened, for example, by high unemployment rates or low employment rates. , or even in regions affected successively by several restructurings, it also seems important to me to help local economic actors cope with traumas such as major corporate restructurings, to reposition and remobilize the strengths, strategies and intelligences of a territory. I often give the example of the caterpillar company in Belgium, in Charleroi, which actually created retraining cells to accompany workers, to give them the opportunity to find a job, but which also created a cell - the CATCH cell - which was added to the conversion cell. Bringing together universities, businesses and local economic players, it has helped to retrain and remobilize forces after a trauma like this. As a result, the employment rate of workers, as well as the wealth of the territory, have been improved.  Therefore, I will propose this amendment tomorrow because it is true that it has sometimes been difficult to convince my colleagues to go in this direction. It is an amendment that should help us to take territorial development into account. However, this territorial development in Europe is extremely important. There are rich territories in Europe, and there are neglected territories, and we cannot leave them alone in this despair. So I think it is important to be able to table this amendment and support it. I hope that I will have the support of the various groups for this amendment.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, since 2007 the European Globalisation Fund has been a key European instrument to show solidarity with workers who have lost their jobs due to globalisation, related changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis. Since its launch in 2007, the Fund has mobilised EUR 631 million for 160 cases targeting almost hundred 150 000 dismissed workers, including NEETs in the most recent years at least. But the world of work has changed significantly since then, and it is high time to update the EGF Regulation to reflect better the current economic and social context. Therefore, I am pleased to see that, overall, the European Parliament supports our proposal for the Globalisation Fund Regulation for the next MFF. In particular, I welcome the fact that Parliament supports the wider scope and the lowering of the thresholds that we proposed. I warmly thank the rapporteur, Ms Maria Arena, and all the members of the Employment Committee and the associated committee for their hard work on this file and I particularly welcome the speed with which Parliament proceeded. Parliament has made various amendments, and I welcome a number of them as they clarify our texts or usefully add to or change elements. On some other amendments we have hesitations, and I’m grateful for the possibility to mention two of them here. One of the key features of our proposal was the accelerated mobilisation procedures. Reintroducing the same mobilisation procedures as in the current regulation will make it impossible to reduce the length of the procedure, and therefore we would lose the opportunity to mobilise the funds and actually help displaced workers more swiftly.  We also have hesitations as regards the further lowering of the threshold of these placements and extending the reference periods. The EGF interventions are justified by the major adverse shock on the local economy caused by dismissals. If we further reduce the already low threshold proposed by the Commission – we go from 500 to 250 in our proposal – then we risk diluting the argument of a major shock and call into question the EU added value. I am eager to listen to the debate. I thank you already for all the work you have done so far.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, the European Union's trade agreements still lack enforceable mechanisms to protect labour and environmental standards. We cannot therefore speak of a trade that benefits everyone.  The aim of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to support those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation, trade liberalisation or technological development. Reality shows that there are always winners, but also losers, and that trade profits are not evenly distributed between the Member States, the regions, but also within society.  Despite the relatively small budget and complex procedures, the Fund has produced tangible results for more than 140 000 workers from across the European Union since its inception. As the fund is not being fully used up, we would like to simplify the application procedures. Member States should be supported in their application and the scope should be broadened and made more flexible.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, three principal points from the Committee on Budgetary Control. First, particular emphasis shall lie on measures that help the most disadvantaged groups and on Member States and the regions that have been hardest hit and where the national and regional authorities lack adequate resources for taking the necessary measures. Whenever the cessation of activity concerns a profit—making enterprise, the company concerned shall contribute to the reintegration of displaced workers, preferably in the context of a social plan. Third, should the Commission implement technical assistance under indirect management, it shall ensure the transparency of the procedure for designating the third party responsible for carrying out the task assigned to it, and shall inform the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) stakeholders, including the European Parliament, of the sub—contractors selected for that purpose.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Dear Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. As responsible for the opinion given by the Committee on Regional Development to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, my work was guided by three objectives. Firstly, reduce the current redundancy threshold of 250 to 150. Secondly, the beneficiaries should be extended to workers who have not yet been laid off, but their dismissal has already been decided. Last but not least, the processing time for applications should be as short as possible. We still feel it's important to do something bigger. Lowering the redundancy threshold to 150 is important because small and medium-sized enterprises rarely have a redundancy threshold of 200 or 250, and the labour market in smaller EU Member States requires this level. We therefore consider it important to lower the threshold to 150.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, in fact, the European Globalisation Fund has received support from well over 100 000 people who have lost their jobs throughout the European Union over more than a decade and, as we continue to work with the Globalisation Fund, we would like us to take a few steps forward in improving the way in which support is received for people who have lost their jobs, so that these people get support more quickly, that their applications are dealt with much more quickly, and it is particularly important to promote gender equality in this area and gender equality. For example, support for people who have lost their jobs should aim at reducing significant gender inequalities in information and communication technologies and science, engineering and mathematics. This could be done by promoting the retraining of women precisely in these areas, traditionally still male-dominated, which, among other things, are generally and much better paid and should also support the provision of care services for dependants, so that women seeking or relocating jobs receive truly comprehensive help and that this is truly effective in real life.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, the European Globalisation Fund is no more. At least, that is the case if the negotiations go well, if tomorrow's vote in the European Parliament goes well. From 2020-2021, we will be talking about the European Transition Fund: a name that I think covers the flag much better.  Initially, the fund was intended to provide support to people who lose their jobs due to structural changes due to globalisation or the financial and economic crisis. In my country, I think everyone knows the example of Ford Genk or, more recently, Caterpillar, as our rapporteur mentioned.  After a decade, we have to admit that the fund was in need of a thorough overhaul. I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on the good proposal. The budget was not used up for a long time and the instrument was actually partially missing its target. One of the problems clearly appeared to be the scope: that was far too scary. That's why we're expanding the scope with automation and digitisation.  In addition, a round of redundancies had to be at least 500 redundancies. In some, mostly less populated areas, that threshold was still far too high. It is precisely in those regions that extra training, extra reorientation is most needed. So the accessibility really had to go up. That is why I am pleased that we in Parliament have succeeded in reducing it to 200.  But we also want to reduce the administrative burden considerably. We will now only have to count redundancies in a particular area and sector to know whether they are eligible. That makes sense: a fired employee wants a new job as soon as possible. No comprehensive analysis of job loss is required.  Last but not least, the European Transition Fund will take into account the impact of Brexit. In my region alone, a no deal will create 28 000 jobs. This is a transition in which we can use all European aid.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, if many people lose their jobs at the same time in a region in Europe, that whole region will be dealt a blow at the same time. In such exceptional situations, people must be able to count on Europe's support and solidarity more quickly.  We know that employment is going to change – and is already changing – because of all kinds of technological developments, international competition and globalisation. And because we have to adapt to climate change, which will have an effect on the labour market. We should not leave people affected by this alone. We must work to give them a new opportunity. People can count on our support to get back to work. They could use that support. Vote for the European Transition Fund.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, set up in 2007, is now expected to be stronger and more efficient and, importantly, to provide more effective support for workers who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation. Therefore, workers will be able to receive support from the Fund if they have lost their jobs as a result of restructuring due, for example, to job automation or digitalisation, and not so far only because of the financial and economic crisis. It is proposed to reduce the support threshold to 250 redundancies. They are also intended to be simplified and shortened application procedures. This is a good plan, but it is mandatory to implement supervision and control and the principle of equality between employees of large companies and employees of small businesses, so that the larger ones do not abuse this mechanism. So far, 11 Member States have applied for assistance from the Fund. It is worth noting the amounts received by some countries. For example, France – more than EUR 100 million, small Ireland – EUR 68 million, Denmark, Greece and Belgium. Poland received €2.5 million from this Fund. I wonder why the previous government in Poland did not benefit from this Fund when, in 2008, 4,500 shipbuilders lost their jobs as a result of the decommissioning of shipyards in Szczecin and Gdynia.

name: Mirja VEHKAPERÄ
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund was originally set up to support citizens who became unemployed as a result of major structural changes caused by globalisation. EU citizens have been able to benefit from re-employment and training. Today's employment crises, however, are not only due to changes in globalisation. Digitalisation and automation bring pressure for change in many sectors. A lot of people fear for their jobs. The new, more flexible fund will respond better to new challenges and help employees better equip themed for future needs. The Fund is by nature a crisis fund. However, many of the Commission's reform proposals would make substantial changes to this and must be treated with certain reservations. For example, it has now been possible to apply for support for redundancies of more than 500 people. The Commission would halve the threshold, and Parliament has had a desire to reduce it to as many as 200. It is true that in many regions of the EU the majority work in small and medium-sized enterprises. They are affected by the crisis throughout the region. However, the criteria should not be over-loosened. If the Fund provides support for an increasing number of ever smaller projects, the Crisis Fund is in danger of becoming something of a non-stop tool. Small projects require as much governance as large ones, so the number of administrations would increase. This fund responds to unforeseen circumstances. It is important that it is flanked by a forward-looking regional and cohesion policy that anticipates the changing needs of employment and regions. I also hope to support EDA's amendments, which would allow support from the Fund for those who lose their jobs as a result of Brexit. Brexit may have as much impact as any other structural change. Of course, the criteria for the aid must be met in other respects.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Globalisation Fund is, after all, renamed the European Transitional Fund. We Greens are very much in support of this. We would have liked to see a further change to 'fair transition' to show even better that sustainable, good, sustainable and high-quality jobs are at stake. For us, the future European Transitional Fund is a very important social and labour market governance instrument, because it directly benefits workers, and we do not have as many instruments in the European Union. That is why it is an essential building block for social Europe as a whole.  I am very pleased that we have been able to achieve many improvements in joint work that the Fund will have in the future; on the one hand, that it is becoming much more forward-looking, because digitalisation, but also the transformation of the economy into a low-carbon economy, is seen as an opportunity and not as a problem that there is retraining for jobseekers for future-oriented industries, especially for green jobs, that NEETs, i.e. young people who are not in education, work or training, can also be included. We also like the increased co-financing rates or the reduced intervention criteria for the number of workers made redundant and we hope that there will be a majority in favour of this. Unfortunately, however, we will not be able to go along with the rapporteur's amendment, because we think it is important – as I have already said – that the EGF funds go directly to workers and not to institutions such as those promoted by the Social Fund, for example, but, of course, overall: broad support from the Greens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are monitoring many of the rapporteur's proposals which make improvements to the Commission's proposal. But let us be clear: such improvements do not change the framework of the fund. It is little more than a palliative that does not solve the problems of closure and relocation resulting from the enlargement of the single market, the strategy of concentrating capital for the accumulation of profits, the deregulation of labour and the incessant demand for cheap labour. Let triumph workers or so many other thousands of workers say so that in Portugal they have seen the job extinguished so that multinationals would increase their profits.  The fund legitimizes the policies of dismissals and unaccountability of multinationals in the preservation of the employment generated. Moreover, its budget remains limited, especially in view of the increase in scope, while right-wing and European Union policies limit the taking of measures by States to support workers in maintaining their jobs.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, amendments 97 and 98 speak on the impact of the UK’s withdrawal on the EU economy, and it is topical because in the last hour we’ve seen the British House of Commons overwhelmingly reject Theresa May’s Brexit deal in the biggest defeat for any government in British history. This is right. It is right to say that Brexit will impact the UK and it will impact the EU, and I do wish that there were a credible deal on the table. So I really don’t know what to do when it comes to this vote on the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Changing the name of the Fund won’t change the issue. I’d love to be able to say that this covers the period 2021 to 2027, but this has not one iota of relevance to the UK. How can I say that British MEPs should simply abstain because it’s none of our business what happens in the European Union post-Brexit and post-transition and we shouldn’t be telling the EU what to do? How can I say that when anti-democratic forces in the UK have used May’s appalling deal as an excuse to continue to campaign to erode that withdrawal itself? In this case, it’s simply an inefficient use of taxpayers’ money in Britain. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund simply means that we’re sending money to the European Union to then apply for it back with strings attached, and then to lose two thirds of that from the following year’s rebate. That, Mr President, simply makes no sense, and to me the whole premise of this Fund is fundamentally flawed.

name: David CASA
text: – Sur President, l-Ewropa gťandha diversi miżuri ta' sapport gťall-ekonomija u l-ťaddiema tagťha. Filwaqt li miżuri bťal dawn, bťalma huwa l-Fond Sożjali Ewropew, huma ta' natura strateżika u ppjanati gťat-tul, hemm oťrajn bťall-Fond Globali Ewropew illi jaťdmu b'mod. name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, globalisation has frequently had negative effects on the maintenance of our production and social protection systems, so Europe's role should be to protect its citizens from these negative effects, to offer shelter against unfair competition, to promote a future of sustainable growth that puts people at the centre.  For these reasons, I would like to remind you of the importance of this fund, which has so often already given concrete support to territories and realities in difficulty. I welcome the result achieved by our group in lowering the minimum threshold for the activation of the fund and also the possibility of taking into account the more companies involved. Too often the cases of smaller realities have not been taken into account, but they would have deserved it because of the social impact on the territories, their size, the size of the territories, is obviously also related to the scale of the crisis.  We now need one more step, what Europeans are asking us to do: to turn this fund into a real fund for an ecological, socially just transition and towards a model of sustainable development. I believe that people, in this particular case the workers, must be at the centre of a new model of development that combines work and the environment.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that, when planning changes to the Globalisation Fund for the period 2021-2027, the European Commission has adequately addressed the new challenges emerging in the European labour market and the needs of European businesses. First of all, I would like to support the proposal that the Fund should support not only cases of mass redundancies resulting from relocation, but also the challenges of automation and digitalisation. In this respect, the Globalisation Fund – or, as proposed by the Committee on Employment, the Transition Fund – should work closely with the European Social Fund Plus, which is also intended to finance projects that prepare workers for new challenges. Experts estimate that many jobs may soon disappear due to automation, so the fund should respond to these challenges.  I would also like to give a positive view of the other changes that have been proposed and which are addressing workers and businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. The reduction in the number of redundant persons from 500 to 250 or even to 200, as the Committee on Employment wants, should be welcomed. I also support the idea of increasing the level of funding for actions taken by local authorities.  I would like to draw attention to Mrs Harkin's proposal that the fund should also support workers who lose their jobs as a result of... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Nothing is as constant as change. In a globalized economy, companies are constantly shifting jobs across the globe. There are winners and losers. For job losses in Europe, we want to ensure that mass redundancies and restructuring support people, businesses, industries and regions in their efforts to get people back to work. The Globalisation Fund makes a significant contribution to this by providing funding to companies, sectors and regions in the future for mass redundancies of more than 200 people. Funding that cushions such processes and opens up a new perspective for people is important. The issues of environmental regulations, ecology, economisation and digitalisation can lose their terror with parts of these funds. The Globalisation Fund must support a sustainable economy in a triad between economics, ecology and the social in the interests of the people.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Globalisation Aid Fund has shown its effectiveness since its creation in supporting laid-off workers as a result of a process of globalisation. We were able to adapt it to include the economic crisis, as a consequence for its intervention, and now we have done so again to include automation and digitization.  Technological evolution causes continuous changes in production processes, and it is our obligation to be up-to-date so that the policies we propose are in compliance with reality.  From the Union we must continue to invest in people and promote the improvement of their skills, particularly if we are talking about a significant number of laid-off workers.  I therefore consider it important that this Fund maintain its reactive nature and also support, like colleagues, the reduction of the threshold for dismissed workers for the Fund to become operational.  In this way it is better suited to the reality of European industrial fabrics, where mass layoffs are becoming less and less, and allows to enter small-scale labour markets.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, I rise exactly an hour since the House of Commons voted by an unprecedented majority to reject Theresa May’s Brexit deal. I rise in a debate about a European fund that puts central European money into places in our continent where people on a big scale are losing their jobs, and it gives them skills and it gives them direction back into work. I rise representing a constituency in the West Midlands of the UK disproportionately likely – according to the Centre for Cities – to find people losing their jobs due to digitalisation, due to platform working and so on; a constituency where our biggest employer, our most important private sector employer, last week, Jaguar Land Rover, promised 4 500 job losses. Of course, my constituents in the West Midlands will not profit from this fund, not now, not ever.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, in Europe it must not be just about currency, the market and money. It has to be about people. It is quite logical that we help people who have lost their jobs because of the crisis or globalisation on their way to a new job.  These are not abstract statistics or numbers. These are people from Drenthe in the Netherlands who lost their jobs at the V&D, people from Friesland who could no longer find work in the banking sector, people in the construction sector in Gelderland who lost their jobs in the crisis. Real people with real problems. It is important that the EU not only takes an eye for business but the problems of these people, and that it contributes to a solution. That is exactly what the Globalisation Fund does, in a successful and efficient way. It is also important that we send the message today that, as far as we are concerned, the EU will also be there in the coming years for people who need support.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Mr President, it has been more than ten years since the creation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. And, of course, as we all note, the situation has changed in the meantime, so it is right that the rules of operation of this fund should also be changed. I welcome, of course, the simplification of the rules and the new criteria and criteria for the beneficiaries. In this way, the changes will be of particular benefit to SMEs and to those countries where there are many small and medium-sized enterprises. However, in these attempts to lower the border, we could be even more ambitious. In my country, for example, according to the latest statistics, there are only 350 companies that would meet these new criteria, so they have more than 250 employees. The changes will also allow those employees who are affected by job losses as a result of digitisation and other new processes to access funding. However, as is the case with all scalps, it is right that the rules are simple, as simple as possible, but control must be as good as possible.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I support the proposal for a revision of the Regulation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, and I particularly appreciate the change concerning the reduction in the number of workers and the extension of the period during which it assesses whether the conditions have been met. It is from the point of view of smaller countries such as the Czech Republic that this change is for the better. In the future, this should facilitate the use and simplification of the application procedure by the Member State, as well as a reduction in the deadline for the Commission's examination of the application.  I also support Parliament's position that the Fund should finance employers' incentives to provide flexible working ves. This is important for parents, and these incentives make a lot of sense in terms of returning to work and for re-measing private and working lives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we are discussing the Fund to deal with the consequences of globalisation. I think he has proven that he really offered, supported the workers at a time when we had mass layoffs. I would say, of course, in the case of Greece that it was not used as much as it could. Because it can also be seen from the funds allocated to Greece, which were very little in relation to the total amount allocated. In any case, it is a fund that can support the regions, support small and medium-sized enterprises, enable a transition and, in this context, I believe that it should now also face the consequences of automation. Therefore, the measures proposed, to the extent that they are aimed purely at supporting small and medium-sized enterprises and, above all, at supporting the unemployed themselves, are very positive. The fact that the threshold should be lowered to the two hundred workers than the five hundred who were before is also very important. Let us consider reaching the threshold of all one hundred and fifty workers.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, the shock caused by local economies by redundancies is very great. The effects of economic globalisation impact on our territories. The shipbuilding workers of my city, Vigo, or Ferrol in Galicia are well known. The workers of the textile sector of Ordes, in A Coruña, know this well, and even if they never know what the fund of globalization is, the workers of Alcoa, an energy-intensive company, in A Coruña, in Avilés. The Commissioner knows about this problem and we will forward a proposal in the future. The Fund has not always been applied transparently and we therefore ask that the Commission be vigilant in implementing the fund, on transparency and on participation in trade union information. I will send you examples of the contrary, as happened in my country, Galicia, with the Galician government. I also draw attention to a fundamental problem, Commissioner: many companies have used the fund to not comply with the labour provisions to which they were obliged under the legislation of the Member State.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would, of course, like to express my support for this instrument and the instrument of European policy, because it actually helps disadvantaged groups of citizens. It also, of course, helps those regions affected by the effects of globalisation, as well as the sectors of our economy concerned.  I must say that I have seen from the outset that this globalisation fund was an excellent idea, and I think that if our European Union policy had addressed precisely these factors that affect the lives of people who lose their jobs, we could also eliminate the Very Brexit disputes. I am a little encouraged by the speech by my colleague Simon, I want to support him very much, I think that focusing on these factors that are deing ordinary people is at the heart of the European Union's interest and we should further deepen this instrument and work with it as a quality tool for improving the quality of life of citizens.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I welcome that Parliament will already adopt our proposal in first reading and I also welcome the fruitful discussions during this debate.  I think this shows that Parliament’s report will provide a solid foundation for the interinstitutional negotiations that will follow. As always, the Commission is open to discussions in the trilogues and will play its role as an honest broker. By revising this Regulation we have committed to giving the EGF the necessary framework to act in today’s world of work and I am happy that Parliament shares this Commission’s initiatives. Together we should fulfil our commitment in line with citizens’ expectations. I would like to thank Parliament once more for its continued support and for the swift adoption and I am confident that under the Romanian Presidency we shall reach a partial, general approach – this is on the provisional agenda of the Employment, Social Affairs, Health and Consumer Affairs Council (EPSCO) March meeting – so this is already an answer to one of the questions by the rapporteur.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all, I thank the Commission for taking this initiative. Without the Commission's initiative, it would have been difficult for us to work on improving the Fund , so I thank the Commission. I would also like to thank all the groups and rapporteurs who have worked with me on this new legislation. I will ask them again for a further effort in tomorrow's vote. Indeed, when working on the support of workers, it is, of course, important to train workers, but if there is no job creation in front of these workers, we are in difficulty with their reintegration into the workplace. I therefore think it is important to vote tomorrow on the amendment I am proposing to obtain this consideration. We need to move forward on two legs: trained workers on the one hand, and an offer of companies, on the other, which allows them to be integrated into the labour market. That is what my amendment is going to do, and I hope that it will be supported by all the groups that have supported the European Transition Fund.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 16 January 2019.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Verónica Lope Fontagné, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Social Fund Plus (COM(2018)0382 - C8-0232/2018 - 2018/0206(COD)) (A8-0461/2018).

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, before I begin my speech I would like to thank the other shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation during the negotiations, but I will refer to this later. The text presented by the Commission has also been of great help, as the merger of several funds within the European Social Fund, keeping its specific objectives intact, will help to reduce administrative barriers and simplify procedures. The linkage to the European Semester will give Member States flexibility to focus on the aspects they consider most necessary. We must remember that our citizens are the greatest asset that the Union has and that they must therefore be at the heart of our policies. It is true that economic recovery is a fact, but much remains to be done. Employment levels, particularly among young people, need to be increased, education and training systems modernized to meet labour market needs and lifelong learning, especially among older workers, need to be strengthened, and we need to combat poverty and social exclusion. But I would like to highlight the following points in the report. The percentage of funding that the ESF+ will allocate to social inclusion measures is increased to 27%, creating its own target groups such as the Roma community. An additional 3% will be allocated to support the most disadvantaged groups through basic material and food assistance and through accompanying measures aimed at improving their integration and participation in society. Young people are also the future of the Union and, therefore, its inclusion in society and the labour market is a priority for us. We propose that all Member States allocate at least 3% of their resources to nini support measures and that the Member States most affected, i.e. those with a rate above the European average, or above 15%, allocate at least 15%. Child poverty is another key point in the report. 26.4% of children in the Union are at risk of social exclusion. These are unacceptable rates. Child poverty hinders children's personal development and hinders their full inclusion in society. If we want to ensure that all European citizens enjoy equal opportunities, we have to work since childhood. That is why we are asking for the creation of a children's guarantee of 5.9 billion euros. Equality between men and women is another important item in the report. Article 6 sets out the necessary provisions to ensure their respect while proposing specific actions aimed at increasing women's participation in society. Full integration of people with disabilities is another key point. In addition to the continuing mentions in the United Nations Convention or respect for the principle of non-discrimination, the fund has its own specific objective of increasing accessibility to improve its inclusion in employment, education and training. And to conclude this first speech, I would like to talk about the social economy company. For the first time, a shared and common concept of social economy is introduced in the Regulation which will ensure greater legal certainty and serve other companies, particularly in countries such as Spain, Italy and Portugal, where the ESF is key, in their work with the most vulnerable people.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: rapporteur for the opinion, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, since 2003, the European Union has had three health sanctions programmes, which have had very good results. For the next financial framework, the Commission proposed that the previous health instrument should be part of the European Social Fund Plus as its 'health' component. The ENVI Commission supported the continuation of a separate health programme, which would have given a strong signal that health is a priority, especially since, according to the latest Eurobarometer, the majority of European citizens support the increased intervention of the European Union in the field of health. Regardless of whether it is a separate programme or part of the Social Fund, the most important thing is to have clear objectives and they are to be met. The main proposals adopted by the ENVI Commission, which had exclusive competences over the health component, were: increasing the health budget to EUR 473 million, access to sustainable and affordable quality care services, patient-centreding, encouraging disease prevention, early diagnosis, promoting lifelong health and setting up a Health Steering Committee, effectively developing work plans and maximising synergies with other programmes and tools in health is integrated.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I warmly welcome the political commitment shown and the hard work done by the European Parliament, the lead and the associated committees and, in particular, the rapporteur, Ms Lope Fontagné, in the swift preparation of Parliament’s report. You have really done your utmost to advance this legislative proposal within the term of this Parliament. I am very pleased that Parliament largely shares the Commission’s ambitions and objectives for the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+), an integrated fund with a substantial budget to implement the principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights, and linked to the European Semester. It is also a fund with simpler and more flexible management, and this will create more added value for its end-users, i.e. our citizen: for example, in modernising and improving the labour markets, ensuring good healthcare, targeting the assistance to those who need it most, and contributing to an overall stronger social dimension of the European Union. In short, the ESF+ will contribute to a more social Europe. Parliament has proposed various amendments. I welcome a number of them as they clarify our text or usefully add or change elements of it. There are some others on which we have hesitation. The thematic concentration requirements – in plain words, the earmarking of parts of the budget – are the focus of most of Parliament’s proposed amendments. Let me underline here that, in our view, pre-allocating ESF+ national envelopes even further than in our proposal would significantly reduce the flexibility of the fund. This would prevent Member States reacting to evolving social needs, something we know happens in reality. It would also limit the possibility of responding to particular issues which Member States are facing and which are identified in the European Semester process.  Turning to the specific amendment proposals related to the employment and social innovation (ESI) strand of the ESF+, our proposal seeks to bring this strand closer to the ESF. I note with satisfaction that Parliament supports the proposed merger of the funds. But let me again highlight the need for flexibility as we proposed it for the ESI strand. Re-introducing fixed percentages for sub-strands would reduce this flexibility and hence make it more difficult to react to new challenges. Last, but not least, Parliament, in particular the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), proposes significant amendments to the health strand for the ESF+. I note that many of these proposals seem to reflect a desire to keep the health programme as a separate instrument, as it is today. While respecting Parliament’s view, the Commission is convinced that greater synergies and coherence between programmes, and closer coordination and consistency, will maximise the impact of EU health measures and will benefit citizens, health professionals and policymakers.  The new architecture of the ESF+ will not only preserve a specific health strand, which will continue to support public health policies to fulfil the objective of ensuring a high level of health protection, but will also ensure that, wherever they are relevant, health aspects are addressed in all social spending. As always, honourable Members, I am now eager to listen to the debate.

name: Karine GLOANEC MAURIN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the ESF Regulation is an opportunity to provide fair, equitable and effective tools for social Europe that we socialists and democrats have been calling for for many years. On the substance of the report - and the Committee on Budgets, of course, supported this good report - I would like to highlight the following three priorities: the revaluation of a fund for the most disadvantaged populations and the fight against unemployment, with, above all, the integration of the children's guarantee; Support for food banks - this is important - and for NGOs working to alleviate food deprivation, poverty and social exclusion; and finally, the necessary balance between the funds thus merged, when there is a possible flexibility. In order to support these three key points, of course, we had to fight in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. I would like to thank my colleague, Brando Benifei, who fought this fight despite the resistance, and sometimes even the opposition, of political forces who would like us to believe that they are progressive. I wanted to report it. This fund will, of course, be part of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF). It is now up to the Board to arbitrate so that it is accessible to as many people as possible.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, it is the strong conviction of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) that, under shared management, the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) should pursue the goal of ‘investment for jobs and growth’, as set out in the future Common Provisions Regulation (CPR), and contribute to the policy objective of a more social Europe, implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights set out in the same regulation. In accordance with this policy objective, the ESF+ should support a number of specific objectives, of which the first is to improve access to quality and sustainable employment that adheres to all existing union labour laws and respects the rights of all job seekers – in particular the young and long—term unemployed and inactive people – while promoting self—employment and the social economy.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too will confine myself to a few specific points in the report that we have drawn up, as the Committee on Regional Development.  I would like to stress that, compared with the text proposed by the Commission, the European Parliament's text better recognises the clear role of the regions, both as beneficiaries and as managing authorities, in order to ensure greater effectiveness of the objectives set out in the proposal and to ensure adequate coordination between the ESF+ and the wider cohesion and regional policy.  I also welcome the Commission's intention to simplify the regulatory framework and believe that synergies and coordination between the Social Fund and the other funds are an important factor in improving.  Finally, the Commission's proposal establishes a link between the European Semester and the country-specific recommendations and ESF investments. However, adequate flexibility should be ensured at the level of managing authorities, both national and regional, in order to identify the priorities and sectors in which investment is needed, with the need to better define the relationship between cohesion policy and the European Semester, so that it is the latter that acquires a greater social dimension.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, I would like to thank the Education is the key to social participation. However, we in the European Union still have a problem of justice in this area, because education is still too dependent on the level of education, but above all on parents' pockets. This problem does not stop at the Erasmus programme, which we so much love, and that is precisely why we want to significantly develop it. I am therefore very pleased that we in Parliament have been able to agree to support the desired development of Erasmus in the future by improving the use of ESF+ in education, by creating synergies between the European Social Fund and the Erasmus programme.  Funds will be used to prepare disadvantaged learners appropriately and actively for mobility experiences and to increase their participation in cross-border learning experiences. This is an important innovation, because education is one of the most important prerequisites for breaking the eternal cycle of poverty. Only those who have the necessary equipment can be successful in our society personally, socially and professionally, and experience abroad is now simply part of it. I can only hope that the Member States will now make appropriate use of these opportunities and put the pressing issue of education at the top of the agenda.

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, our main goal in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) was to ensure that the ESF+ becomes a tool to protect, develop and empower people. We wanted to ensure that future projects will be as inclusive and non-discriminatory as possible, that they will enable everybody in the EU to have better life prospects, and that, through this fund, we can stop maintaining systems of discrimination and exclusion and show that we take very seriously the values we set jointly in our Treaties. We wanted, with the help of this fund, to achieve the transformation of our society into a sustainable society, something to which we committed ourselves by signing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Let me finish by expressing my gratitude to the rapporteur, Ms Lope Fontagné, and also to Brando Benifei for their excellent cooperation during the shadow rapporteurs’ meetings.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! First of all, I congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their effective work on this report. The European Social Fund, whose tasks include eradicating poverty, unemployment, greater mobility, social cohesion and a number of others, are familiar to us. We tabled amendments to this report and this fund in the FEMM Committee, which additionally addressed inequalities between women and men in these problems. We must bear in mind that the same problems have different causes for women and men, for example, women's inactivity. The reason for this inactivity of women is primarily the lack of crèches, kindergartens, care services for the elderly, and the cause of men's inactivity is health problems. So if we want to fight these problems, we must seek care infrastructure and services, a domestic worker market for women, and implement health prevention programmes for men. All this falls within the European Social Fund. Just one more sentence. I would like to express my satisfaction that there are increased resources in the future for non-discrimination. The issue of minorities and women's rights can also be better protected through this.
