name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Mr Fontagné, for the excellent work we have done together. The new European Social Fund has an essential task: to credibly transform the European pillar of social rights into concrete rules and resources useful for the daily lives of European citizens. For this reason, I am proud to have contributed with my amendments to strengthening the European Commission's text, with concrete improvements on the issue of work, training and the fight against poverty and social exclusion. The resources for the youth guarantee will be increased, as will the resources for new digital skills, as well as the percentages to be allocated to social inclusion programmes and the European Aid Fund for the most deprived. We have given centrality to people with disabilities to ensure access to high-quality services, work, education and training. The new Social Fund will finally be able to co-finance income support measures, such as the inclusion income introduced recently in Italy. We have extended the EaSI fund for social innovation, allowing, as we have long been asked for, direct access by local authorities and third sector organisations to European funds, to finance integration programmes at local level. We have finally, after a great battle of many years, introduced a new programme, the youth guarantee, which will allow the many young people from disadvantaged economic or social conditions to have free access to essential services, such as health care, education, quality childcare, decent housing and adequate nutrition. We will now start negotiations with the Member States, aware that ours is an ambitious text, worthy of the role of the European Parliament as the first defender of people's rights, a role to be rediscovered in order to restore confidence in the European project that unites us.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The renewed European Social Fund Plus is europe's stronger social dimension. This is not only an integrated development of social infrastructure, but above all an investment in human capital. In order for today's workers to cope with globalisation, digitalisation, modern technology, to ensure smart and sustainable economic growth, a high level of human health, improved employment opportunities, we need a modern welfare system that fits into new forms of work and an ageing population. However, in my opinion, the following issues have not been very clear in this modern European social opening: for example, good investment in the future of the younger generation, better conditions for people with disabilities, clear support for the Roma minority, concrete investment in NGOs and in micro, small and medium-sized enterprises. It is also important not to be repulsed by the rigid rules of Member States' initiatives in shared management, including the financing of transnational cooperation operations, and above all to ensure a consistent interpretation and transparency of the rules.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, allow me to thank the rapporteur, co-rapporteurs and the Commission for their good work on an important file. This file is the EU’s main financial instrument to invest in people, and is key in strengthening social cohesion, improving social fairness and increasing competitiveness across Europe. We have debated over months and agreed to outline the goals of this file together with the recommendations for country analysis provided by the European Semester. I am happy that we managed to put together a higher focus on the social economy, skills forecasting, digital skills, early childhood education and care. We managed as well to put earmarks for youth employment and to try to achieve some flexibility for the next period. Crises will happen in the next period as well – like in this one – and it is important to have flexibility in order to cope with them successfully. But what we mainly managed to do is to support the long-term integration of migrants into countries across Europe. These people are here whether you like it or not, whatever your proposal is for the solution for this problem, the country has to have the capacity and money in order to do the necessary work for the integration of these people into European society. And I am very proud that we succeeded in doing that. We stressed the need to provide stronger support for single parents, use funds more effectively than today, and to replace access to regular education. I think this file will not achieve miracles, like any other file, but I think that it will contribute to seeing a better and stronger Europe in the next mandate.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a growing social divide is one of the biggest threats that the European Union is facing right now, and the Brexit referendum especially has shown that there is a group of people in the European Union – not only in the UK but also in other Member States – who fear their social problems are not being addressed. We have to address their social problems: not by leaving a community of solidarity, not by leaving the European Union, but by making the European Union more socially just and addressing problems of social inequality. The European Social Fund is one of the puzzle pieces needed in order to make that happen: to strengthen the fight against energy and housing poverty, to tackle a just transition and to fight against social exclusion. The European Parliament, with this proposal, has proved that it is ready to pick this fight and to tackle inequality, and now we need to see the Council and the Member States, too, showing their readiness to do that. If they don’t, they will be endangering the future of the European Union as a whole.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the negotiation of the Structural Funds cannot take place for fear of electoral costs. Whether we want a social Europe or not. The European Union budget is being reduced in its entirety for the next budgetary period and expenditure on social issues is also being reduced. At a time when we have new needs, an ageing population, our youth who are out of work, the migration, the poverty that plagues. Europe finally needs to have a social face, or it will be destroyed by the righteous indignation of its world. We need specific objectives on social issues and these objectives must be as binding as economic ones.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I welcome the Commission's proposal for a new regulation on the European Social Fund. I believe that the integration of the financial resources of several complementary instruments so far can have a positive impact on increasing the effectiveness of support. A good step towards transparency is also the creation of a single overarching objective supported by 11 specific objectives focused on the most important issues of the labour market, education and social inclusion. I am also pleased that Parliament's position also calls for greater emphasis on the role of the regions, as they will not only be beneficiaries and managing authorities of the future ESF Plus, but above all have the most knowledge and many years of experience. They are just the closest to the citizen. It is good that, already at the level of work in the Committee on Employment, we have been able to reach a compromise satisfactory to all political groups. I hope for smooth negotiations with the Council so that the final document is adopted without undue delay.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, poverty is poison in our nations. In Europe, one in four children is at increased risk of poverty or social exclusion. It is children who grow into young people, they are young people who grow into adults and it is those adults who are at risk of never catching up again. Backlog of job probability, a backlog of the chances of good health care.  That is why there is a proud Social Democrat in front of you. On our initiative, the Children's Guarantee has been put to parliament's role. I am proud that Parliament is freeing up EUR 5.9 billion to combat social injustice. As far as I am concerned, child poverty is leaving the Union, and I think this report is going to make an important contribution to this.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by welcoming the existence of this Fund and its purpose as an engine for financing social policies and employment. However, this, which is a good instrument, has to improve at least in the following respects.  The first and fundamental is to give it a greater economic amount. Having plunged European workers into precariousness, the cost of solving social and labour problems is much higher than before.  As for the latter, it is essential to concrete priority projects through social dialogue – equal opportunities, training, youth employment and so on – and for this, it is positive to create and use synergies with other funds, such as the InvestEU.  It is also necessary to streamline and simplify the management of the same.  Despite all this, it will not be enough to solve the structural problems of the European Union, as long as we do not end, inter alia, the conditions of the European Semester.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, Dear Commissioner and ladies and gentlemen, I hope that this European Social Fund coming out of this effectively strengthened Parliament, which is now more, will not leave the priorities of the social rights pillar on paper. To this end, two conditions must be checked: first, it must be a simplified programme in its access and, secondly, it must be demanding in its attribution, meeting only the real needs of Europeans and not contributing to party propaganda.  This requires that social and geographical barriers in access to this fund be overcome, but only projects that translate into greater social development are supported, highlighting here the Youth Guarantee programme, which aims to support young people in unemployment who are not trained.  All this becomes even more relevant in rural areas with specific contingencies and with fewer economic and labour opportunities, which brings me to the last note: that the European Social Fund does not forget that we are the Europe of the regions and that one of its main objectives is to eliminate the divisions that still persist between them, providing different answers to different realities.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Mr President, unemployment, high levels of poverty, social exclusion remain a priority problem throughout the European Union. We must therefore strive for the real implementation of the social pillars of European and European social rights by increasing employment and social progress, promoting equality between women and men, and we must combat poverty and, in particular, child poverty, and social policies must be adequately financed in order to implement all this. We therefore need to increase the budget of the European Social Fund and at least one third of the European Social Fund + resources must be allocated to the fight against poverty and social exclusion. That is why our Social Democrat group is asking for at least six billion children to be guaranteed from this fund so that we can overcome extreme child poverty in Europe, and a second ESF+ should help to combat poverty among older women across the EU, as women's pensions are as much as 40% lower than for men. Finally, if a woman has every opportunity to actively reconcile working life and family commitments, it will also increase women's employment in the labour market and reduce their poverty.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. It is the case that only what you can experience, what you can understand, you will find well in the long term and support it. The ESF+ finances projects across Europe that make Europe tangible for thousands of people. Especially in regions that are not so economically developed, the question is increasingly being asked: what do we have of Europe? The Social Fund is giving the right and decisive answer: Europe is investing in the people. Training, social security or reintegration into the labour market and society will be supported. All this is financed by the European Social Fund. When it comes to structural change, Europe is not leaving people alone. Today, poverty is still hereditated. We can now interrupt this if we give children social rights along the way. That is why we are calling for Europe to provide basic and important things for children affected by poverty: free school meals, free textbooks, and if parents' money is not enough to go out to school, schools must be able to take money into their hands.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We need more money to combat youth unemployment. We need this money to give young people in Europe perspectives to guarantee all children in Europe a heated children's room.  Of course, every child has a right to a school snack. In other words, we need a funded child guarantee to ensure that every child in the European Union has access to free health care, good accommodation and adequate nutrition.  This means that the ESF+ should be increased, not cut. We need this money so that we do not only talk in Sunday speeches about what to do, but actually do it here in the European Union.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A key objective in the European Social Fund Plus is to improve the quality, efficiency and relevance of education and training programmes for the labour market. Actions co-financed by the Fund must enable the acquisition of the competences actually needed in the market, including digital skills. In particular, the latter will be crucial in the coming years. The emerging transformation of the economy, as well as the emergence of 4.0 industries, will require specific competences. The fund must be used to strengthen the competences of workers and people who are just entering the labour market. As technological developments are taking place very quickly, it is important that the Fund also provides better forecasting of changes in the labour market. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her commitment and very good work on the Fund. I agree with the rapporteur that the Fund should be complemented by improved access to employment also for disadvantaged people. Through the Fund, it is necessary to promote not only self-employment, but also employment in general.  I also agree with the proposal that Member States with problems with young people in the NEET category should allocate a greater share of the Fund's resources to support young people.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, disabled people, young offenders and the long-term unemployed in the UK risk losing critical support if Brexit goes ahead, due to the loss of GBP 500 million per year from the European Social Fund (ESF). UK Youth, which represents 40 local youth associations across England, estimates that when accounting for the loss of funds from both the ESF and the European Regional Development Fund, youth services would lose about GBP 160 million per year after Brexit.  As a member of the EU, the UK receives significant funding for young people, who have disproportionately experienced the consequences of austerity. Since the Tories took office in 2010, there has been GBP 737 million worth of cuts in the youth service across England. Merseyside Youth Association in my region said that without ESF about 800 long-term unemployed young people would lose out on employability support each year, 40 direct staff jobs would go, leaving more than 21 600 vulnerable young people without life-changing support. The people of Liverpool voted to remain in the EU. Let’s hope that is still possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, globalisation, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment have created millions of the poor and unemployed and it is obvious that the European Social Fund+ with the actions it must take can move at various levels. First of all, to tackle child poverty, because child poverty has reached very high levels. To support the long-term unemployed, to support our young jobseekers and, at the same time, they must have training and training tools at their disposal in order to be able to stand in the new globalised environment. Furthermore, disabled people also need the support of the European Social Fund+ which can spread to many levels even in terms of hygiene and employment-related actions.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the proposal, rather than its architecture and objectives, the programmes it involves or the financial distribution it carries out, is compromised by the full subordination to the European Semester, the insufficient funds, the conditionality of the programme to the Commission's desiderates, as well as the articulation it intends to promote with the InvestEU fund.  In so that the programme can have a more significant impact, particularly in Portugal, we have made forward a number of changes: the subordination of the programme to national development strategies and fully shared management, the guarantee of appreciation and increased investment in universal and quality free public services, particularly in the health and education sectors, the use of the fund as an instrument to address social problems and challenges , in particular in job creation and the integration of strategies to combat poverty, the significant increase in the Fund's budget. These changes represent an opportunity to give you robustness and reach.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I believe that this new regulation on the European Social Fund will contribute to a more efficient use of funds. There should be no overlap of funds and projects could combine multiple objectives. The new rules should facilitate implementation and reduce administrative burdens. I also have a positive view of the greater link between funding and the European Semester process. I believe that this should allocate resources to key priorities in which Member States show unsatisfactory results. Socio-economic disparities between Member States should also be overcome more over time. I also appreciate the greater flexibility in investing funds and therefore leaving a great possibility to adapt funding according to the national context. In the Czech Republic, for example, we will be able to continue to support children's groups, micro-nursery and educational programmes.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, let me thank the rapporteur. It is a sad truth that many social challenges remain in European society. More than 100 million citizens are at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In the Czech Republic alone, there are 863,000 inhabitants who have entered a debt trap that ended in execution. This, of course, poses a huge problem, which is also related to the fact that debt people very often do not believe in justice. These problems not only threaten the well-being of directly affected citizens, but lead to economic and social pressure on the whole of European society. I am therefore very happy that the European Social Fund plus will support investment in people and policy systems such as employment, public services, health, education and social inclusion. The European Union must never forget that the best investment is in people and in a better quality of life. Our citizens deserve the best conditions to develop freely in a peaceful society.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate, first of all, Mrs Lope Fontagné for the excellent work she has done in this dossier. The European Social Fund has been a key part of European cohesion. Europe today faces social challenges with an increasingly elderly population and therefore needs more and better care. This is an increased pressure on the social and health services of the Member States which must have a multiannual Union strategy that goes beyond their policies and can be complementary to it. In fact, the amount allocated to the health item by this renewed European Social Fund, which involves the extinction of the European Union health programme, is EUR 413 million and a total of EUR 101.2 billion. It should be noted that this fund is ambitious in providing for its use to improve fair and timely access to quality, sustainable and comfortable-priced health services involving from primary care, long-term care, more citizen-centred care, these are provided by proximity units, centres of excellence or by informal or family carers. And, ladies and gentlemen, i am sure that is the case, because that is why we ensure that no citizen is left on the path in the construction of the European project.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Mr President, the European Union can remain competitive in the global economy only if it maintains a high level of employment, education, health and social inclusion of its people. The skills gap, particularly in the digital sphere, and the lack of a link between education systems, on the one hand, and the labour market, on the other hand, have a detrimental impact on European society as a whole. Therefore, investment in human capital is very important for active growth in the European economy and the ESF+ is an investment in human capital. As rapporteur for the Youth Employment Initiative, I welcome the fact that the ESF+ programme is of particular concern to the youth field and that even a minimum percentage is set for young people under this programme.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate has further demonstrated the importance of the ESF+ and Parliament’s report will be a solid foundation for the interinstitutional negotiations. As always, the Commission is open to discussion in the trilogues and will play its role as an honest broker. I very much hope, and I am confident, that the Council under the Romanian Presidency will, for its part, advance further on the ESF+ Regulation with a view to its adoption in 2019, well in time for the next programming round. EU funding for investing in people is the tangible illustration of our European values, promoting equality, social fairness and social progress through concrete actions to empower and protect our citizens – the unemployed and the employed, men and women, EU natives or citizens born outside the European Union – and this from early childhood on. The ESF+ is a tool with direct visibility to citizens. It is an instrument to help achieve social cohesion and upward social convergence. I am convinced that, thanks to the strong commitment on the part of the European co-legislators, and Parliament in particular, the European Union will be better placed to deliver on our citizens’ legitimate expectations in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. Thank you, to those concerned, for your hard work. Thank you for the fact that you advanced as quickly as you did, and congratulations to all those who participated in this, and specifically to the rapporteur.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, once again, I would like to express my appreciation for the good harmony between colleagues and teams in the negotiation of this report and, of course, for the Commission's proposal. With the limited time we have had, I believe that we have managed to agree on a strong and balanced text, which has been possible because we all had a common objective, the social improvement of Europe, which has made us avoid maximalist positions in order to achieve the greatest possible consensus. I am aware that we have all had to give in on a few points, but I think that the agreement reached in the Committee on Employment will be useful for European citizens, regardless of where they live. In order to improve economic, social and territorial cohesion, the Fund will be in line with the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights and Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and, therefore, the different territorial realities within and between Member States, such as depopulation, will be taken into account. In this way, we will send two clear messages. The first is citizenship. European citizens are the main concern of the European Union and we will therefore work to improve their living conditions. And the second message is addressed to the Council. From the European Parliament we have done our job. The work has paid off and, if the report is adopted, as I hope, we are prepared to begin negotiations. As rapporteur, even knowing that it is difficult, I hope that the Romanian Presidency will be able to approve its mandate in sufficient time to begin negotiations and I hope, like most colleagues, that we can finish the report in this parliamentary term.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 16 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – Since 1958, the European Social Fund has been contributing to increasing unemployment, improving training and education, social inclusion and combating poverty. In recent years, we have seen that it is the ESF that has also made a significant contribution to reducing youth unemployment, where we have ensured, through many programmes, that young people are entitled to employment, traineeships or retraining after graduation. Individual projects have contributed to improving economic, social and territorial cohesion. I would like to pay tribute to the fact that the EP Committee on Employment and Social Affairs is pushing for an increase of 19% in ESF+ funding in 2021-2027 compared to the European Commission's original proposal, from EUR 89.6 billion to EUR 106.8 billion. This is good news for the populations of individual Member States, because the Fund will be able to support various activities not only for young people, but also for children from poor families, who, through various programmes, will be given the opportunity to develop their talents, but also to actively engage in leisure activities, thereby ensuring their social exclusion as a result of economic poverty.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Europe is at a crucial time when its relevance and success in the coming decades will be driven by its ability to remain competitive in the world economy and to ensure high levels of employment, education and training, health, social inclusion and active participation in society. For Europe to be competitive and united in the future, I believe that it is necessary to invest in its citizens today. Furthermore, given that the European Social Fund is the Union's main instrument focusing on employment, skills and social inclusion, it is essential that most of this programme is redirected with a view to improving social, economic and territorial cohesion in all parts of the Union. To this end, I would like to stress the following point: support should be provided to improve the quality, accessibility, inclusion, effectiveness and relevance of the labour market in education and training systems. One of the concrete measures we need at the moment is the acquisition of key competences, particularly in terms of digital skills, including the data protection and information management skills that all people must fulfil in this digital age.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – According to statistics, more than EUR 100 million Europeans suffer poverty and material disadvantages every day, and we all know that poverty is a violation of human rights, because it loses access to all their other rights. Recognising the negative effects of poverty in the report, we must pay particular attention to eradicating all forms of poverty in all its aspects, including extreme poverty, which is the world's greatest challenge.  The European Union can only remain competitive if it is competitive in the global economy, provided that it maintains a high level of employment, education, health and social inclusion. The fact that there are skills gaps, in particular those relating to the digital field, as well as the still insufficient correlation in many sectors between education and training systems and the labour market, has a negative impact on European society as a whole. And that needs to change. The European Social Fund + (ESF+) should be, in particular, a fund to invest in people, their development and their needs. It should cover the most difficult moments of our lives, provide support in the fields of education and training, employment and social and care services. Particular attention should be paid to the needs of persons with disabilities.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. We see that growing social inequality is one of the greatest threats to which the European Union is currently facing. With the European Social Fund Plus, we have an instrument that combats this inequality directly in the regions. With concrete projects, such as initiatives against energy poverty and housing projects for socially disadvantaged people, the ESF+ supports where it is urgently needed. As Greens, it is particularly important to us that civil society is more involved in the planning, implementation and evaluation of projects. This principle of partnership will be strengthened. In the future, more social projects in the European Union will also benefit from increased financial support. In doing so, we are taking another step towards social union. With this proposal, the European Parliament is demonstrating its willingness to actively combat inequalities.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Pascal Arimont, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the specific provisions for the European Territorial Cooperation (Interreg) objective supported by the European Regional Development Fund and external financing instruments (COM(2018)0374 - C8-0229/2018 - 2018/0199(COD)) (A8-0470/2018).

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I have just watched the vote in the House of Commons with great excitement and have found that the negotiated deal has been scrapped by a large majority.  Brexit also means the end of cross-border cooperation. Interreg actually means exactly the opposite. As a resident of a border region in eastern Belgium, I speak from my own experience when I say that this Interreg programme has been contributing for many years – it was launched in 1990 – to the fact that many border regions have become common areas. That remains very important. Border barriers – also and above all in people's minds – must continue to be overcome piece by piece. That is why this report is also symbolically important.  As the negotiator of this Parliament, I have been very much in favour of further promoting cross-border cooperation. We have had to deal with 946 amendments and we have drawn up 46 compromise proposals, which has resulted in all parties unanimously adopting this report when they voted in committee. Because – and this was a bit of the leitmotif of all – border regions must not be dead ends, but must reflect a living Europe. In this sense, the Interreg support programme stands for the opposite of foreclosure. With our report, therefore, we as a Parliament are sending out a clear signal. For example, the Commission planned to fix the total amount of funding of EUR 8.4 billion for the forthcoming funding period. However, even if this will only be determined later in the MFF negotiations, we have already provided for an estimated EUR 11.1 billion, which means that we have increased the budget, because that is important to us. It is important that cross-border cooperation can be practised without cuts, as is currently the case. We are of a very clear opinion that there must be no cuts.  Cross-border cooperation is vital for the whole of Europe, especially at a time when there is an increasing need to raise internal borders. People at the borders – many of them cross-border workers – simply do not understand why there are still obstacles at the borders. It is precisely these people who first notice what works in Europe and what does not.  Interreg projects are in many cases also pilot projects for a stronger integration of our regions. They create solutions to very specific problems between different regions and border regions. This way of finding a solution is what Europe really needs.  It was also important to us, when dealing with the legislative proposal, simply promoting practical cross-border projects. It was important to us that more money was provided. It was important to us that the promoters do not have to change their structures on the ground. These have worked well over the years. Why change what works well? We should not do this. Quite the opposite. It was also important to us that the so-called micro-projects, the people-to-people projects, such as cooperation between associations across the border, can be defined as an integral part of the programme and can also be implemented more easily.  Overall, I am pleased that we have written a very practical text that has nothing to do with the often invoked Brussels ivory tower. The proposals came from local stakeholders. We have worked very well with the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee. We need to reduce controls and paperwork, which is really a hurdle for many associations, companies and organisations. That is what we have to do now. I believe that the Commission's proposals also went in the right direction.  We have also defined the criteria in such a way that they prepare for the future. In other words, we have defined criteria for dealing with problems relating to the promotion of SMEs, the security situation and climate change. All of this means that we have to define this Interreg programme as a symbol. If a head of an advertising agency had to make a film about Europe, he would have to invite all the persons of these agencies so that Interreg's projects ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you once more for giving me the floor this evening. On behalf of the Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Arimont, and the shadow rapporteurs for the quality of this report and for your ongoing support for European Territorial Cooperation (ETC), also known as Interreg. The Commission also wishes to praise the Committee on Regional Development (REGI) for having worked swiftly. With the tight schedule ahead of us, it is indeed paramount to be ready and steady when the next programming period starts. The Commission is confident that the Council will do its utmost to maintain the momentum on this important file, enabling the launch of negotiations soon. This is all the more important as European Territorial Cooperation embodies the very essence of our European project: getting together beyond boundaries to address common challenges.  Allow me to highlight some of the key novelties of our proposals. The aim is to revisit the Interreg architecture of programmes so as to reduce overlaps and fragmentation, thereby increasing the impact on the territories targeted by the programmes. Here the proposal underlines the importance of functional areas such as sea basins. At the same time, the proposal provides means to preserve cross—border or bilateral cooperation, notably in the maritime sector. The aim of the proposal is also to reinforce the strategic dimension of the future programmes by linking them more strongly with existing strategic framework policy initiatives and finally, to radically simplify the whole framework in order to dedicate fewer resources to administrative and control tasks and focus much more on results and real impact. The Commission appreciates that you recognise this important effort to simplify and calls upon you to work together to maintain these simplification measures. Finally, in Interreg programmes the cross-border cooperation will focus more than before on institutional cooperation, resolving border issues and investing in joint services of public interest. Overall, by mainstreaming and simplifying European Territorial Cooperation, we can strengthen it and take it to another level.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am a child of the Euregio Maas-Rhine. Around four million people live in this region – Belgians, Dutch and Germans. Why is it so important that we have Interreg in such regions? Because Interreg crosses borders. Cooperation between universities, the cross-border labour market, many programmes bring people together here and make these people fun. And that is exactly what we expect of Europe: that Europe is fun. I would like to stress that it is important that we, as a Parliament, have asked for more money for these programmes, because we not only want the tried and tested programmes to continue, but we must also develop this tool so that Europe can continue to grow together. However, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control, it is also important for me to stress the importance of reducing the administrative burden. When administration takes more time than the project itself, it doesn't make people so much fun anymore. We want to inspire people in Europe, and Europe must be fun. That is why it is important that we develop these programmes further.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Rapporteur għal opinjoni tal-Kumitat għall-Kultura u l-Edukazzjoni. – Sur President, Sur Kummissarju, l-istrumenti finanzjarji li huma msemmija f'dan ir-rapport huma importanti ħafna għall-iżvilupp reġjonali, għall-kultura u l-progress successfultiv fl-Unjoni Ewropea. Dawn huma kru大jali jekk għandna l-għan li jkollna Unjoni Ewropea li fiha d.c. jħossuhom parti minnha u li toffri opportunitajiet indaqs li大-大ittadini kollha, jiġu minn fejn jiġu. Il-proposti tiegħi fil-Kumitat CULT jinsistu li l-kultura u l-edukazzjoni huma importanti jekk irridu neliminaw il-fruntieri reġjonali. Għalhekk irridu niżguraw fund suffi大jenti għal dan l-għan. Filwaqt li nagħraf ix-xogħol tajjeb li għamel ir-Rapporteur, fejn għandha x'taqsam il-politika reġjonali, irridu nagħtu importanza wkoll lir-ri大erka u l-edukazzjoni għax dawn jgħinu biex tingħata spinta flower-kompetittività u l-innovazzjoni u għat-tkabbir ekono sod-reġjuni kollha-Unjoni. Il-messaġġ li rridu nagħtu hu wieħed – li fl-Unjoni kulħadd huwa meqjus indaqs irrispettivament minn liemaġ rejun wieħed ikun ġej. Aħna Unjoni Ewropea mingħajr fruntieri tal-art jew baħar, ta' kulturi u lingwi differenti u benniena ta' opportunitajiet.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I do think that it is not today that cross-border cooperation is something of the past, but of today. If you look in Northern Ireland alone – where we have recently been with a delegation – what it means in sparsely populated areas to actually introduce cooperation with universities and schools, new technology, energy generation and so on, then you need each other in the border areas.  Border areas are the scars of the past and then you see what that means. But in some other areas, for example, those Interreg programmes have enabled them to continue and achieve higher education, for example in some other areas, which have not been prioritised, such as London, in Scotland. Twenty years ago, a base for today's economy.  In the enlargement of the Union, the experience seen in the so-called old Member States was immediately applied there. You saw how people wanted to work together in languages, in everyday things.  Two more comments. So it's not obsolete at all, it's very, very modern. And certainly also the almost EUR 1 billion that is now being made available for these interregional, innovative projects. Sometimes projects are too small to do them together directly on the sides of the border, but you look for another region or city to make pace, creating scale, for example for 3D printing. Applying new technologies more quickly, and that is what the Commission's new initiative has brought into territorial cooperation here. I think that's a great initiative. Not old politics, but doing the things that are necessary now and also in the next seven years with the new programme. Bravo.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, like many of those who have spoken, I come from a border region and for all of us Interreg has been an extraordinary tool for teaching cooperation between different territories, and I believe that this is one of its extraordinary European added values. In recent years, the European Union has been, and above all thanks to Interreg, an instrument for promoting a plan for growth and peace, and thousands of communities have collaborated with the most diverse projects, many of which have radically improved the lives of their citizens. We have also developed instruments such as the European Grouping of Territorial Cooperation, which have enabled us to do better.  Today, as Members of this House, we can be proud that even at a difficult time we have managed – and we hope it will be confirmed – to guarantee over EUR 11 billion for the projects of the next term of office, greatly increasing those proposed by the Commission. This is a great achievement which we hope will be confirmed.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, cross-border cooperation is one of the most visible expressions of European cooperation. The Interreg programmes have been doing a good job for decades to promote this, to get people to work across borders, to allow people to use each other's facilities or to better connect infrastructure across borders.  I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament intends to allocate EUR 11 billion to financially support cross-border cooperation. That money is also badly needed, because we are also going to support something new in the future. It has already been said that the so-called interregional innovative investments.  Nearly €1 billion will be allocated to joint innovative investments by knowledge institutions, companies and governments based in various European countries. This means that we will join forces at European level to develop and bring new products and services to market. In addition, the location of the investment is no longer a guide to the financial support given from Europe, but the way in which an investment can create as much European added value as possible. By investing together in innovation on a European scale, the European Union can become more competitive on a global scale with, for example, the United States or China. This results in more cooperation and more cohesion in Europe, but ultimately also more European jobs, more growth, more prosperity.  Finally, I hope that we can enter into negotiations with the Council very quickly on this new regulation. This is particularly important in order to get the new Interreg programmes launched in 2021, thereby blurring borders in Europe even further.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. It is good that we are accompanying the report with a debate – a debate – because it deserves it, even though it is now midnight. It was originally intended that the report would only be presented briefly in plenary.  After all, there is hardly a European policy area that is so committed to the European idea of cross-border cooperation and cohesion – the internal cohesion of the European Union – as the objective of European territorial cooperation. Although national borders have become largely porous, there are still different legal systems and administrative structures between the Member States of the European Union, which make cross-border cooperation more difficult for citizens in border regions.  The Interreg programmes can help here, and they have helped to ensure that citizens can jointly solve problems and implement projects across state borders in the often structurally weak border areas. This regulation is intended to form the basis for further support for cross-border cooperation for the next funding period. In doing so, we must ensure that the possibilities for cooperation are not reduced, but extended, that the financial resources made available are not reduced, but at least maintained. Bureaucracy that has been built up in recent years must be reduced. And a major step forward in the new regulation is that territorial cooperation is no longer confined to the Member States of the European Union, but can be linked to the instruments of the Neighbourhood Policy and development cooperation.  Our rapporteur, Pascal Arimont, has qualified the Commission proposal considerably in terms of improved possibilities. We should give it the go-ahead by a large majority. It is a very important regulation and that is why it should take us some time.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! European territorial cooperation – by promoting the value of action across borders and uniting Europeans – is, in my opinion, the essence of what the European Union is. I am therefore all the more pleased that its value has been confirmed by a separate regulation dedicated to it. I also believe that the solutions it proposes, in particular simplifications, such as the possibility of using lump sums, simplified costs, better access for smaller beneficiaries or avoiding multiple checks, will make the added value of the ETC even more noticeable. I am also pleased that the role of the border regions and the importance of cross-border cooperation, which have been adequately reflected in the budget, have been recognised. I agree with the rapporteur that, in order for interreg programmes to be fully exploited, a higher level of co-financing than proposed is necessary. I therefore support the proposed ceiling of 85%. I also share the rapporteur's concern about the change of the n+3 to n+2 rule, which may have negative consequences in the form of a loss of funds due to the lack of sufficient time to use them. I saved five minutes of time, Mr President, as part of a speech by my colleague Joachim Zeller, which was very great and wise.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: We agree on the quality of Joachim's statements. You saved 5 seconds, not 5 minutes, but everything is right.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: – Mr President, although wall rhetoric and manifest selfishness abound in these times, logic prevails when the well-being of our citizens is at stake.  Cooperation is the path to progress and this is evidenced by the experience shared by Spain and Portugal, because, since 1989, collaboration between the administrations of both countries has allowed to improve the quality of life in regions such as Galicia, Alentejo, Algarve or Castilla y León.  Today this cooperation is articulated through the Interreg programme, which manages de facto to erase the border line to boost growth that benefits both Spanish and Portuguese.  This example ilusters the importance of effectively managing across common borders, especially when regional funds could suffer cuts in the next multiannual financial framework.  But one thing is clear: cohesion policy must be protected, maintained and promoted, because it improves people's lives with projects like Interreg's. In a context where populismos are listed upwards, funding that helps build hospitals, schools and roads needs to be boosted.  Removing barriers to common life is the Ultimate Goal of the Union. Let us then bet on coexistence and efficient management, for public services at the level of our citizens and for more and better Europe. And let's start with Interreg.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, European territorial cooperation plays an important role in cohesion policy and is an essential element in the development of the regions. In this respect, the initiatives of the European Territorial Cooperation Groups have achieved remarkable results in the implementation of projects financed by structural and investment funds. Member States should therefore confer on these groups enhanced management capacity functions and encourage local and regional authorities to set up cooperation groups with legal and investment management capacity. The definition of 'regional integration and cooperation organisations' as a group of regions in the same geographical area, with the objective of closer cooperation in areas of common interest, aims to establish specific regional development objectives aimed at the common interest of the regions. In this context, I appreciate the efforts of some mayors in Romania, who have created the "Western Alliance", calling for increased powers to manage European funding in order to strengthen territorial cooperation.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are particularly pleased with the work that has been done.  The Commission's original proposal contained a number of critical issues, on which we successfully intervened in the amending and negotiating phase. Firstly, we have given the cross-border maritime programmes the right importance, bringing them back to the first axis of 'cross-border cooperation'. We have increased the total share of resources allocated to Interreg – almost 11 billion – and raised both the EU co-financing threshold to 80 %, and the pre-financing rates, thus giving regional and local authorities the liquidity they need to finance projects on the ground.  I call on all my fellow Members, and in particular those who are interested in changing the absurd rules of current economic governance, to vote in favour of the two amendments tabled by the Movement for the Break-up from the calculation of the national cofinancing deficit. With these very important votes on the new 2021-2027 programming, we will begin to see who is really to change this Europe and who is not.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have would like to say to the honourable Members, and especially the rapporteur, that I have listened very carefully to the debate and I would like to assure you on behalf of the Commission that European territorial cooperation will remain an essential component of cohesion policy and of our European policy tout court. The Commission takes note of the views of Parliament expressed during the discussion and I want to thank you specifically for your support regarding the promotion of interregional innovation investments. The Commission is also confident that, based on previous experience, there will be a high demand for these resources. Good work has been done so far. Today we want to make sure that we can continue in a simpler, more efficient framework and the Commission is confident that Parliament will be a strong partner in this endeavour. Thank you very much for your hard work and I very much hope, and am confident, that under the Romanian Presidency the Council will, for its part, advance also further on our Interreg proposal with a view to its adoption in 2019, well in time for the next programing round. I am sure that you all know how important that is also.  Thank you very much and also for having stayed here for the debate, and I wish you a good night.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the It gives me the honour of having the last two minutes of this parliamentary day here. The last two minutes do not stop me from saying thank you. First of all, thank you to all the Colleagues who took part in this debate. Thank you to all the shadow rapporteurs who have been actively involved in getting such a sensible text in place during the negotiations and during the shadow meetings. Thanks to the Commission, which has been actively involved in this process, has always been by our side. I would also like to link this with the request that we get the Romanian Presidency so motivated that it can draw up its general approach in the very short term, so that we can get into the trialogue and try to get this text negotiated as far as possible before the new Parliament has to bend further over this text. The aim must be that this text is clear for the new funding period and that the agencies and all the actors on the ground have a text for which they can prepare as quickly as possible, so that the programmes can be implemented very quickly on the ground. With this in mind, thank you very much for the excellent cooperation, and I hope that Interreg will continue to keep us in the future.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 16 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The main objective of the European territorial cooperation programmes or Interreg is to promote cooperation between Member States, their regions and neighbourhood partners, fostering dialogue between citizens and promoting the exchange of best experience and practices. As draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, External Trade, Research and Energy, I am pleased with the result achieved and with the text voted on in plenary, which aims to maintain the current structure of Interreg, while preserving cross-border maritime cooperation, which is fundamental for a continent of which the Mediterranean Sea is the beating heart.
